questions.text: Which of the following conditions will shift the Oxygen-Hb dissociation curve to the left? (FMGE DECEMBER 2021)
questions.solution:
Ans. C. Alkalosis

 

  • Alkalosis leads to a leftward shift in the oxygen-hemoglobin dissociation curve. This phenomenon, often referred to as the Bohr effect, involves changes in the blood's pH influencing hemoglobin's affinity for oxygen. In conditions of increased pH (alkalosis):
    • Hemoglobin's affinity for oxygen increases, causing the curve to shift left. This means hemoglobin holds onto oxygen more tightly, which can be advantageous in environments where oxygen needs to be retained in the blood, such as at high altitudes.
    • A left shift indicates that at a given partial pressure of oxygen, a higher percentage of hemoglobin is saturated with oxygen compared to normal conditions.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Hypoxia: Incorrect as hypoxia typically results in a compensatory rightward shift of the curve to facilitate more oxygen unloading to the tissues.

 

Option B. Hypercarbia: Incorrect because increased carbon dioxide (hypercarbia) leads to acidosis, which shifts the curve rightward, reducing hemoglobin's affinity for oxygen to aid in oxygen delivery to tissues.

 

Option D. Increase in 2,3-DPG: Incorrect as an increase in 2,3-DPG decreases hemoglobin's affinity for oxygen, shifting the curve rightward to enhance oxygen unloading in peripheral tissues.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Alkalosis will shift the Oxygen-Hb dissociation curve to the left factors responsible for shifting the curve right

 

  • Hypoxia
  • Hypercarbia
  • ﻿﻿Decrease in pH (acidosis)
  • ﻿﻿Increase in temperature
  • ﻿﻿Increased 2,3-DPG

 

Factors responsible for shifting the curve left

 

  •  Increase in pH (alkalosis)
  • ﻿﻿Decrease in PCO2
    • 2,3-DPG
    • Temperature
    • ﻿﻿HbF
    • ﻿﻿Carbon Monoxide

 

Oxygen-hemoglobin dissociation curve is shown below

questions.text: Which of the following enzyme deficiency is most likely to cause Classical Galactosemia in infants: (FMGE DECEMBER 2021)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) GALT (Galactose-1-phosphate Uridyl Transferase)

 

Classical Galactosemia is primarily caused by a deficiency of the enzyme Galactose-1-phosphate Uridyl Transferase (GALT). GALT is involved in the conversion of galactose-1-phosphate to glucose-1-phosphate in the galactose metabolism pathway.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Galactokinase: Galactokinase deficiency leads to minor type Galactosemia, a different form of galactose metabolism disorder with oil drop cataract formation but no hepatomegaly and jaundice.

 

Option C. UDP-galactose-4-Epimerase: Deficiency of UDP-galactose -4- Epimerase is a rare condition.

 

Option D. Glucose-6-phosphatase: Glucose-6-phosphatase is associated with disorders like Glycogen Storage Disease Type I (Von Gierke's disease).

 

Educational Objective:

 

Deficiency of GALT (Galactose-1-phosphate Uridyl Transferase) leads to the accumulation of toxic intermediates, including galactose-1-phosphate, causing various symptoms such as cataract, jaundice, hepatomegaly, mental retardation and oil drop cataract.

 

 

Ref: Harper’s Illustrated Biochemistry 32nd edition Page no. 198

questions.text: Cannon ball metastasis is seen due to which of the following? (FMGE DEC 2021)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Choriocarcinoma

 

Multiple nodular lesions in both hemi thorax, canon ball appearance is suggestive of lung metastasis.

 

Common causes are:

 

  • Follicular CA thyroid
  • Clear cell renal CA
  • Choriocarcinoma

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Retinoblastoma: Retinoblastoma is a malignant tumor of the retina, primarily affecting children. While it can metastasize, it typically does not present with cannon ball metastasis in the lungs.

 

Option C. Silicosis: Silicosis is an occupational lung disease caused by inhalation of silica dust. It is characterized by nodular pulmonary fibrosis, not by cannon ball metastasis.

 

Option D. Asbestosis: Asbestosis is a chronic lung disease caused by inhalation of asbestos fibers, leading to diffuse interstitial fibrosis. Like silicosis, it does not produce cannon ball metastases.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Cannon ball metastasis in the lungs is commonly seen in cases of choriocarcinoma, characterized by multiple large, round nodules in both lungs.

questions.text: A 72-year-old man presented with weight loss, decreased appetite, and iron deficiency anemia. Chest X-ray was done and given below. What is the diagnosis? (FMGE DEC 2021)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Lung metastasis

 

Lung metastasis refers to cancer that has spread from another part of the body to the lungs. This condition is characterized by the presence of multiple nodules in the lungs, often seen in a chest X-ray. The patient's symptoms of weight loss, decreased appetite, and iron deficiency anemia are nonspecific but can occur in the context of metastatic cancer.

 

In the context of a chest X-ray showing multiple nodules “cannon ball deposits” in lungs indicative of metastasis and a patient's systemic symptoms, lung is a strong consideration, especially when there is a known primary malignancy elsewhere in the body.

 

In a patient with iron deficiency anemia, this finding suggests a possible gastrointestinal malignancy, such as colorectal cancer, with metastases to the lungs. Thus, the diagnosis would be lung metastasis.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Bronchogenic carcinoma: Typically presents as a single mass rather than multiple nodules.

 

Option C. Miliary tuberculosis: Shows a diffuse pattern of numerous small nodules throughout the lung fields, which is different from the pattern seen in metastatic disease.

 

Option D. Mesothelioma: Primarily affects the pleura and presents with pleural thickening and effusion rather than multiple nodules in the lung parenchyma.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Lung metastasis is indicated by the presence of multiple nodules in the lungs, often accompanied by systemic symptoms like weight loss and decreased appetite in patients with known primary cancers​

questions.text: Intravenous anesthetic agent of choice for cardiac surgeries is? (FMGE DEC 2021)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Etomidate

 

Etomidate

 

  • Use: Etomidate is favored for cardiac surgeries because it has a minimal impact on hemodynamics. It maintains stable blood pressure and heart rate, which is particularly important for patients undergoing cardiac surgery.
  • Note: It is a short-acting intravenous anesthetic agent, though it has a potential side effect of causing adrenal insufficiency due to adrenal cortex suppression.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Propofol:

 

  • Use: Propofol is widely used for its rapid onset and offset, providing smooth induction and maintenance of anesthesia.
  • Drawback: It can cause significant hypotension, particularly in patients with compromised cardiac function or those who are hypovolemic. This property makes it less desirable for cardiac surgeries where hemodynamic stability is crucial.

 

Option B. Ketamine:

 

  • Use: Ketamine provides analgesia, amnesia, and can produce a dissociative state. It is known to increase heart rate, blood pressure, and cardiac output.
  • Drawback: The hemodynamic effects of ketamine might not always be favorable in cardiac surgeries, especially in patients with ischemic heart disease.

 

Option D. Sevoflurane:

 

  • Sevoflurane is actually an inhalational anesthetic, not intravenous. It has a rapid onset and offset, producing smooth induction and recovery. Sevoflurane can cause dose-dependent decreases in blood pressure but is commonly used in cardiac surgeries for its cardioprotective properties. However, it does not apply to this context as the question specifies an intravenous anesthetic agent.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Etomidate is the preferred intravenous anesthetic agent for cardiac surgeries due to its minimal impact on hemodynamics, maintaining stable blood pressure and heart rate. Propofol and Ketamine have significant effects on hemodynamics, making them less ideal for cardiac surgeries. Sevoflurane, while useful in cardiac surgeries, is an inhalational agent, not intravenous.

 

Ref: Miller’s Anesthesia, 9th Ed. Pg 668

questions.text: At which vertebral level does the spinal cord typically terminate in infants? (FMGE DECEMBER 2021)
questions.solution:
Ans. C. L3

 

Explanation

 

The spinal cord in infants usually ends at the L3 vertebral level. This information is important especially during procedures such as lumbar punctures (spinal taps), where the needle is inserted below the level of the spinal cord to obtain cerebrospinal fluid.

 

As an individual grows, the vertebral column lengthens, and the spinal cord appears to "ascend" within the vertebral canal, which is why, in adults, the spinal cord typically ends around the L1-L2 vertebral level.

 

 

Other options:

 

Option A) L1: The L1 vertebra is located slightly above the level where the spinal cord typically ends in infants. In most adults, the spinal cord typically extends only to the level of the first or second lumbar vertebra (L1-L2).

 

Option B) L2: Similar to the L1 vertebra, the L2 vertebra is also located above the typical level where the spinal cord ends in infants.

 

Option D) L4: The L4 vertebra is located below the typical level where the spinal cord ends in infants.

 

Educational Objective

 

  • In infants, the termination of the spinal cord is at L3 following which the cord moves up with age.
  • In adults, the termination of the spinal cord is at L1 (Gray’s anatomy update 41st& 42nd edition)

questions.text: Three Testicle appearance’ is seen in? (FMGE DECEMEBR 2021)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Spermatocele

 

The 'Three Testicle appearance' refers to the presence of a third mass in addition to the normal testicles, often seen in cases of spermatocele.

 

  • Spermatocele:
    • Description: A unilocular retention cyst located in the head of the epididymis behind the upper pole of the testis.
    • Contents: Contains spermatozoa and typically has a 'barley water' appearance.
    • Appearance: Creates an additional palpable mass in the scrotum, which can be interpreted as a 'third testicle.'
    • Treatment: Management involves either aspiration or surgical excision if the cyst is large or symptomatic.

 

Other Options:

 

  • Option A. Vaginal hydrocele:
    • This is an accumulation of serous fluid between the layers of the tunica vaginalis surrounding the testicle. It does not create a distinct 'third testicle' mass but rather causes a generalized swelling of the scrotum.
  • Option C. Epididymo-orchitis:
    • This is an inflammation of the epididymis and/or the testicle, usually due to infection. It typically presents with pain, swelling, and tenderness, rather than a distinct third mass.
  • Option D. Torsion Testis:
    • Testicular torsion involves the twisting of the spermatic cord, cutting off blood supply to the testis. This is a surgical emergency presenting with sudden, severe pain and swelling of the testis, but not with an additional palpable mass.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The 'Three Testicle appearance' is characteristic of a spermatocele, which is a retention cyst located in the head of the epididymis, creating an additional palpable mass in the scrotum.

questions.text: A 45-year-old chronic alcoholic is brought to the hospital due to fever and abdominal pain. He was diagnosed to have a cirrhotic liver 2 years back. The ascitic fluid shows a neutrophil count of 360 cells/microliter. Which of the following is the drug of choice in this patient? (FMGE DEC 2021)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Cefotaxime

 

The patient likely has spontaneous bacterial peritonitis (SBP), a common and serious complication of cirrhosis, characterized by an infection of the ascitic fluid. A neutrophil count of 360 cells/microliter in ascitic fluid confirms SBP.

 

Cefotaxime or ceftriaxone, a third-generation cephalosporin, is the drug of choice because it is effective against most of the bacteria that cause SBP. However, the ICMR guidelines recommend using Peptazo (piperacillin-tazobactam) in India due to high levels of resistance to third-generation cephalosporins.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Metronidazole: Effective for anaerobic infections but not the first choice for SBP.

 

Option C. Amoxicillin: Not as effective as cefotaxime for the organisms commonly causing SBP.

 

Option D. Vancomycin: Used for Gram-positive infections but not typically for SBP.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Cefotaxime is the preferred treatment for spontaneous bacterial peritonitis in cirrhotic patients.

questions.text: A patient is taking chemotherapy for treatment of lung cancer. Which of the following drug should be used to prevent the nausea and vomiting in this patient? (FMGE DECEMBER 2021)
questions.solution:
Ans. C. Palonosetron

 

Palonosetron is a highly effective 5HT3 receptor antagonist used specifically to prevent chemotherapy-induced nausea and vomiting (CINV). It is particularly potent and has a longer half-life compared to other agents in this class, such as Ondansetron and Granisetron, making it suitable for both acute and delayed CINV. Palonosetron provides improved control of nausea and vomiting by blocking serotonin receptors in the brain and gut that are triggered by chemotherapy.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Domperidone: While Domperidone is an antiemetic, it primarily acts as a dopamine antagonist with prokinetic properties, which make it more useful for gastrointestinal motility disorders. It is less effective than 5HT3 antagonists in controlling CINV.

 

Option B. Promethazine: This drug belongs to the phenothiazine class of antiemetics and is used for general nausea and vomiting. However, its sedative effects and lower efficacy in controlling severe CINV compared to 5HT3 antagonists limit its use in this context.

 

Option D. Metoclopramide: Also a dopamine antagonist with prokinetic effects, Metoclopramide is used to prevent nausea and vomiting, including that induced by chemotherapy. However, it is generally considered less effective for severe cases of CINV compared to 5HT3 receptor antagonists and is associated with a risk of extrapyramidal side effects.

 

Additional Information:

 

  • For comprehensive management of CINV, combinations of antiemetics, including a 5HT3 receptor antagonist like Palonosetron, a corticosteroid like Dexamethasone, and a neurokinin-1 receptor antagonist like Aprepitant, are often recommended. This multi-drug approach targets different pathways involved in the nausea and vomiting reflex, providing more effective relief.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Palonosetron is the preferred choice among the options listed for preventing nausea and vomiting in a patient undergoing chemotherapy for lung cancer. Its efficacy in controlling both acute and delayed phases of CINV makes it a critical component of supportive care in cancer therapy.

choices.text: Perforation of the intestine

questions.text: A patient was brought to the emergency with hypotension, raised JVP, muffled heart sounds, engorged neck veins. He died in the hospital and an autopsy was done which showed the following image. The most likely cause of death in this patient would be? (FMGE DECEMEBR 2021)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Cardiac tamponade

 

The explanation given above is of Beck’s Triad:

 

  • Muffled heart sounds
  • Distended neck veins
  • Hypotension

 

X ray finding - enlarged cardiac shadow

 

Investigation of choice: 2D ECHO → for diagnosis

 

Rx: Emergency Rx → needle pericardiocentesis

 

Treatment of choice → surgical pericardiotomy.

 

Other options:

 

Option A. Heart rupture:

 

  • Heart rupture is a tear in the wall of the heart muscle. It's typically associated with a recent myocardial infarction (heart attack).
  • While heart rupture can lead to blood filling the pericardial space and subsequently causing cardiac tamponade, the presented triad of symptoms (Beck’s Triad) is more suggestive of an acute cardiac tamponade, which is the immediate cause of the symptoms rather than the heart rupture itself.

 

Option C. Perforation of the intestine:

 

  • Perforation of the intestine leads to the release of the contents of the intestine into the peritoneal cavity, leading to peritonitis.
  • Common symptoms include severe abdominal pain, fever, and abdominal distension.

 

Option D. Pneumonia:

 

  • Pneumonia is an inflammatory condition of the lung affecting primarily the alveoli, which might be filled with fluid or pus.
  • Symptoms usually include productive cough, chest pain, fever, and difficulty breathing.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Cardiac tamponade is characterized by Beck's Triad: hypotension, raised JVP, and muffled heart sounds. Immediate treatment includes needle pericardiocentesis.

questions.text: Which of the following is a contraindication for breastfeeding? (FMGE DECEMBER 2021)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Galactosemic child

 

Breastfeeding is contraindicated in infants with galactosemia, as it can lead to the accumulation of galactose in the body, causing serious health issues.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. HIV mother: While breastfeeding is generally recommended for HIV-negative mothers, it is not strictly contraindicated in mothers with HIV.

 

Option B. Mother on radiotherapy: Radioactive substances used in radiotherapy can be harmful to the infant, But are not absolute contraindicated for breastfeeding infants.

 

Option D. CMV infection: Cytomegalovirus (CMV) infection is not an absolute contraindication for breastfeeding. In some cases, the benefits of breastfeeding may outweigh the potential risks associated with CMV transmission.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Galactosemia is a rare genetic disorder in which the body is unable to metabolize galactose, a component of lactose found in breast milk and formula. The breastfeeding is strictly C/I in galactosemic child to prevent severe mental retardation in child.

questions.text: Identify the rhythm in the following ECG: (FMGE DEC 2021)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Normal Sinus Rhythm

 

Normal sinus rhythm is characterized by the following ECG features:

 

  1. Regular rhythm with a consistent P wave before each QRS complex.
  2. P waves are upright in leads I, II, and aVF.
  3. A rate between 60-100 beats per minute.
  4. PR interval is normal (0.12-0.20 seconds).
  5. QRS complex duration is within the normal range (less than 0.12 seconds).

 

These features indicate the electrical activity is originating from the sinoatrial (SA) node and is conducted normally through the atria, atrioventricular (AV) node, and ventricles.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A.  Atrial Fibrillation: This would present with an irregularly irregular rhythm and absent P waves. The baseline would appear wavy due to the fibrillatory waves.

 

Option B. Atrial Flutter: Characterized by a sawtooth pattern of flutter waves, usually at a rate of around 250-350 beats per minute.

 

Option D. AV Block: This would show prolonged PR intervals or dropped QRS complexes depending on the degree of block. In complete heart block (third-degree), there is no relationship between P waves and QRS complexes.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Normal sinus rhythm is indicated by regular rhythm, normal P waves, and consistent PR interval, confirming proper electrical conduction from the SA node through the heart.

questions.text:
A patient presents with symptoms below, the site of lesion as shown in the image. (FMGE DECEMBER 2021)

 

 

 

  1. Shows the site of the lesion
  2. Has loss of proprioception, vibration, and discriminative touch on the same side
  3. Has loss of pain and temperature on the contralateral side.

 

What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Ans. C. Brown Squared syndrome

 

  • Brown-Séquard syndrome is a neurological condition resulting from the hemisection or lateral half-cut of the spinal cord. This type of injury disrupts several pathways in the spinal cord:
    • Ipsilateral deficits (same side as the lesion): There is a loss of proprioception, vibration sense, and discriminative touch due to the damage to the dorsal columns (fasciculus gracilis and cuneatus).
    • Contralateral deficits (opposite side of the lesion): Loss of pain and temperature sensations occurs due to the damage to the spinothalamic tract, which crosses over to the opposite side shortly after entering the spinal cord.
    • Motor deficits: The corticospinal tract, which is primarily involved in voluntary motor control, is also affected on the same side as the lesion, leading to weakness or paralysis.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Weber's syndrome: Incorrect because it involves a brainstem lesion affecting the oculomotor nerve and the cerebral peduncle, leading to symptoms like ptosis, ophthalmoplegia, and contralateral hemiparesis, which are not described here.

 

Option B. Dejerine syndrome: Incorrect as it generally refers to a type of thalamic stroke syndrome or a combination of brainstem symptoms not related to hemisection of the spinal cord.

 

Option D. Wallenberg syndrome: Incorrect because it is also known as lateral medullary syndrome and affects structures in the brainstem, presenting with symptoms like vertigo, dysphagia, hoarseness, and ipsilateral loss of facial pain and temperature sensation, which differ from those described.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Brown-Séquard syndrome is characterized by a unique pattern of neurological deficits resulting from hemisection of the spinal cord, leading to ipsilateral proprioceptive and motor deficits and contralateral pain and temperature loss.

questions.text: In a rural community healthcare initiative, a specific type of health worker plays a crucial role. These workers are usually women from the village they serve, aged 25 to 45, known for their effective communication skills, and are tasked with bridging the gap between the community and healthcare services. What is the official title given to these health workers? (FMGE DEC 2021)
questions.solution:
Ans. B. Accredited social health worker

 

ASHA is expected to act as

 

  • Interface between: Community and Health care system
  • Bridge between: ANM and village
  • Accountable to: Panchayat

 

Selection criteria of ASHA:

 

  • Woman resident of local community
  • Preferably 25 – 45 years age
  • Literate with formal education up to 10th class (Relaxable for Tribal areas)

 

Proposed population norm: 2 ASHA worker per 1000 population

 

Responsibilities of ASHA:

 

  • Create awareness on health and its social determinants and mobilize the community towards local health planning and increased utilization and accountability of the existing health services
  • Promote good health practices and provide a minimum package of curative care as appropriate and feasible and make timely referrals
  • Provide information on determinants of health, on existing health services and the need for timely utilization of services
  • Counsel women on aspects of reproductive and child health
  • Mobilize the community and facilitate them in accessing health and health related services provided by the government
  • Act as a depot holder for essential provisions like ORS, IFA tablets, chloroquine, disposable delivery kits, oral pills & condoms
  • Provide primary medical care and act as DOTS provider
  • Help develop a comprehensive village health plan
  • Arrange escort/accompany pregnant women and children requiring treatment/ admission to nearest health facility
  • Be a part of JSY (Janani Suraksha Yojana) and help reduce MMR

 

Additional Information

 

Indicators for Monitoring and Evaluation of ASHA’s Work

 

• Process indicators:

  • No. of ASHAs selected
  • No. of ASHAs trained
  • % ASHAs attending review meeting after 1 year

• Outcome indicators:

  • % newborns weighed and families counselled
  • % deliveries with skilled assistance
  • % institutional deliveries
  • % JSY claims made to ASHA
  • Completed immunized 12-23 months age group
  • % unmet need in BPL
  • % fever cases received chloroquine within 1 weeks in endemic area

• Impact indicators:

  • Infant mortality rate (IMR)
  • Child malnutrition rates
  • No. of cases of TB/Leprosy detected as compared to last year.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Multipurpose Worker: They usually have broader roles that might encompass multiple health domains, such as health and sanitation. They are usually males.

 

Option C. Anganwadi Worker: Their primary role is associated with the Integrated Child Development Services (ICDS) program, focusing on the nutritional and educational needs of children in the village.

 

Option D. Dai/Trained Birth Assistant: These are often local women who have been trained to assist in childbirth but primarily operate in maternal health settings.

 

Educational Objective:

 

ASHAs are crucial in rural health systems for their role in primary healthcare outreach, education, and community engagement, making healthcare more accessible and effective at the grassroots level.

questions.text: Safety pin appearance is seen in: (FMGE DECEMBER 2021)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Burkholderia pseudomallei

 

Safety pin appearance is seen in Burkholderia pseudomallei.

 

  • It is a Gram-negative bacterium that causes melioidosis.
  • Culture-based methods, including selective agar media, are used to grow and identify Burkholderia pseudomallei.
  • Molecular techniques, such as polymerase chain reaction (PCR), can be used for more rapid and specific detection.

 

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Hemophilus influenza: This is a Gram-negative coccobacillus that does not exhibit a safety pin appearance. It causes respiratory infections and invasive diseases such as meningitis and epiglottitis.

 

Option C. Pseudomonas aeruginosa: This is a Gram-negative rod that does not show a safety pin appearance. It is known for its blue-green pigment and fruity odor, and it causes infections in immunocompromised patients and those with cystic fibrosis.

 

Option D. Burkholderia cepacia: This is a Gram-negative bacillus related to Burkholderia pseudomallei but does not typically show a safety pin appearance. It causes respiratory infections, particularly in individuals with cystic fibrosis.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The safety pin appearance on Gram stain is a distinctive feature of Burkholderia pseudomallei, the causative agent of melioidosis. Recognizing this staining pattern can aid in the rapid identification and diagnosis of this potentially serious infection.

questions.text: A 50-year-old male laborer, recently enrolled in the Employee State Insurance (ESI) scheme, visits a clinic with a chronic cough. He consults a registered medical practitioner under the ESI scheme and inquires about the benefits he can receive. What type of service is the practitioner most likely able to provide to this beneficiary?(FMGE DEC 2021)
questions.solution:
Ans. B. Indirect medical benefit

 

Under the Employee State Insurance (ESI) scheme, various benefits are provided to eligible workers. These benefits include direct medical services through ESI hospitals and dispensaries and indirect medical benefits through private medical practitioners (insurance medical practitioners) in rural areas.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Direct medical benefit: This includes services provided by ESI hospitals and dispensaries. The question specifies a private practitioner, which refers to indirect benefits.

 

Option C. Sickness benefit: This refers to a cash benefit provided under the ESI scheme when an insured person is unable to work due to sickness, paid at a rate of 70% of wages for up to 91 days. This benefit is not provided directly by the doctor.

 

Option D. Extended sickness benefit: Provides enhanced wage benefits for prolonged illnesses, again a monetary benefit rather than medical service directly provided by a doctor.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Employees State Insurance (ESI)

 

It comes under the Ministry of Labour. It is not applicable for Defence Mining and Railway.

 

People with a monthly wage of less than Rs.21000/month are eligible to get the benefits.

 

The benefits include the following:

 

  • Direct medical benefit in the form of ESI hospitals and dispensaries.
  • Sickness benefit (70% wages for 91 days or 3 months)
    • If Extended, it becomes (80% of wages for 2 years)
    • Enhanced sickness benefit (100% of the wages for sterilization procedures – 7 days for males and 14 days for females)
  • Disablement benefit is 90% wages depending on temporary or permanent disability
  • Dependent’s benefit is also 90%
    • Indirect Medical Benefit by private medical practitioners through panel system in the rural areas (Insurance medical practitioners).
    • Under ESI Funeral expense 15,000 is also given

questions.text: A 25-year-old patient has developed tuberculosis in which mycobacterium is resistant to rifampicin, isoniazid, bedaquiline, and levofloxacin. This tuberculosis is referred to as? (FMGE DECEMBER 2021)
questions.solution:
Ans. C. Extensively drug resistant TB

 

Extensively Drug-Resistant TB (XDR TB) is defined as tuberculosis that is resistant to the most effective first-line treatments, rifampicin and isoniazid (which defines MDR TB), plus any of the fluoroquinolones, and at least one of three injectable second-line drugs (amikacin, kanamycin, or capreomycin) or newer drugs like bedaquiline and linezolid. In this patient's case, the resistance to both rifampicin and isoniazid along with levofloxacin (a fluoroquinolone) and bedaquiline qualifies the infection as XDR TB.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Terminologies used for tuberculosis are as follows:

questions.text: A newborn presented to the NICU with respiratory distress and meconium discharge from the umbilicus. The condition occurs due to the patency of which of the following structures?(FMGE DECEMBER 2021)
questions.solution:
Ans. D. Vitello intestinal duct

 

Explanation:

 

  • The presence of meconium discharge at the umbilicus is suggestive of vitelline fistula, which occurs due to patent vitelline duct, which connects the primitive gut to the yolk sac.

 

 

The condition described, where a newborn presents with respiratory distress and meconium discharge from the umbilicus, is known as Meconium Peritonitis. Meconium is the earliest stool of a newborn, and its presence outside of the digestive tract is abnormal and can indicate a problem in the fetal development of the gastrointestinal (GI) tract.The condition occurs due to the patency (failure to close) of the Vitellointestinal (Vitelline) Duct.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Mesonephric Duct (Wolffian Duct): The mesonephric duct is part of the early urinary and reproductive systems in the developing embryo. It plays a role in the formation of the male reproductive system but is not associated with meconium discharge from the umbilicus.

 

Option B. Allantois: The allantois is a fetal structure that plays a role in the formation of the urinary bladder. It normally obliterates and becomes a ligament without causing meconium discharge from the umbilicus.

 

Option C. Urachus: The urachus is a remnant of a canal that connects the bladder to the umbilicus during fetal development. Normally, the urachus obliterates before birth, forming a fibrous cord known as the median umbilical ligament. Failure of the urachus to close can lead to a condition called urachal anomalies, but it does not typically result in meconium discharge from the umbilicus.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Vitellointestinal (Vitelline) Duct is a narrow tube that connects the developing embryo's midgut to the yolk sac. Normally, it obliterates during fetal development. When it fails to close properly, it can lead to the persistence of a tubular structure known as a Meckel's diverticulum. This diverticulum may contain gastric or intestinal mucosa and can be a source of complications, including meconium discharge from the umbilicus.

questions.text: A patient was brought to the emergency following a car accident. His Blood Pressure is 90/60 mm of Hg, His Glasgow coma scale is 9. He has suffered injuries to the abdominal viscera. The least likely cause of hypovolemia in this patient is? (FMGE DECEMEBR 2021)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Subdural hematoma

 

Subdural Hematoma (SDH) involves bleeding between the dura mater and the arachnoid mater, typically from venous sources such as the bridging veins. While SDH is a significant and serious condition, it generally does not lead to hypovolemia because the bleeding is contained within the intracranial space and does not result in large-volume blood loss.

 

  • Source: Bridging veins
  • Cause: Trauma (acceleration, deceleration force)
  • Radiological Findings: Concavo-convex hyperdensity on NCCT Head
  • Patient Profile: Usually seen in elderly or obese individuals after a fall

 

 

Other options:

 

  • Option A. Splenic Injury:
    • The spleen is one of the most commonly injured organs in blunt abdominal trauma. Injury or rupture of the spleen can result in significant internal bleeding and hypovolemia.
    • Features: Can cause substantial internal bleeding leading to hypovolemia.
  • Option C. Retroperitoneal Hematoma:
    • The retroperitoneal space contains several large blood vessels, including the aorta and inferior vena cava. Injuries to these vessels or other structures in this space can result in large-volume blood loss into the retroperitoneal space, leading to hypovolemia.
    • Features: Significant blood loss into retroperitoneal space, causing hypovolemia.
  • Option D. Hemothorax:
    • Hemothorax is the collection of blood in the pleural cavity, which can occur due to traumatic injuries. Traumatic hemothorax can result in significant blood loss, leading to hypovolemia.
    • Features: Blood accumulation in pleural cavity, causing hypovolemia.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Subdural hematoma, characterized by bleeding between the dura mater and the arachnoid mater, is least likely to cause hypovolemia compared to splenic injury, retroperitoneal hematoma, or hemothorax

questions.text: A 14-year-old girl presented with cyclical abdominal pain and a midline hypogastric lump. She has not achieved menarche yet. The per vaginal examination is shown below and a bluish swelling is seen along with it. What is the likely cause of her condition? (FMGE DEC 2021)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Imperforate hymen

 

Explanation:

 

  • Primary amenorrhea with cyclical pain is suggestive of an obstructive cause.
  • O/e a bulge seen protruding from the vagina is suggestive of an imperforate hymen.
  • This classically presents as a bluish bulge distending the hymen in girls with primary amenorrhea
  • The bulge (hamatocolpos) is felt along the entire length of the vagina on doing a PR examination
  • Treatment: Cruciate incision and drainage of hamatocolpos is done. 

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Bartholin cyst: There is a blockage of the Bartholin’s duct resulting in accumulation of secretions, presents as a unilateral swelling over the posterior part of labia majora extending into minora. It is treated by marsupialization.

 

Option B. Transverse vaginal septum: It occurs due to defective fusion and canalization of the mullerian duct and urogenital sinus. It may vary in thickness and location. Treatment is excision. Presenting symptoms may be similar to imperforate hymen.

 

Option D. Endometrioma: Ovarian endometriosis results in the formation of ovarian endometriotic cysts referred to as endometrioma Or chocolate cysts. Treatment is surgical excision.

 

Educational Objective:

 

An imperforate hymen in a girl with primary amenorrhea and cyclical abdominal pain presents as a bluish bulge distending the hymen, treated with a cruciate incision.

 

Ref: Dutta’s textbook of Gynecology 6th edition pg 450,

questions.text: A 30-year-old man presented with excessive fatigability towards the end of the day that improved with rest. He also gives a history of ptosis, difficulty in speech, and swallowing. What is the most likely diagnosis? (FMGE DEC 2021)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Myasthenia gravis

 

Myasthenia gravis is characterized by fatigability that worsens with activity and improves with rest. The symptoms of ptosis, difficulty in speech, and swallowing are also indicative of myasthenia gravis, a disorder caused by autoimmune destruction of acetylcholine receptors at the neuromuscular junction, leading to muscle weakness.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Lambert-Eaton syndrome: Typically improves with activity and is associated with small cell lung cancer.

 

Option C. Duchenne muscular dystrophy: Presents with progressive muscle weakness from childhood, not with fluctuating symptoms.

 

Option D. Systemic lupus erythematosus: Can cause various neurological symptoms but not typically fluctuating muscle weakness.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Myasthenia gravis presents with fluctuating muscle weakness that improves with rest, and symptoms like ptosis, and difficulty in speech and swallowing.

questions.text: Marsupialization is an ideal treatment of choice for condition X involving the female reproductive tract, the lesion responsible for condition X is located at? (FMGE DEC 2021)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Bartholin gland

 

Explanation:

 

  • Marsupialization is the best course of treatment for a Bartholin cyst or abscess. The clinical vignette suggests a Bartholin gland lesion.
  • The Bartholin glands are situated in the superficial perineal pouch and can develop cysts or abscesses due to blockage of their ducts.
  • Marsupialization involves incising the abscess, draining it, and suturing the walls of the cyst to the surrounding vaginal mucosa to prevent recurrence.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Perineal body: The perineal body, or obstetric perineum, is a pyramidal-shaped tissue where the muscles of the pelvic floor and perineal muscles and fascia meet, situated between the vagina and the anal opening.

 

Option C. Vagina: The vagina rarely has cysts as its mucosa is devoid of glands. However, vaginal cysts may present as Gartner’s duct cysts or epidermal inclusion cysts.

 

Option D. Cervix: The cervix has cysts in the form of nabothian follicles, which do not require treatment.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Marsupialization is an ideal treatment for a Bartholin gland cyst or abscess.

 

Ref: Dutta’s textbook of Gynecology 6th edition p 162

questions.text: A vegetarian patient presents with anemia & hypersegmented neutrophil. The most probable diagnosis is: (FMGE DECEMBER 2021)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Megaloblastic anemia

 

This is the most probable diagnosis. Megaloblastic anemia is primarily caused by a deficiency in vitamin B12 or folate, which are essential for DNA synthesis in the rapidly dividing cells, like those in the bone marrow. A vegetarian diet, especially if not properly balanced, can lead to vitamin B12 deficiency, as this vitamin is mostly found in animal products. Hypersegmented neutrophils(> 6 lobules)  are a hallmark feature of megaloblastic anemia, along with large, immature red blood cells (megaloblasts).

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Anemia of Chronic Disease: This type of anemia is usually associated with chronic infections, inflammatory diseases, or malignancies. It is characterized by the body's inability to utilize stored iron effectively. While it's common, it doesn't typically present with hypersegmented neutrophils, which are more indicative of a problem with DNA synthesis in blood cells.

 

Option B. Iron Deficiency Anemia: Common in vegetarians due to a diet lacking in heme iron (found in meat), iron deficiency anemia is characterized by microcytic and hypochromic red blood cells (smaller and paler than normal). However, hypersegmented neutrophils are not a feature of this type of anemia.

 

Option D. Sideroblastic Anemia: This type of anemia is characterized by the presence of ring sideroblasts in the bone marrow and is often related to defective heme synthesis. It doesn't typically present with hypersegmented neutrophils and is less likely in this clinical scenario.

 

Educational Objective:

 

In vegetarian individuals, vitamin B12 deficiency is more common as vitamin B12 is primarily found in animal products. Megaloblastic anemia is characterized by the presence of large, immature red blood cells (megaloblasts) in the bone marrow. This is because B12 is required for nucleic acid synthesis so, in B12 deficiency, the nucleus is not able to divide and but cell will keep growing in size causing formation of megaloblasts.

 

Ref: Harper’s Illustrated Biochemistry 32nd edition Page no. 657

questions.text: A 35-year-old woman presents to you with complaints of difficulty in hearing in the right ear which is slowly progressive. She also has tinnitus which is pulsatile in nature. On examination, a reddish mass was seen behind the tympanic membrane and an audible bruit is heard over the mastoid when auscultation with a stethoscope. Her Rinne test was negative. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis? (FMGE DEC 2021)
questions.solution:
Ans. D. Glomus tumor

 

The given clinical picture suggests a diagnosis of a 'glomus tumor'

 

Glomus tumor

 

It is the most common benign neoplasm of middle ear and is so-named because of its origin from the glomus bodies.

 

The tumour consists of paraganglionic cells derived from the neural crest.

 

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. CSOM patients on examination shows presence of granulations, in-growth of squamous epithelium from the edges of perforation, tympanosclerosis and adhesions.

 

Option B. Acute suppurative otitis media is an acute inflammation of middle ear by pyogenic organisms. Tympanic membrane is retracted with handle of malleus assuming a more horizontal position, prominence of lateral process of malleus and loss of light reflex. A cart-wheel appearance can be appreciated in later stages.

 

 

Option C. Mastoiditis leads to features like pain behind ear, fever, ear discharge. Mastoid surface looks smooth and shiny, so often called as ‘ironed out mastoid’. On otoscopy, light house sign & sagging of posterior meatal wall seen.

 

 

Educational Objective:

 

The presence of a reddish, pulsating mass behind the tympanic membrane, along with conductive hearing loss and pulsatile tinnitus in a middle-aged female, is highly indicative of a glomus tumor, particularly glomus tympanicum. Prompt referral for appropriate imaging and specialist evaluation is essential for accurate diagnosis and management.

 

Reference – Dhingra 7th edition, Page No. 121,122

questions.text: A 6-year-old boy fell from the bed and developed swelling in the nose and difficulty in breathing. Examination revealed smooth rounded swellings on either side of the septum, through both the nares. On palpation, it was soft and fluctuant. What is the next best step in the management of this patient? (FMGE DEC 2021)
questions.solution:
Ans. B. Incision and drainage

 

The presence of a history of trauma, coupled with bilateral septal swelling, indicates a possible septal hematoma. This condition is typically treated by performing incision and drainage of the hematoma.

 

Incision and Drainage: This is the most appropriate initial management step for a septal hematoma because it promptly relieves the pressure from the accumulated blood, preventing further complications like cartilage destruction or infection.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Systemic Antibiotics: While important, antibiotics alone would not address the immediate problem of the hematoma; they are typically used post-drainage to prevent secondary infection.

 

Option C. High-resolution Computerized Tomography (CT): While helpful for assessing complex facial fractures, a CT scan is not necessary in this straightforward case of suspected septal hematoma without evidence of further complications or other injuries.

 

Option D. Submucosal Resection: This surgical procedure is used for correcting nasal septum deviations but is not appropriate for treating a septal hematoma.

 

Educational Objective:
 

 

Reference - Dhingra 7th edition, Page No. 168

questions.text: The subcellular organelle which is associated with killing viruses & bacteria is: (FMGE DECEMBER 2021)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Lysosome

 

Lysosomes are subcellular organelles that contain enzymes acid hydrolases capable of digesting and breaking down cellular debris, pathogens, and other foreign materials. They play a crucial role in the immune response by serving as the cellular "garbage disposal" system, engulfing and degrading viruses, bacteria, and other particles.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Peroxisome: Peroxisomes are involved in various metabolic functions, including lipid metabolism (alpha-oxidation and oxidation of VLCFA) and detoxification. They have catalase to destroy free radicals formed from these pathways.

 

Option B. Mitochondria: Mitochondria are responsible for energy production in the form of ATP through cellular respiration. While they play a critical role in cellular function, they are not specifically associated with killing viruses and bacteria.

 

Option D. Golgi apparatus: The Golgi apparatus is involved in processing and packaging cellular proteins,

 

Educational Objective:

 

Lysosomes are membrane-bound organelles that contain enzymes capable of breaking down all types of biological polymers – proteins, nucleic acids, carbohydrates, and lipids. They are key to the intracellular degradation process. When a cell engulfs a virus or bacterium (through phagocytosis), the resulting phagosome fuses with a lysosome, where the engulfed material is degraded and rendered harmless.

 

Ref: Harper’s Illustrated Biochemistry 32nd edition Page no. 482

questions.text: Which of the following features are NOT associated with the condition shown in the image below? (FMGE DEC 2021)
questions.solution:
Ans. C. Munro micro abscesses

 

The patient's age and the presence of purple, polygonal flat-topped papules, and plaques on the flexural aspect of wrist as shown in the image points to the diagnosis of lichen planus.

 

Munro micro abscesses (Collection of Neutrophils in stratum corneum) are not a feature of Lichen Planus but they are seen in Psoriasis.

 

Other 3 Options often seen in Lichen Planus and Wickham's Striae is a characteristic feature of Lichen Planus, appearing as white lacy patterns, primarily on mucosal surfaces.

 

Additional Information:

 

Lichen planus:

 

  • Lichen planus (LP) is an idiopathic inflammatory disease affecting the skin and mucous membrane.
  • The five characteristics of lichen planus lesions are 5Ps: purple polygonal, pruritic, plane topped (flat), and papules.
  • Lichen planus has characteristics including cicatrizing alopecia, flat-topped purple polygonal papules, and plaques on the flexural aspect of the wrist, Wickham's striae on the lips, longitudinal ridging, and thinning of nails.
  • Wickham's striae are distinctive white streaks that create a lacework in the buccal mucosa.

 

 

 

 

 

  • Lichen planus is characterized by the degeneration or destruction of basal epidermal cells. This degeneration leads to the formation of spaces in the epidermis known as Max Joseph spaces.
  • It happens as a result of dermal CD8 + T lymphocytes destroying basal keratinocytes. Colloid bodies, also known as cytoid or Civatte bodies, are degenerating basal epidermal cells that can appear singly or in clusters.

 

Other histopathological characteristics of lichen planus include:

 

Hyperkeratosis, Hypergranulosis Pigment incontinence (melanin slowly migrates into the dermis as a result of keratinocyte degeneration), engulfment of dermal melanin by macrophages to form Melanophages (melanin-containing macrophages) and The development of Max Joseph spaces in the epidermis. There is a band-like lymphocytic infiltrate at the dermoepidermal junction; the rete ridges have a saw-toothed appearance because they are pointed at their lower ends.

 

The image below shows the HPE of Lichen planus with arrows pointing out Saw toothed appearance of Rete ridges:

 

 

Educational Objective:

 

Munro microabscesses are specific to Psoriasis and do not occur in Lichen Planus, which instead presents with a unique combination of Wickham's striae, hyperkeratosis, and a distinctive histological appearance with saw-toothed rete ridges and band-like infiltrates.

 

Reference: Rooks textbook of dermatology- 9th Edition page no 32.36, 32.38, 34.42, 35.7, 35.8, 37.3, 37.12, 37.14, 37.14

choices.text: Order a thyroid radionuclide uptake and scan

questions.text: A 40-year-old female patient presents with cold intolerance, dry skin, constipation, and on examination slow ankle jerk with a TSH level of 15 IU/L and low T3, and T4. Of the following, the next best step in the management is: (FMGE DEC 2021)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Begin treatment with levothyroxine (LT4)

 

The patient exhibits classic signs and symptoms of hypothyroidism: cold intolerance, dry skin, constipation, and slow reflexes. The elevated TSH level (15 IU/L) and low levels of T3 and T4 confirm the diagnosis. The standard treatment for hypothyroidism is thyroid hormone replacement with levothyroxine, which will help normalize thyroid hormone levels and alleviate symptoms.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Measure Thyroxine binding globulin (TBG): This is not necessary for the diagnosis or initial management of primary hypothyroidism.

 

Option C. Order a thyroid radionuclide uptake and scan: This is generally used for evaluating hyperthyroidism or thyroid nodules, not primary hypothyroidism.

 

Option D. Order thyroid ultrasonography: Useful if a thyroid nodule or goiter is suspected, but not needed for straightforward hypothyroidism without any palpable thyroid abnormalities.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Levothyroxine replacement therapy is the appropriate treatment for hypothyroidism confirmed by elevated TSH and low T3 and T4 levels.

choices.text: Multiple Renal Cysts in the fetus

questions.text: A 24-year-old primi with a history of 3 months of amenorrhea undergoes USG. The USG done is suggestive of? (FMGE DEC 2021)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Hydatidiform mole

 

  • The USG shown a snowstorm appearance seen in complete molar pregnancy

 

Complete Mole:

 

  • Completely Paternal Origin
  • The ova is empty/ inactivated
  • One sperm (23X) fertilizes the empty ova and undergoes androgenesis (duplication) to form the gamete which is DIPLOID (46 XX – MOST COMMON)

 

OR

 

  • 2 sperms (23X & 23 X or 23 X & 23Y) i.e., dispermy will fertilize the empty ova and form the gamete which is 46XX or 46XY

 

Partial Mole

 

  • TRIPLOID
  • Contains both paternal and maternal components
  • 2 sperms (either 23 X or 23 Y) fertilize an ovum (23X) and form a triploid gamete which could be either 69XXX or 69XXY
  • Management of Molar Pregnancy: Suction evacuation f/b beta HCG surveillance.

 

Other Options

 

Option A. Ectopic pregnancy:

 

  • It refers to an implantation outside the endometrial cavity.
  • Commonest type is tubal ectopic (ampulla)
  • Ultrasound in a tubal ectopic may show an adnexal mass, empty uterus and fluid may be present in POD. Colour Doppler shows characteristic ring of fire appearance on ultrasound.

 

Option C. Multiple Renal Cysts in the fetus: It is a congenital anomaly due to improper development of the fetal kidney. There may be associated oligohydramnios if both fetal kidneys are affected.

 

Option D. Oligohydramnios: Refers to reduced AFI < 5cm or single deepest pocket < 2cm.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The ultrasound appearance of a complete molar pregnancy typically shows a "snowstorm" pattern, which is characteristic of a hydatidiform mole.

 

Ref: Duttas textbook of obstetrics 8th edition pg 225

questions.text: Gamma radiation is used for sterilization of: (FMGE DECEMBER 2021)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Syringes, needles and catheters

 

Gamma radiation is used for the sterilization of articles such as syringes, needles, catheters, and gloves.

 

Gamma particles show maximum penetration and since there is no increase in temperature during the process it is called as cold sterilization.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Contaminated clothes and animal carcasses: While gamma radiation can theoretically be used for these purposes, it is not typically employed due to practicality and cost. Incineration or chemical disinfection are more common methods for dealing with contaminated clothes and animal carcasses.

 

Option C. Gloves and aprons: Though gamma radiation can sterilize gloves and aprons, it is less common compared to other methods like ethylene oxide gas or steam sterilization, which are more cost-effective for these items.

 

Option D. Bacterial vaccines and intravenous solutions: Gamma radiation is generally not used for sterilizing vaccines and intravenous solutions because it can degrade the active components and alter their effectiveness. These are typically sterilized using filtration or other methods that preserve their integrity.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Gamma radiation is an effective sterilization method for medical devices like syringes, needles, and catheters due to its deep penetration and ability to destroy pathogens without raising temperatures.

questions.text: A woman presented in her 8th week of pregnancy seeking MTP. The appropriate dosage of Misoprostol (administered by mucosal route) would be? (FMGE DEC 2021)
questions.solution:
Ans. D) 800 mcg

 

Explanation:

 

Medical MTP:

 

 

Success Rate:

 

  • 95 - 99% till 7 weeks
  • 90 - 95% 7 – 9 weeks

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • For medical termination of pregnancy in the 7-9 week period, the appropriate dosage of misoprostol administered by the mucosal route is 800 mcg.

 

Ref: Dutta’s textbook of obstetrics 8th edition pg 203

choices.text: Ileostomy and definitive surgery later
Ileal pouch-anal anastomosis
Resection of the diseased segment and anastomosis of the normal segment
Right hemicolectomy and ileo - transverse anastomosis

questions.text: A patient suffering from inflammatory bowel disease presented with ileal perforation and peritonitis. Intra-operatively, severe peritoneal contamination is found. What is the surgical management of choice in this patient? (FMGE DECEMEBR 2021)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Ileostomy and definite surgery later

 

This patient has Crohn’s disease, which can present with terminal ileitis and complications like perforation peritonitis. The appropriate surgical management depends on the extent of peritoneal contamination:

 

  • Severe Peritoneal Contamination: If there is severe peritoneal contamination due to the perforation, performing an ileostomy is the preferred approach. This diverts the fecal stream and allows the inflammation and infection to subside before a definitive surgery is performed later (typically after 4-6 weeks). This approach minimizes the risk of complications from primary anastomosis in a contaminated field.

 

Other Options:

 

  • Option B. Ileal pouch-anal anastomosis (IPAA):
    • This surgical procedure is more commonly used for patients with ulcerative colitis, not Crohn's disease. It's not appropriate in the context of an acute perforation and peritonitis due to Crohn’s disease.
  • Option C. Resection of the diseased segment and anastomosis of the normal segment:
    • While this might be an appropriate approach for isolated disease without complications, it's less commonly chosen in the setting of acute perforation with severe contamination. The risk is that the newly created anastomosis might not heal properly, leading to another leak and peritonitis.
  • Option D. Right hemicolectomy and ileo-transverse anastomosis:
    • This involves removing the right side of the colon and part of the small intestine. It's an extensive surgery and would be more applicable if there were a malignancy or a stricture in the right colon. In the setting of an acute perforation and contamination from Crohn's disease, this might be considered too aggressive, where a more limited resection and diversion should be done.

 

Educational Objective:

 

In patients with Crohn’s disease presenting with ileal perforation and severe peritoneal contamination, the preferred surgical management is to perform an ileostomy and plan for definitive surgery later, to minimize complications and allow for stabilization of the patient.

choices.text: Doctor should be punished under the law

questions.text: A 32-year-old patient was referred by physician to a radiologist go for a CT Brain. The radiologist later visits the physician offering him gifts and money for the referral. Which of the below statements are true regarding the above practice? (FMGE DECEMBER 2021)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) The doctor is practicing dichotomy

 

Dichotomy / Fee splitting: unethical act of fee splitting or taking commission for referring patients. It is punishable by the state medical council.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Association of Doctor: Not applicable to the scenario described.

 

Option B. Doctor should be punished under the law: While punishment is a possible outcome, the specific unethical practice described is dichotomy.

 

Option D. It is called Covering: The term "covering" generally refers to physicians covering for one another in terms of patient care and does not relate to the unethical practice described.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The practice of accepting gifts or money for patient referrals is known as dichotomy, an unethical act punishable by the state medical council.

choices.text: Barium meal follow-through

questions.text: Identify the investigation shown?(FMGE DECEMBER 2021)
questions.solution:
Ans. A. CT enterography

 

  • The given procedure is CT enterography where in the patient is given oral mannitol for bowel distension.
  • It is the IOC for small bowel tumors and strictures.
  • Enteroclysis is a study in which the barium or mannitol is put directly into the bowel through a tube reaching up to DJ flexure which allows a greater distension.

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Barium Enteroclysis This involves placing a tube into the small intestine to directly instill barium contrast, followed by fluoroscopy and X-rays. It's more invasive than enterography.

 

Option C. Barium Meal Follow-Through : This test also uses barium contrast, but it is ingested orally and the images are taken as the barium passes through the digestive tract over time, primarily using X-rays.

 

Option D. CT Enteroclysis : Similar to barium enteroclysis but uses CT imaging for greater detail after inserting contrast directly into the small intestine via a tube. This is more invasive than CT enterography.

 

Educational Objective :

 

CT enterography is particularly useful for identifying and evaluating small bowel pathologies, such as tumors, inflammation, and strictures, using a non-invasive method that provides comprehensive details of the bowel and surrounding tissues.

questions.text:
Mr. Sanjay Gupta 45-year-old male presented to OPD with acute onset of fever, weight loss, fatigue and pallor.

 

CBC shows: HB – 7gm/dl, TLC-13000/cumm, Platelet count- 1Lakh/cumm. On physical examination hepatosplenomegaly noted. Bone marrow examination shows M: E ratio is increased. What is the most likely diagnosis? (FMGE DEC 2021)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Acute Leukemia

 

Acute leukemia can present with pancytopenia (low red blood cells, white blood cells, and platelets) and splenomegaly. The increased M ratio (myeloid to erythroid ratio) in the bone marrow examination is also indicative of acute leukemia. Patients typically present with symptoms such as fever, weight loss, fatigue, and pallor.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Aplastic anemia: Aplastic anemia presents with pancytopenia but does not typically involve splenomegaly. It is characterized by hypocellular bone marrow with a decrease in all three cell lines (red blood cells, white blood cells, and platelets).

 

Option C. CML: Chronic Myeloid Leukemia (CML) presents with a high total leukocyte count (TLC) and has an insidious onset rather than an acute presentation. It also typically features the Philadelphia chromosome (t 9;22).

 

Option D. Leukemoid reaction: A leukemoid reaction is characterized by a high level of leukocytosis secondary to severe systemic inflammation, not by the presence of blasts or an increased M ratio.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Acute leukemia can present with pancytopenia and splenomegaly
  • Aplastic anemia presents with pancytopenia, there is no splenomegaly.
  • Leukemoid reaction presents with high level of leukocytosis secondary to severe systemic inflammation.
  • CML presents with high TLC count but has insidious onset.

questions.text: A 54-year-old man was brought to the casualty with fever, headache, and focal seizures. EEG shows focal temporal lobe spikes. CSF sample analysis shows 50 cells with 90% Lymphocytes and 10% Neutrophils. What would be the drug of choice for this condition? (FMGE DEC 2021)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Acyclovir

 

The clinical presentation and CSF findings suggest herpes simplex virus (HSV) encephalitis, which commonly affects the temporal lobe and shows lymphocytic pleocytosis And EEG is showing the characteristic finding that temporal lobe epileptiform spikes.

 

DOC - IV Acyclovir

 

  • Standard Dose: 10 to 15 mg per kilogram, administered three times a day.
  • Monitoring:
  • Renal Function: Acyclovir can crystallize in the urine, potentially causing acute kidney injury (AKI) – needle shaped crystal
  • Hydration: Ensure the patient is adequately hydrated to help prevent crystallization.
  • Precautions: Monitor renal function closely, especially when using high doses in the context of herpes simplex virus encephalitis.

 

Note –

 

  • Herpes simplex virus (HSV) encephalitis can occur at any age and during any season
  • MRI Findings: Temporal lobe hyperintensity, particularly on the medial side of the temporal lobe.
  • Clinical Presentation: Patients often present with focal seizures or behavioral abnormalities due to temporal lobe involvement.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Valacyclovir: An oral prodrug of acyclovir, not preferred for initial severe cases requiring intravenous treatment.

 

Option C. Gancyclovir: Used for cytomegalovirus (CMV) infections, not HSV.

 

Option D. Foscarnet: Reserved for resistant HSV or CMV infections.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Acyclovir is the treatment of choice for HSV encephalitis.

questions.text: A HIV patient presents with persistent diarrhea. Microscopic examination of the stool is given below. Identify the causative organism? (FMGE DECEMBER 2021)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Cryptosporidium

 

Cryptosporidium is a protozoan parasite that commonly causes diarrhea in immunocompromised individuals, such as those with HIV/AIDS. The image provided shows the characteristic appearance of Cryptosporidium oocysts, which are typically detected in stool samples using staining techniques.

 

Cryptosporidium:

 

  • Transmission: Typically occurs through ingestion of contaminated water or food.
  • Symptoms: Includes persistent diarrhea, abdominal pain, nausea, and vomiting. In immunocompromised patients, the diarrhea can be severe and lead to significant dehydration and weight loss.
  • Diagnosis: The diagnosis is confirmed by microscopic examination of stool samples. Special stains such as modified Ziehl-Neelsen stain (kinoun stain) can be used to visualize the oocysts, which appear as round, red-stained structures against a blue or green background.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Cyclospora: Another coccidian parasite causing diarrhea, but the oocysts are larger than those of Cryptosporidium and require different staining techniques (such as modified acid-fast stain) for identification.

 

Option C. Microspora: Refers to microsporidia, which are also known to cause diarrhea in HIV patients. However, they appear as small spores and require specific staining techniques like Chromotrope 2R or calcofluor white stain.

 

Option D. Cystoisospora (formerly Isospora): Causes isosporiasis, another diarrheal illness in immunocompromised individuals. The oocysts are larger and ellipsoidal, detected using acid-fast staining methods.

 

Educational Objective:

 

In HIV patients with persistent diarrhea, Cryptosporidium is a common causative organism, identified by its characteristic oocysts in stool samples stained with special stains like the kinoun stain.

choices.text: Cover with hot damp sheets
Cover with cool damp sheets

questions.text: A man was working in a field and he suddenly collapsed on a hot summer afternoon. On examination, there were no physical signs of dehydration but radial pulse was present. His serum electrolytes level was normal. The doctor found that the body temperature was 106 degrees Fahrenheit. Which of the following should be given as first aid in this case? (FMGE DEC 2021)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Cover with cool damp sheets

 

The man is experiencing classic heat stroke, indicated by high body temperature and collapse. The first aid should involve cooling measures, such as covering with cool damp sheets, to lower body temperature rapidly and prevent organ damage.

 

There are two main types of cooling methods for managing heat-related illnesses:

 

  1. Passive Cooling: This involves placing the patient in a shaded area or a cool environment without any additional measures. It relies on the natural cooling effect of the environment.
  2. Active Cooling: This method involves more direct and proactive cooling techniques and can be further divided into:
    • Active External Cooling: Applying cool, damp sheets, ice water, or using ice water baths to reduce body temperature.
    • Active Internal Cooling: Infusing cold saline solutions, such as cold dextrose in normal saline (DNS) or cold Ringer's lactate (RL), chilled to around 15°C.

 

For immediate treatment, both passive and active cooling methods should be utilized. Active cooling, especially using cold and damp sheets, is commonly employed for effective temperature reduction.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Inject epinephrine immediately: Not indicated for heat stroke; used for anaphylaxis.

 

Option B. Cover with hot damp sheets: Would worsen the condition by increasing body temperature.

 

Option D. Start CPR: Not necessary as the patient has a radial pulse and is not in cardiac arrest.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Cooling measures, like covering with cool damp sheets, are crucial in the first aid for heat stroke.

questions.text: A 14-year-old male presented with recurrent epistaxis. There is no history of trauma associated with it. He also complained of nasal obstruction and rhinorrhea. On examination, there is a firm purplish mass on the posterior nasopharynx. What is the most probable diagnosis? (FMGE DEC 2021)
questions.solution:
Ans. D. Juvenile nasopharyngeal angiofibroma

 

The history of a juvenile male with recurrent spontaneous epistaxis and nasal obstruction is suggestive of juvenile angiofibroma.

 

Juvenile nasopharyngeal angiofibroma

 

  • Most common benign tumor of nasopharynx.
  • Site of origin: sphenopalatine foramen.
  • It is highly vascular tumor. vessels are just endothelium-lined spaces with no elastic or muscle coat. This accounts for the severe bleeding as the vessels lose the ability to contract; also, the bleeding cannot be controlled by application of adrenaline, hence biopsy is contraindicated.

 

Extensions of JNA

 

  1. Nasal cavity causing nasal obstruction, epistaxis and nasal discharge.
  2. Paranasal sinuses. Maxillary, sphenoid and ethmoid sinuses can all be invaded.
  3. Pterygomaxillary fossa, infratemporal fossa and cheek.
  4. Orbits giving rise to proptosis and “frog-face deformity.” It enters through the inferior orbital fissure and also destroys apex of the orbit. It can also enter the orbit through superior orbital fissure.
  5. Cranial cavity. It can extend into:
  6. Anterior cranial fossa through roof of ethmoids or cribriform plate.
  7. Middle cranial fossa through erosion of floor of middle cranial fossa or indirectly by invading the sphenoid sinus and Sella turcica. In the former case, tumor lies lateral to internal carotid artery and in the latter case medial to the artery

 

Clinical features:

 

  • Adolescent male
  • Profuse spontaneous recurrent epistaxis
  • Nasal obstruction with denasal speech
  • Conductive hearing loss due to tubal block

 

 

  • Other clinical features like broadening of nasal bridge, proptosis, swelling of cheek, infratemporal fossa or involvement of IInd, IIIrd, IVth and VIth cranial nerves will depend on the extent of tumor.

 

 

Treatment – Surgical excision is treatment of choice.

 

Investigation:

 

CECT (contrast enhanced CT) - This shows Hollman miller sign or antral sign i.e., anterior bowing of posterior wall of maxillary sinus MRI is complementary to CT scan Angiography – to assess blood supply of tumor. Feeding vessels should be embolized preoperatively

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Nasopharyngeal carcinoma presents with Painless cervical lymphadenopathy, nasal obstruction, rhinolalia clausa, unilateral hearing loss of conductive type due to serous otitis media caused by ET obstruction

 

Option B. Rhabdomyosarcoma arises from the embryonic muscles tissue or the pluripotent mesenchyme. In early stages, it mimics chronic suppurative otitis media with ear discharge, polyp or granulations.

 

 

Option C. Pyogenic granuloma is a reactive granuloma usually occurs in response to trauma or chronic irritation. It mostly involves anterior gingivae but sometimes the other sites such as tongue, buccal mucosa or lips.

 

 

 

Educational Objective:

 

Juvenile nasopharyngeal angiofibroma should be strongly considered in adolescent males presenting with unexplained, recurrent epistaxis and nasal obstruction, especially when a nasopharyngeal mass is identified. Prompt and thorough diagnostic imaging followed by surgical planning is essential for effective management of this condition.

questions.text: What appearance seen on Chest Xray of a patient of silicosis who is having respiratory difficulty? (FMGE DEC 2021)
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Snow storm appearance

 

Silicosis: most common occupational lung disease.


Chest Xray has snowstorm appearance.

 

 

Caused by birefringent silica particles of Sio2.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Honey comb appearance: This is typically seen in interstitial lung diseases such as idiopathic pulmonary fibrosis and not specific to silicosis.

 

Option B. Starry Sky appearance: This description is not typically used for chest X-rays and is more commonly associated with the appearance of lymphoid tissue in certain types of lymphoma under microscopic examination.

 

Option C. Tram Track appearance: This is seen in conditions like bronchiectasis, characterized by parallel line opacities representing dilated bronchi.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The "snow storm" appearance on a chest X-ray is characteristic of silicosis, the most common occupational lung disease caused by inhalation of silica particles.

questions.text: A patient from Uttar Pradesh is diagnosed with tumor in abdomen and got operated. On histopathological examinations tumor was found to be originated from all three germ layers. What is the diagnosis? (FMGE DEC 2021)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Teratoma

 

Teratoma arises from all 3 germ layers. Cells of teratoma are totipotent. Most common site of teratoma is gonads.

 

In females teratoma of ovaries known as dermoid cyst and they are usually benign

 

In males - Teratoma in relation to testis are usually malignant.

 

M/c extra gonadal site for teratoma is mediastinum.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Adenoma: A benign tumor originating from glandular tissue, not involving all three germ layers.

 

Option C. Multiple myeloma: A malignancy of plasma cells, not related to the germ layers.

 

Option D. Anus material: This option is not relevant and appears to be incorrect.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Teratomas originate from all three germ layers and can be found in the gonads or extragonadal sites such as the mediastinum.

questions.text: A 29-year-old pregnant woman in 7th week of pregnancy presents with right lower abdominal quadrant pain. She was diagnosed with acute appendicitis. What is the best management for this patient? (FMGE DEC 2021)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Immediate Laparoscopic appendectomy

 

Immediate laparoscopic appendectomy is the most appropriate treatment for acute appendicitis in a pregnant patient to prevent potential complications for both the mother and the fetus. Laparoscopic appendectomy is a minimally invasive surgical procedure to remove the appendix, typically performed in the first two trimesters. This method is preferred due to advantages such as reduced postoperative pain, quicker recovery, and fewer postoperative complications compared to open surgery. Delaying surgery in cases of acute appendicitis increases the risk of complications like rupture, abscess formation, fetal loss, or preterm birth.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Wait till 28 weeks of pregnancy: Waiting to perform surgery until 28 weeks of pregnancy is inappropriate for acute appendicitis. Delaying treatment can lead to serious complications such as rupture or abscess formation, which can increase the risk of fetal loss or preterm birth. While surgical intervention in the second trimester is considered safer, it is not advisable to wait in acute conditions.

 

Option C. Oschner Sherren regimen: This regimen is used for conservative management of an appendicular mass, which develops when there is delayed presentation of appendicitis and the body walls off the inflammation, forming a palpable lump. It involves bed rest, antibiotics, and nil by mouth until symptoms subside. This regimen is not appropriate for acute appendicitis without lump formation.

 

Option D. MTP (Medical Termination of Pregnancy): Termination of pregnancy would not be the first line of management for appendicitis. It would only be considered if there were significant complications that endangered the mother's life or if the fetus showed signs of distress or anomalies. In this scenario, the primary recommendation is to address the acute appendicitis surgically.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The appropriate management of acute appendicitis in a pregnant patient is immediate laparoscopic appendectomy to prevent complications for both the mother and the fetus.

choices.text: Ask the mother to give high fiber diet
Plain X-ray of the abdomen
Barium enema and Anorectal manometry

questions.text: A 6-year-old child is suffering from constipation. Despite giving stool softeners the child is able to pass only one stool in a week. There is a history of delayed passage of meconium after 48 hours at birth. What initial management will you prescribe for this child? (FMGE DECEMEBR 2021)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Barium enema and Anorectal manometry

 

The history provided is suggestive of Hirschsprung’s disease, a condition characterized by the absence of ganglion cells in the distal colon, leading to functional obstruction. This condition often presents in early childhood with symptoms of constipation and a history of delayed meconium passage.

 

  • Barium enema: This radiological test involves introducing barium contrast into the colon via the rectum, allowing visualization of the transition zone between the aganglionic (narrow) and ganglionic (dilated) segments of the colon, which is characteristic of Hirschsprung's disease.
  • Anorectal manometry: This test measures the pressures of the anal sphincter muscles and the neural reflexes necessary for normal bowel movements. In Hirschsprung's disease, the normal rectosphincteric reflex is absent.

 

These tests are critical for diagnosing Hirschsprung's disease. The investigation of choice to confirm the diagnosis is a suction rectal biopsy showing aganglionosis.

 

Other Options:

 

  • Option A. Ask the mother to give high fiber diet:
    • Dietary fiber can help alleviate symptoms of constipation by bulking up stools and promoting regular bowel movements. However, in cases of Hirschsprung's disease, adding fiber might not be effective and can even exacerbate symptoms if there is a significant segment of the colon that is aganglionic (lacking nerve cells). This wouldn't be the first-line intervention in this context.
  • Option B. Plain X-ray of the abdomen:
    • An abdominal X-ray might show an obstruction or fecal loading, especially in the proximal (normal) portion of the bowel. However, it does not provide a specific diagnosis for Hirschsprung's disease and thus is not sufficient as the initial investigation.
  • Option D. Surgical treatment:
    • Surgical intervention is the definitive treatment for Hirschsprung's disease, involving the removal of the aganglionic segment of the bowel. However, this option is pursued after the diagnosis is confirmed and not as an initial approach.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Initial management of suspected Hirschsprung’s disease involves confirming the diagnosis with a Barium enema and Anorectal manometry.

 

Surgeries: Soave, Duhamel and Swenson procedures are done.

questions.text: A patient presented with lesions as shown in the image below and later developed arthritis also. What is the treatment of choice for a patient who presented with the following findings? (FMGE DECEMBER 2021)
questions.solution:
Ans. A. Methotrexate

 

  • The patient has dactylitis of multiple digits, on toes sharply demarcated red Papulosquamous lesions on both toes all of which point towards a diagnosis of psoriatic arthritis.
  • Methotrexate and apremilast are the first-line drugs for the treatment of moderate to severe psoriasis associated with psoriatic arthritis.

 

Psoriatic arthritis

 

  • It refers to an inflammatory musculoskeletal disease characteristically occurring in individuals with psoriasis.
  • Asymmetric oligoarthritis commonly involves a knee or another large joint with a few small joints in the fingers or toes, often with dactylitis.
  • Asymmetric oligoarthritis is the most common type of psoriatic arthritis.
  • Classic psoriatic arthritis typically involves Distal Interphalangeal joints.
  • Arthritis mutilans is worst type of Psoriatic arthritis
  • Methotrexate & apremilast are the first line drugs for the treatment of moderate to severe psoriasis associated with psoriatic arthritis.

 

Additional Information

 

Treatment of ladder for psoriasis:

 

1. Mild plaque psoriasis without psoriatic arthritis

  • It refers to an inflammatory musculoskeletal disease characteristically occurring in individuals with psoriasis.

 

  • First line
  • Coal tar
  • Dithranol
  • Potent topical corticosteroid
  • Vitamin D analogue

 

  • Second line
  • Local NB‐UVB or PUVA
  • Excimer laser

 

2. Moderate to severe plaque psoriasis without psoriatic arthritis

  • First line
  • NB‐UVB or PUVA

 

  • Second line
  • Acitretin
  • Apremilast
  • Ciclosporin
  • Fumaric acid esters (where available)
  • Methotrexate

 

  • Third line
  • Adalimumab
  • Etanercept
  • Infliximab
  • Secukinumab
  • Ustekinumab
