3. Moderate to severe plaque psoriasis with psoriatic arthritis

  • First line
  • Apremilast
  • Methotrexate

 

  • Second line
  • Adalimumab
  • Etanercept
  • Infliximab
  • Ustekinumab

 

  • Third line
  • Combination therapy

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Cyclophosphamide 

 

  • This is a cytotoxic medication most often used in the treatment of cancers and severe autoimmune diseases.
  • It is not typically used as a first-line treatment for arthritis due to its significant side effect profile.

 

Option C. Mycophenolate mofetil 

 

  • This medication is used as an immunosuppressant in organ transplantation and certain autoimmune conditions.
  • While it may be used in the management of connective tissue diseases, it is not the first-line treatment for psoriatic arthritis or rheumatoid arthritis.

 

Option D. Rituximab 

 

  • This is a monoclonal antibody that targets CD20-positive B cells and is used in the treatment of rheumatoid arthritis after other treatments have failed. It is not typically the first choice of treatment for new-onset arthritis associated with skin lesions.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Drug of choice for different types of psoriasis:

questions.text: Which type of epithelium lines the inner surface of the fallopian tube? (FMGE DECEMEBR 2021)
questions.solution:
Ans. C. Ciliated columnar epithelium

 

Explanation:

 

The lining epithelium of the fallopian tube is a single layer of ciliated columnar epithelium. The fallopian tube, also known as the uterine tube or oviduct, is a crucial part of the female reproductive system responsible for transporting eggs from the ovaries to the uterus. It is lined by ciliated columnar epithelium.

 

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Simple Columnar Epithelium: Simple columnar epithelium consists of a single layer of column-shaped cells. This type of epithelium is commonly found in various parts of the digestive tract, including the stomach and intestines, where it plays a role in absorption and secretion. However, it is not the lining of the fallopian tube.

 

Option B. Pseudostratified Ciliated Columnar Epithelium: Pseudostratified ciliated columnar epithelium is characterized by columnar cells that appear stratified due to variations in cell height and the presence of cilia on their apical surfaces. This type of epithelium is found in the respiratory tract, where the cilia help move mucus and foreign particles away from the lungs. It is not the lining of the fallopian tube.

 

Option D. Cuboidal Epithelium with Microvilli: Cuboidal epithelium consists of cube-shaped cells and is found in various glands and ducts in the body. The presence of microvilli on the apical surface of cuboidal cells can enhance their absorptive capacity. However, this type of epithelium is not the lining of the fallopian tube.Top of Form

 

Educational Objective:

 

The fallopian tube is indeed lined by ciliated columnar epithelium. This type of epithelium is specialized for its role in facilitating the movement of eggs (ova) from the ovaries toward the uterus.

 

The cilia on the surface of the columnar cells create coordinated, wave-like movements that help transport the egg. Additionally, the secretions of these cells nourish and protect the egg.

choices.text: Conversion of 25-OH cholecalciferol to 24, 25 di-OH cholecalciferol

questions.text: Which of the following explains the role of sunlight in Vitamin D metabolism: (FMGE DECEMBER 2021)
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Conversion of 7-dehydrocholesterol to cholecalciferol

 

Sunlight plays a crucial role in the synthesis of vitamin D in the skin. Specifically, ultraviolet B (UVB) radiation from sunlight converts 7-dehydrocholesterol, a compound present in the skin, into cholecalciferol, also known as vitamin D3. Cholecalciferol then undergoes further metabolic steps to become the active form of vitamin D.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Conversion of cholecalciferol to 25-OH cholecalciferol: This step occurs in the liver, where cholecalciferol is hydroxylated to 25-hydroxycholecalciferol (25-OH vitamin D3).

 

Option B. Conversion of 25-OH cholecalciferol to calcitriol: This step occurs in the kidneys, where 25-OH vitamin D3 is further hydroxylated to its active form, calcitriol (1,25-dihydroxycholecalciferol).

 

Option C. Conversion of 25-OH cholecalciferol to 24, 25 di-OH cholecalciferol: This step is a minor pathway and occurs in the kidneys, leading to the formation of 24,25-dihydroxycholecalciferol. The major pathway is the conversion to calcitriol.

 

Educational Objective:

 

 

Ref: Harper’s Illustrated Biochemistry 32nd edition Page no. 498

questions.text: Identify the virus given in the image below? (FMGE DECEMBER 2021)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) HIV

 

The image shows an HIV virus.

 

  • It is an enveloped virus with positive-sense single-stranded RNA as its genetic material.
  • HIV primarily infects CD4+ T cells and macrophages.
  • Laboratory diagnosis of HIV infection involves screening tests (EIA/CLIA) and confirmatory tests (Western blot/immunofluorescence assays).
  • Antiretroviral therapy (ART) aims to suppress viral replication, reduce viral load, preserve immune function, and improve quality of life.
  • Prevention strategies include safe sex practices, sterile needle use, HIV testing and counselling, and pre-exposure prophylaxis for high-risk individuals.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. EBV (Epstein-Barr Virus): A member of the herpesvirus family associated with infectious mononucleosis and certain cancers. Structure is shown below.

 

 

 

Option C. CMV (Cytomegalovirus): Another herpesvirus, known for causing infections in immunocompromised individuals, particularly different in structure.

 

 

Option D. Coronavirus: Known for its crown-like appearance under electron microscopy and causes respiratory illnesses like COVID-19.

 

 

Educational Objective:

 

HIV is an enveloped virus with positive-sense single-stranded RNA, known for targeting CD4+ T cells and macrophages, and is identified by the presence of gp120 and gp41 glycoproteins on its surface.

questions.text: Which filter is used in a colposcope? (FMGE DEC 2021)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Green

 

Explanation:

 

  • Green is the color of the filter used in a colposcope.
  • Colposcopy is a procedure in which the cervix is seen on microscopy.
  • This device offers binocular vision with a 6x–15x magnification.
  • To see the vascular pattern clearly, a green filter is utilized to investigate vascular patterns. The distinctive vascular pattern of abnormal regions, such as mosaic, reticular, and punctate, can be used to identify them.
  • Grading is done using Reid Colposcopic Index.
  • Colposcopic examination may be assisted using acetic acid (3-5℅) which stains the abnormal area white (due to clumping of nuclear chromatin) or by the use of Lugol’s iodine where normal cells take up the brown stain (due to glycogen content) whereas the abnormal areas remain unstained.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Black: A black filter is not used in colposcopy. Black filters do not aid in visualizing vascular patterns.

 

Option B. Red: A red filter is not typically used in colposcopy. Red filters do not enhance the visibility of the vascular patterns necessary for this procedure.

 

Option D. Yellow: A yellow filter is not used in colposcopy. Yellow filters are not useful in differentiating the vascular patterns of the cervix.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The green filter in a colposcope is used to clearly visualize the vascular patterns of the cervix, aiding in the identification of abnormal regions.

 

Ref: Dutta’s textbook of Gynecology 6th edition pg 115, Williams textbook of gynecology 3rd edition pg 665

choices.text: Pregnancy associated with Neural tube defects

questions.text: Serial monitoring of serum beta hCG is required for which of the following conditions? (FMGE DEC 2021)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Molar pregnancy

 

Explanation:

 

  • Serum testing repeatedly A molar pregnancy is tested for with beta CG.
  • Serum hCG levels are monitored after the termination of molar pregnancy (post evacuation surveillance)
    • Post Evacuation Surveillance
    • Risk of progression to GTN
    • Done by serial measurement of β hCG to detect persistent/ renewed trophoblastic proliferation.
    • 2 days post evacuation – Baseline
    • Then weekly till negative (7 weeks for partial; 9 weeks for complete)
    • Then monthly for 6 months
    • Contraception

 

Other options:

 

Option A. Downs syndrome: Trisomy 21:  

 

  • First trimester screening: NT-NB scan and Dual marker test (beta HCG raised, PAPPA pregnancy associated plasma protein A decreased)
  • Second trimester screening: Quadruple marker test ( Beta HCG : raised; Alpha feto protein : decreased; Unconjugated estradiol: decreased Inhibin A : raised

 

Option B. Pregnancy associated with Neural tube defects: raised levels of alpha feto protein

 

Option D. Rh negative pregnancy: when the fetus is Rh positive causes isoimmunization which may affect subsequent pregnancies. Indirect Coombs test (ICT) done at monthly intervals is useful to monitor these cases. A titer more than 1:16 is considered significant.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Serial monitoring of serum beta hCG is essential for post-evacuation surveillance of molar pregnancy to detect persistent or renewed trophoblastic proliferation, helping to manage and monitor the risk of progression to gestational trophoblastic neoplasia (GTN).

 

Ref: Dutta’s textbook of obstetrics 8th edition pg 227

questions.text: In a detailed epidemiological study of a remote region, researchers discovered that the sex ratio among a representative sample of 10,000 individuals was over 1000. What does this indicate about the male population in this sample? (FMGE DEC 2021)
questions.solution:
Ans. B. Male population less than 5000

 

Sex Ratio denotes the number of females per 1000 males. 

 

Calculation 

 

Sex Ratio = Total number of females in the country/Total number of males in the country*1000, The sex ratio is typically defined as the number of females per 1000 males. If the sex ratio is greater than 1000, it means there are more than 1000 females for every 1000 males in the population. Given the population is 10,000 and the sex ratio is >1000, it implies that the male population is less than half, which is less than 5000.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The sex ratio is typically defined as the number of females per 1000 males.

questions.text: A non-alcoholic patient starts developing a strong belief that his daughter is trying to kill him, which is not true. What is the diagnosis? (FMGE DECEMBER 2021)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Delusional disorder

 

The patient's fixed, false belief that his daughter is trying to kill him, despite evidence to the contrary, is characteristic of a delusion. When such delusions are the primary symptom without the presence of other psychiatric symptoms like hallucinations, disorganized thinking, or mood symptoms, it is suggestive of a delusional disorder.

 

Other Option:

 

Option A. Depression: While major depressive disorder can sometimes be associated with delusions, they usually occur in the context of other depressive symptoms such as sadness, anhedonia, changes in sleep or appetite, etc.

 

Option B. Bipolar disorder: Patients can have delusions during manic or depressive episodes, but they also exhibit other mood symptoms.

 

Option D. Xenophobia: This is a fear of strangers or foreigners, not a delusional belief about harm from a known person.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Delusional disorder is characterized by one or more delusions that persist for at least one month, without other significant psychiatric symptoms.

 

Reference: Kaplan & Sadock’s Synopsis of Psychiatry, 12th edition, Page No 345-346

questions.text: Which of the following best describes the postmortem image given below? (FMGE DECEMBER 2021)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Cadaveric spasm

 

Image shows cadaveric spasm in a drowning victim having grass from the river bank firmly clutched in the hand suggesting antemortem drowning. Contracted muscles with the absence of primary relaxation in a dead body is the hallmark feature of cadaveric spasm.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Cutis Anserina: Commonly known as "goosebumps" or "goose flesh," it's the temporary change in the appearance of the skin when small bumps develop due to cold or strong emotions.

 

Option B. Rigor Mortis: The stiffening of muscles in a body that occurs after death. It's caused by chemical changes in the muscles and is temporary, typically lasting a few hours to a couple of days.

 

Option D. Café Coronary: Colloquially used to describe a heart attack that happens suddenly, often while consuming a meal or a beverage in a café. It's related to the notion that indulging in rich foods might trigger a heart attack.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Cadaveric spasm

 

  •  It is a condition in which the muscles of the body which were in a state of contraction immediately before death, continue to be so after death without passing through the stage of primary relaxation.
  • Cadaveric spasm, being an antemortem phenomenon, reflects the last act of the subject
  • Occurs immediately after death.
  • Only Selected muscles involved (Hands)
  • Intensity of muscle contraction is much more as compared to Rigor Mortis
  • Mechanism: Not known

questions.text: A patient with carcinoma endometrium is treated with pelvic external beam irradiation to the whole pelvis. Which of the following organs is most radiosensitive in the pelvic region? (FMGE DEC 2021)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Ovary

 

Explanation:

 

The most radiosensitive organ in the pelvic region is the ovary. This is because:

 

  • The ovary has a low radiation tolerance level of 2-3 Gy.
  • Age significantly impacts the radiation dose required to induce ovarian failure. Most women over the age of 40 can experience amenorrhea after a single dose of 3–4 Gy. In contrast, oogenesis in younger women is considerably less susceptible to radiation damage.
  • The vagina, in comparison, is highly radio-resistant, with a tolerance dose of around 90 Gy.

 

Other options:

 

Option B. Vagina: This organ is highly radio-resistant, requiring doses up to 90 Gy.

 

Option C. Bladder: While it is radiosensitive, its tolerance is higher compared to the ovary.

 

Option D. Rectum: Similarly, the rectum is sensitive to radiation but has a higher tolerance dose compared to the ovary.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The ovary is the most radiosensitive organ in the pelvic region, with a radiation tolerance level of 2-3 Gy.

 

Ref: Dutta's textbook of Gynecology 6th edition pg 509

choices.text: Initial serum beta hCG level < 200 mlU/mL

questions.text: Which of the following is not an indication for expectant management in unruptured ectopic gestation? (FMGE DEC 2021)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Gestational sac size >4 cm

 

Explanation:

 

Expectant management of unruptured ectopic pregnancy is only suitable for clinically stable, asymptomatic women with specific criteria:

 

  • Clinically stable with no pain.
  • Serum βhCG < 1000 IU/L.
  • Tubal ectopic < 35 mm with no visible heartbeat.
  • Able to return for follow-up.

 

Management involves repeating βhCG levels on days 2, 4, and 7 after the initial test. If βhCG levels drop ≥ 15% from previous values, continue weekly monitoring until a negative result. If values fall < 15%, remain the same, or rise, review the condition and consider shifting to medical or surgical management.

 

A gestational sac size > 4 cm is not suitable for expectant management and typically requires surgical intervention.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Initial serum beta hCG level < 200 mlU/mL: This can be considered for expectant management if other criteria are met.

 

Option C. Asymptomatic: Asymptomatic patients may be managed expectantly if other criteria are met.

 

Option D. Decreasing beta hCG measurements: Decreasing levels indicate a non-viable pregnancy and can be managed expectantly if other criteria are met.

 

Educational Objective:

 

A gestational sac size greater than 4 cm in an unruptured ectopic pregnancy requires surgical intervention and is not suitable for expectant management.

 

Ref: Duttas textbook of obstetrics 8th edition pg 216, page no 378, William’s Obstetrics 25th edition, https://www.nice.org.uk/guidance/ng126

choices.text: Ketone body synthesis

questions.text: Glucagon activates all except:
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Glycolysis

 

Option D. Glycolysis: This is the correct answer. Glycolysis is the metabolic pathway that breaks down glucose to produce energy. Glucagon generally inhibits glycolysis in the liver, as its primary function is to increase blood glucose levels, not consume it. The hormone works to conserve glucose for use by other organs, particularly the brain and red blood cells.

 

Other Options

 

Option A. Gluconeogenesis: Glucagon activates gluconeogenesis, which is the synthesis of glucose from non-carbohydrate precursors. In the liver, glucagon stimulates enzymes involved in this pathway, leading to increased production of glucose, which then enters the bloodstream.

 

Option B. Lipolysis: Glucagon also promotes lipolysis, the breakdown of stored triglycerides into free fatty acids and glycerol in adipose tissue. These fatty acids can be used by various tissues as an energy source, and glycerol can serve as a substrate for gluconeogenesis in the liver.

 

Option C. Ketone Body Synthesis: During prolonged fasting or in conditions where carbohydrate sources are scarce, glucagon stimulates the liver to produce ketone bodies from fatty acids. Ketone bodies serve as an alternative energy source, especially for the brain, when glucose is limited.

 

Educational objective:

 

Glucagon is a catabolic hormone and mainly promotes catabolic processes. In fasting state, it primarily functions to increase blood glucose levels by promoting processes that release glucose into the bloodstream. Therefore, glucagon activates gluconeogenesis, lipolysis (the breakdown of fats into fatty acids and glycerol), and ketone body synthesis. However, glucagon inhibits glycolysis, as its primary goal is to raise blood glucose levels rather than promoting glucose utilization. Glycolysis and Link reactions are activated by Insulin.

 

Ref: Harper’s Illustrated Biochemistry 32nd edition Page no. 188

questions.text: Identify the heart chamber marked in the given CT image.  (FMGE DECEMBER 2021)
questions.solution:
Ans. D. Left atrium

 

Explanation

 

The posterior-most heart chamber is left atrium which is marked in this image. The pulmonary veins are draining in the LA which is an additional clue.

 

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • The left atrium is typically situated posterior to the other cardiac chambers in axial sections of the chest.
  • Right Ventricle (RV) located anteriorly and typically appears triangular in transverse sections.
  • Left Ventricle (LV) situated next to the left atrium but is more anterior and has a thicker wall, responsible for pumping oxygenated blood to the body.

questions.text: A school-going child presents with a history of recurrent upper respiratory tract infections, mouth breathing, and impaired hearing. On examination, a high arched palate is noted. What is the management of this condition? (FMGE DEC 2021)
questions.solution:
Ans. C. Adenoidectomy with grommet insertion

 

The presented clinical presentation indicates the presence of adenoid hypertrophy accompanied by serous otitis media. The most suitable course of action for management involves performing an adenoidectomy and inserting grommets.

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Tonsillectomy: This would generally be considered if the tonsils themselves were enlarged and contributing to oropharyngeal obstruction or recurrent tonsillitis, which is not specifically indicated in this scenario.

 

Option B. Adenoidectomy: Alone could be an option but might not sufficiently address the middle ear effusion without grommet insertion.

 

Option D. Myringotomy with grommet insertion: Focuses only on the ear symptoms and does not address the adenoid hypertrophy, which is the underlying cause of the eustachian tube dysfunction.

 

Educational Objective:

 

In cases of adenoid hypertrophy with concurrent serous otitis media, combining adenoidectomy with grommet insertion provides a comprehensive approach, treating both the root cause and its secondary complications. This strategy ensures both immediate and long-term relief from the symptoms, promoting better respiratory and auditory health.

questions.text: In evaluating a health report on a developing country, a metric is highlighted that quantifies the number of maternal deaths per 100,000 live births. This statistic is vital for understanding the status of maternal health and monitoring the progress of health initiatives. What is this specific metric called? (FMGE DEC 2021)
questions.solution:
Ans. B. Maternal mortality ratio

 

Maternal mortality Ratio (MMR): Maternal deaths expressed as per 100,000 live births where a ‘maternal death’ is defined as ‘death of a women while pregnant of during delivery or within 42 days (6 weeks) of termination of pregnancy, irrespective of duration or site of pregnancy, from any cause related to or aggravated by the pregnancy or its management but not from accidental or incidental causes.

 

MMR is a ratio 

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Maternal Mortality rate (MMRate): It is calculated by dividing the average annual number of maternal deaths in a population by the average number of women of reproductive age (typically those aged 15 to 49 years) who are alive during the observation period. MMRate reflects the risk of maternal death per pregnancy or per birth and the level of fertility in a population. 

 

Option C. Infant Mortality Rate: Measures the number of infant deaths for every 1,000 live births in a year, which is a different focus.

 

Option D. Under 5 Mortality rate: Counts the deaths of children under five per 1,000 live births, focusing on child health beyond the neonatal period.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The Maternal Mortality Ratio is crucial for gauging the health of pregnant women and new mothers, providing insights into the safety and quality of maternal health services in any given region.

 

Ref. Park 27/e p635

questions.text: A patient came with complaints of diarrhea, dermatitis and mental retardation. It was also found that he was a maize eater. What is the probable diagnosis?(FMGE DECEMBER 2021)
questions.solution:
Ans. C. Pellagra

 

Vitamin B3 / Niacin deficiency, or pellagra, causes diarrhea, dermatitis over sun-exposed areas, dementia, and, if untreated, death. Diets high in maize and jawar put people at risk for pellagra. Pellagra can be brought on by excessive alcohol use, the carcinoid syndrome, or Hartnup disease.

 

 

Pellagroid dermatitis features depicted in above image

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Kwashiorkor:

 

  • This is a form of severe protein malnutrition characterized by edema, an enlarged liver with fatty infiltrates, and dermatosis.
  • The skin may appear flaky, with areas of redness and depigmentation, often described as a "flaky paint" dermatosis. This occurs because of the breakdown of the skin barrier and can lead to secondary bacterial infections.

 

Option B. Night blindness:

 

  • Night blindness, or nyctalopia, is primarily caused by a deficiency of vitamin A. This deficiency affects the eyes, leading to problems seeing in low light or darkness. The symptoms described in the question don't point towards a vitamin A deficiency.

 

Option D. Beri Beri:

 

  • Beri Beri is caused by a deficiency of thiamine (vitamin B1). There are two main forms: wet beriberi (affecting the cardiovascular system) and dry beriberi (affecting the nervous system). The symptoms can include weakness, pain, and mental confusion, but the classic triad seen in pellagra is not characteristic of beri beri.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Pellagra is recognized by its classic triad of diarrhea, dermatitis, and dementia, especially in the context of a diet predominantly consisting of maize, which lacks adequate niacin and tryptophan.

 

Reference: Rook's Textbook of Dermatology 9th edition Chapter 63 Page number 63.4

choices.text: Posterior urethral valves
Ectopic ureter / Duplicate ureter
Urinary tract infection

questions.text: A 7-year-old girl is having continuous dribbling of urine with normal voiding pattern. What is the most likely cause? (FMGE DECEMEBR 2021)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Ectopic ureter/ Duplicate ureter

 

An ectopic ureter is a congenital anomaly where the ureter does not insert into the bladder in its normal anatomical location. In females, it can drain urine into the urethra, vagina, or other locations outside the bladder, leading to continuous dribbling of urine because the urine bypasses the normal control mechanisms of the bladder. This is the most likely cause in the presented case of a 7-year-old girl with continuous dribbling of urine and a normal voiding pattern.

 

Other Options:

 

  • Option A. Posterior urethral valves:
    • This is a congenital condition mostly seen in male infants and involves an obstruction in the posterior urethra. It is characterized by a weak urine stream, difficulty in emptying the bladder, recurrent urinary tract infections, and potential kidney damage. It is not common in females and therefore is not the most likely cause in this scenario.
  • Option C. Urinary tract infection (UTI):
    • A UTI can cause symptoms such as urgency, frequency, pain during urination, and sometimes incontinence. However, continuous dribbling of urine is not typical of a UTI, and such infections are usually accompanied by symptoms like pain, burning sensation, and fever, which are not mentioned in this case.
  • Option D. Vesicoureteric reflux:
    • This condition involves the backward flow of urine from the bladder to the ureters and possibly the kidneys. It can lead to recurrent UTIs and potential kidney damage, but it does not typically present as continuous dribbling of urine.

 

Educational Objective:

 

In a young female patient presenting with continuous dribbling of urine with a normal voiding pattern, consider the possibility of an ectopic ureter or duplicated ureter. This congenital anomaly allows urine to bypass the bladder, leading to continuous leakage.

choices.text: To differentiate between chronic inversion and fibroid polyp
It is used to diagnose cervical stenosis
It is used in Fallopian Tube Recanalization
It is used to measure the uterine cavity and the cervical length

questions.text: During your internship, you notice the following instrument being used by the senior resident. The uses of this instrument include all the following except: (FMGE DEC 2021)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) It is used in Fallopian Tube Recanalization

 

Explanation:

 

  • The object in the photograph above is Simpson's uterine sound.
  • It is NOT used in the recanalization of the fallopian tube. Special thin cannulae are used for this purpose.
  • Uterine sound uses include:
    • Measuring the uterine cavity and cervical length.
    • Diagnosing cervical stenosis.
    • Identifying a missing intrauterine contraceptive device (IUCD).
    • Differentiating between chronic inversion and fibroid polyp (in fibroid polyp, the sound can enter the uterine cavity; in chronic inversion, it cannot as the whole uterus is inverted inside out).

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. To differentiate between chronic inversion and fibroid polyp: This is a use of the uterine sound as described.

 

Option B. It is used to diagnose cervical stenosis: This is a valid use of the uterine sound.

 

Option D. It is used to measure the uterine cavity and the cervical length: This is another correct use of the uterine sound.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Simpson's uterine sound is not used in Fallopian Tube Recanalization; it is primarily used to measure the uterine cavity, diagnose cervical stenosis, identify missing IUCDs, and differentiate between chronic inversion and fibroid polyp.

 

Ref: Duttas textbook of obstetrics 8th edition pg 750, Duttas textbook of Gynaecology 6th edition 224

questions.text: A 30-year-old male presented to emergency with head trauma due to road traffic accident. In hospital, the patient developed seizures. Emergency CT scan revealed widespread cerebral edema. Which of the following is diuretic of choice for cerebral edema in this patient? (FMGE DECEMBER 2021)
questions.solution:
Ans. A. Mannitol

 

Mannitol is an osmotic diuretic which can be used for the management of cerebral edema (in the absence of intracerebral bleed). It works by increasing the osmolality of the blood, drawing water out of tissues, including the brain, into the vascular compartment, thus decreasing intracranial pressure. This makes Mannitol particularly useful in acute settings of cerebral edema due to trauma, where rapid reduction of intracranial pressure can be life-saving.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Spironolactone: This is a potassium-sparing diuretic that primarily acts on the distal convoluted tubule and collecting ducts in the kidneys. It is used for conditions such as hypertension, heart failure, and hyperaldosteronism but does not decrease intracranial pressure and thus is not suitable for treating cerebral edema.

 

Option C. Furosemide: While Furosemide is a potent loop diuretic often used to manage edema and fluid overload in congestive heart failure and renal failure, it is less effective than Mannitol for cerebral edema because it does not significantly affect the osmotic gradient between the brain tissues and plasma.

 

Option D. Hydrochlorothiazide: A thiazide diuretic mainly used for hypertension and mild to moderate peripheral edema. It is ineffective for acute management of cerebral edema due to its mechanism of action and relative potency.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Important indications of mannitol are:

 

  • Acute congestive glaucoma (DOC)

  • Cerebral edema (DOC)

  • Incipient renal failure


Contra-indications of Mannitol are:

 

  • Congestive heart failure

  • Pulmonary edema

  • Acute renal failure

  • Cerebral hemorrhage

choices.text: Failure in closure of anterior neuropore of neural tube
Failure in closure of posterior neuropore of neural tube
Failure in closure of complete neural tube
Failure in closure of caudal neuropore of neural tube

questions.text: What is the embryological basis of the developmental defect shown in the image below? (FMGE DECEMBER 2021)
questions.solution:
Ans. A. Failure in closure of anterior neuropore of neural tube

 

Explanation

 

The image shows the congenital defect - Anencephaly.

Anencephaly occurs when the anterior (cranial) portion of the neural tube fails to close properly during embryonic development. As a result, the brain and skull do not form correctly, and a major portion of the brain may be missing. Babies born with anencephaly typically have a very short life expectancy and severe neurological deficits. This condition is incompatible with long-term survival, and infants with anencephaly are usually stillborn or die shortly after birth.

 

 

Other options:

 

Option B) Failure in Closure of Posterior Neuropore of Neural Tube: This condition is known as "spina bifida." Spina bifida occurs when the posterior (caudal) portion of the neural tube fails to close completely during development. There are different forms and severities of spina bifida, including spina bifida occulta (mildest), meningocele, and myelomeningocele (most severe). In myelomeningocele, the spinal cord and its protective covering (meninges) protrude through an opening in the spine, leading to significant neurological and motor impairments.

 

Option C) Failure in Closure of Complete Neural Tube: The complete failure of neural tube closure would likely result in a situation where there is no development of the brain or spinal cord, rendering the embryo nonviable.

 

Option D) Failure in Closure of Caudal Neuropore of Neural Tube: Failure to close the caudal (lower) neuropore of the neural tube results in a condition known as "caudal dysplasia" or "caudal regression syndrome." This condition primarily affects the lower part of the spine and may lead to abnormalities in the development of the lower limbs, urinary and gastrointestinal systems, and the spinal cord itself.

 

Educational Objective

 

  • Exencephaly is the failure of the anterior end (cranial end) of the neural tube to close. As a result, the skull vault does not form. This exposes the deformed brain. The exposed brain tissue degenerates, leaving a mass of necrotic tissue.
  • Anencephaly is the absence of a significant portion of the brain, skull, and scalp. The brain stem is still intact.

questions.text: Which of the following options contains all intravenous hypnotic agents? (FMGE DECEMBER 2021)
questions.solution:
Ans. A. Propofol, Sodium thiopentone, Etomidate

 

Contains drugs that are all intravenous anesthetics commonly used as hypnotic agents in the induction of anesthesia.

 

  • Propofol is widely used due to its rapid onset and short duration of action, making it ideal for induction as well as maintenance of anesthesia.

  • Sodium thiopentone is a barbiturate used for the induction of anesthesia, providing effective and quick unconsciousness.

  • Etomidate is another IV anesthetic known for its cardiovascular stability, often chosen in patients at risk of hypotension.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Halothane, Sevoflurane, Desflurane: These are inhalational anesthetic agents, not intravenous. They are used for both induction and maintenance of anesthesia but are administered via inhalation, not IV.

 

Option C. Sugammadex, Sufentanil, Tramadol: Sugammadex is a reversal agent for certain muscle relaxants; it is not an anesthetic. Sufentanil is an opioid analgesic, and Tramadol is a pain reliever, both used to manage pain rather than as primary hypnotic agents.

 

Option D. Vecuronium, Rocuronium, Atracurium: These are all muscle relaxants used in anesthesia to facilitate intubation and surgery. They do not have hypnotic properties and do not induce unconsciousness.

 

Educational Objective:

 

When selecting an agent for inducing anesthesia, it is important to choose a drug that is specifically intended for this purpose. Intravenous hypnotic agents like those listed in Option A are specifically designed to induce unconsciousness rapidly and safely, with properties that allow for quick adjustment of anesthesia depth and easy recovery.

questions.text: Vitamin K supplementation is given to neonates to prevent? (FMGE DEC 2021)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Hemorrhagic disease of newborn

 

All newborn infants receive an intramuscular injection of phytonadione (Vitamin K) with 0.5–1 mg to prevent hemorrhagic illness.

 

Factors II, VII, IX, and X, which are dependent on vitamin K, are temporarily deficient, and this leads to hemorrhagic illness in newborns.

 

Deficiency of free vitamin K from the mother.

 

It responds to vitamin K therapy, which also works to prevent it (0.5-1 mg of phytonadione).

 

However, neonates who are vitamin K deficient receive 1–5 mg of vitamin K intravenously.

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Breast milk jaundice: Breast milk jaundice is late onset seen in second week of birth. It is due to increased breast feeding. No treatment is required

 

Option C. keratomalacia: Keratomalacia is a severe eye condition that involves the softening and destruction of the cornea, the clear front part of the eye that covers the iris and the pupil. It is most commonly caused by a severe deficiency of vitamin A and is often associated with malnutrition.

 

Option D. Scurvy: Baby will have pseuodparalysis of limbs with arthritis, bleeding gums, crying while bathing or changing clothes.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Vitamin K supplementation is crucial for preventing hemorrhagic disease of the newborn, which is due to the deficiency of vitamin K-dependent clotting factors.

questions.text: A 46-year-old woman experiences an allergic reaction after eating a meal containing pearl millet (bajra) mixed with unknown black seeds. To analyze the seeds by separating them based on density, which solution should be used to effectively differentiate between the bajra and the black seeds? (FMGE DEC 2021)
questions.solution:
Ans. C. 20% salt solution

 

A 20% salt solution is ideal for separating bajra grains from potential contaminants like ergot seeds based on their density differences. In this solution, ergot seeds, which are lighter, will float, while the denser bajra grains will settle at the bottom. This method is not only effective but also straightforward, allowing for quick and clear differentiation between the grains and any adulterants, which is crucial for further analysis and ensuring food safety.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Distilled water: May not create enough density contrast to effectively separate the seeds based on their specific densities.

 

Option B. 10% salt solution: Might not be concentrated enough to differentiate between the densities of bajra and the black seeds.

 

Option D. Normal saline: Typically has a salt concentration of about 0.9%, which is too low to create the necessary density gradient for this purpose.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Ergotism

 

  • Occurs due to food toxicant - ergot fungus ‘Claviceps fusiformis’
  • Food items having a tendency for ergotism - Bajra, Rye, Sorghum, Wheat, 
  • Removal of ergot:
    • Float in 20% salt water
    • Hand-picking
    • Air-floatation
  • Upper safe limit for ergot: 0.05 mg per 100 grams’ food material

questions.text: A 38-year-old public health officer in a state health department is focusing on evaluating birth and death rates to aid in health program planning. She needs to select a system specifically designed to assess these rates accurately at state or national levels. Which system or method is the most appropriate for her needs? (FMGE DEC 2021)
questions.solution:
Ans. B. Sample Registration System

 

The Sample Registration System (SRS) is the most suitable choice for assessing birth and death rates at state or national levels. Initiated as a pilot in 1964-65 and scaled up in 1969-70, the SRS provides reliable estimates of fertility and mortality, including birth rates, death rates, and infant mortality rates. It operates through a dual record system combining continuous enumeration by an enumerator and independent retrospective surveys, making it a highly effective tool for generating accurate demographic data essential for public health planning and evaluation.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Census: While useful for providing a broad demographic snapshot, the census occurs only every ten years and may not offer the timely data needed for ongoing health program adjustments.

 

Option C. Death certificate: This documents individual deaths but does not provide aggregated data necessary for broader demographic analysis.

 

Option D. Lay reporting: Involves non-professional reporting of health events, which can be useful for certain data collection but lacks the systematic approach required for accurate state or national level assessments.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Evaluation of birth and death rate done by Sample Registration system.

 

Main objective of SRS: To provide reliable estimates of Birth Rate, Death Rate and Infant Mortality Rate at the natural division level for rural areas and at the state level for urban areas.

 

 SRS is a dual record system:

 

  • Field Investigation: continuous enumeration of births and deaths by an enumerator
  • Independent retrospective survey: every 6 months by an investigator-supervisor

 

Additional Information

 

Advantages of SRS:

 

  • Elimination of errors of duplication
  • Leads to a quantitative assessment of the sources of distortion in the two sets of records making it a self evaluating technique.

 

Primary objective: To build up statistics on ‘Most Probable Causes of Death’ for rural and urban areas using lay diagnosis reporting (Post Death Verbal Autopsy)’ method

 

Main components of SRS:

 

  • Base-line survey - To obtain usual resident population of the sample areas
  • Continuous (longitudinal) enumeration of vital events 
  • Independent retrospective half-yearly surveys for recording births and deaths which occurred during the half-year under reference and updating the Houselist, Household schedule and the list of women in the reproductive age group along with their pregnancy status by the Supervisor
  • Matching of events recorded during continuous enumeration and those listed in course of half-yearly survey
  • Field verification of unmatched and partially matched events
  • Filling of Verbal Autopsy forms for finalized deaths

 

Sample design adopted for SRS: A unistage stratified simple random sample. Infant Mortality is the decisive indicator for estimation of sample size at Natural Division

questions.text: Identify the parasite? (FMGE DECEMBER 2021)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Giardia lamblia

 

The image shows the trophozoite form of Giardia lamblia. This protozoan parasite is known for its characteristic pear shape, with flagella and a "smiling face" appearance due to its two nuclei.

 

Giardia lamblia:

 

  • Morphology: Pear-shaped trophozoites with two nuclei that look like eyes and multiple flagella.
  • Transmission: Fecal-oral route, often through contaminated water or food.
  • Clinical Presentation: Causes giardiasis, which can present with symptoms such as diarrhea, abdominal cramps, bloating, and weight loss. Chronic infection may lead to malabsorption and nutritional deficiencies.
  • Diagnosis: Identification of trophozoites or cysts in stool samples, often using direct microscopy or immunoassays.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Trichomonas vaginalis: This parasite causes trichomoniasis, a sexually transmitted infection. The trophozoites have a characteristic pear shape with a single nucleus and multiple flagella but lack the "smiling face" appearance.

 

 

 

Option C. Trypanosoma: This genus includes species such as Trypanosoma brucei and Trypanosoma cruzi, which cause African sleeping sickness and Chagas disease, respectively. These parasites are characterized by their elongated shape with a single flagellum.

 

 

 

Option D. Cyclospora: This protozoan parasite causes cyclosporiasis, presenting with watery diarrhea, and is typically identified by its oocysts in stool samples, which are not similar in appearance to Giardia lamblia.

 

 

 

Educational Objective:

 

Giardia lamblia is identified by its distinct trophozoite form with a pear shape and two nuclei giving a "smiling face" appearance. It causes giardiasis, which is commonly diagnosed by detecting trophozoites or cysts in stool samples

questions.text: Following gastrectomy, the patient is most likely to have which of the following? (FMGE DEC 2021)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Vitamin B12 deficiency

 

Gastrectomy reduces the stomach's ability to produce intrinsic factor, which is essential for the absorption of vitamin B12 in the ileum. Without intrinsic factor, vitamin B12 cannot be effectively absorbed, leading to deficiency. This can result in megaloblastic anemia and neurological symptoms if not treated.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Folic acid deficiency: While folic acid absorption can be affected, it is less common than vitamin B12 deficiency post-gastrectomy.

 

Option C. Gastric ulcer: Unlikely as the stomach is resected during gastrectomy.

 

Option D. Constipation: Not directly related to gastrectomy.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Vitamin B12 deficiency is a common complication after gastrectomy due to reduced intrinsic factor production.

questions.text: Which of the following side effects are seen most commonly with Isotretinoin?
questions.solution:
Ans. D. Embryopathy

 

Isotretinoin

 

  • It is commonly used to treat cystic nodular acne. When taken orally, 13 cis retinoic acid, also referred to as isotretinoin, is a highly teratogenic derivative of vitamin A.
  • It interferes with the development of numerous organs and prevents the migration of neural crest cells during embryogenesis. Retinoic acid embryopathy is the collective term for these defects.
  • Ventriculomegaly, malformed facial or cranial bones, microtia or anotia, micrognathia, cleft palate, congenital heart defects, and thymic hyper- or hypoplasia are just a few examples of specific anomalies.
  • In pregnancies exposed during the first quarter of this medication, isotretinoin also increases the risk of spontaneous abortions and stillbirths by up to 40%. Presenting with pregnancy during treatment with isotretinoin is a failure of prevention strategies.

 

The following are the isotretinoin usage guidelines:

 

  • Because it causes birth defects, isotretinoin should not be used while pregnant or nursing.
  • Patients should use two forms of birth control at the same time beginning 1 month before treatment, for the duration of the course of treatment, and for 1 month after stopping isotretinoin.
  • Patients should perform two pregnancy tests before beginning isotretinoin, perform a monthly pregnancy test while taking the medication, and perform a second test 1 month after stopping the medication.
  • Isotretinoin should only be used to treat severe, nodulocystic acne; it should not be used to treat less severe cases of acne.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Discoloration of teeth:

 

  • Tetracyclines, a class of antibiotics, are more commonly linked to the discoloration of teeth when given to children.

 

Option B. Ebstein’s anomaly:

 

  • Ebstein's anomaly is a rare congenital malformation of the heart. Lithium, an agent used for bipolar disorder, has a more established link with Ebstein's anomaly.

 

Option C. Neural tube defects:

 

  • Neural tube defects (NTDs) like spina bifida occur due to the improper closure of the embryonic neural tube.
  • Women who use valproic acid during the pregnancy have a higher risk (compared to the general population) of having a baby with spina bifida and other neural tube defects.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Isotretinoin is highly teratogenic and is associated with severe embryopathy, including a range of developmental abnormalities in fetuses exposed during pregnancy. Due to its significant risks, isotretinoin use is strictly regulated with mandatory contraceptive measures and pregnancy testing to prevent fetal exposure.

 

Additional Information

 

Oral retinoids in acne: 

 

  • DOC: Isotretinoin = 13-cis Retinoic acid
  • Indication: Nodulocystic acne, resistant acne
  • Most common side effect: cheilitis        
  • Dose: 0.5-1 mg/kg/ body weight daily (TCD: 120-150 mg/kg body weight)
  • Lab monitoring: Fasting lipid profile, LFT as oral retinoids are associated with increased triglycerides & total cholesterol
  • Most severe adverse effect: DISH (Diffuse Idiopathic Skeletal Hyperostosis)

 

Pregnancy Category X Teratogenic: 

 

  • Period of drug stoppage prior to conception (women): 28 days or 3 months

 

Drugs safe in pregnancy: 

 

  • Topical erythromycin, azelaic acid, Benzoyl peroxide 
  • Oral erythromycin

 

Some important Drugs, their indications & their ADR:

 

 

Reference: Williams obstetrics 25th edition Page no 540-543

Rooks textbook of dermatology- 9th Edition Chapter 90 page no 90.1, 90.2, 90.18, 90.37

questions.text: In a hospital orientation on waste management, staff are instructed on the proper disposal of contaminated materials. If a medical staff member uses a cotton swab that becomes contaminated with blood, which colored bag should be used for disposal according to the hospital's waste segregation protocols? (FMGE DEC 2021)
questions.solution:
Ans. A. Yellow

 

Cotton swab contaminated with blood is a soiled hospital waste. So it is discarded into the yellow bag.

 

Educational Objective:

questions.text: Which substance helps in the adhesion of leukocyte to the endothelium? (FMGE DEC 2021)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Selectin

 

Cellular events of inflammation:

 

Margination → Rolling →Adhesion → Pavementing → diapedesis → chemotaxis → phagocytosis

 

Selectins and integrin are needed for adhesion. Integrin helps in firm attachment; selectin helps in loose attachment.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. P53: A tumor suppressor gene involved in cell cycle regulation and apoptosis, not in leukocyte adhesion.

 

Option C. Leukotriene: A group of inflammatory mediators involved in chemotaxis and increasing vascular permeability, but not directly in adhesion.

 

Option D. PECAM-1: Platelet Endothelial Cell Adhesion Molecule-1 is involved in diapedesis, the migration of leukocytes through the endothelial layer.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Selectins facilitate the adhesion of leukocytes to the endothelium during the inflammatory response.

choices.text: Combined deficiency of folate and vitamin B12

questions.text: Which causes SCID (Severe Combined Immuno-Deficiency syndrome)? (FMGE DEC 2021)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Deficiency of Adenosine deaminase

 

Adenosine deaminase (ADA) deficiency is an inherited disorder that damages the immune system and causes severe combined immunodeficiency (SCID). People with SCID lack virtually all immune protection from bacteria, viruses, and fungi. They are prone to repeated and persistent infections that can be very serious or life-threatening. These infections are often caused by “opportunistic” organisms that ordinarily do not cause illness in people with a normal immune system.

 

The main symptoms of ADA deficiency are pneumonia, chronic diarrhea, and widespread skin rashes. Affected children also grow much more slowly than healthy children and some have developmental delay.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Deficiency of Tyrosine kinase: While deficiencies in specific tyrosine kinases can lead to immune system abnormalities, they are not typically associated with SCID. For example, Bruton’s tyrosine kinase (BTK) deficiency leads to X-linked agammaglobulinemia.

 

Option C. Vitamin B12 deficiency: This deficiency leads to megaloblastic anemia and neurological symptoms but is not associated with SCID.

 

Option D. Combined deficiency of folate and vitamin B12: Deficiencies in folate and vitamin B12 also cause megaloblastic anemia and are not related to SCID.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Deficiency of adenosine deaminase (ADA) causes severe combined immunodeficiency (SCID), a condition characterized by profound immunodeficiency and susceptibility to severe infections.

questions.text: Cardiac output returns to pre-pregnant levels by? (FMGE DEC 2021)
questions.solution:
Ans. D) 10 days postpartum

 

Explanation:

 

  • Cardiac output begins to increase in pregnancy up to 40 % reaching its peak during pregnancy around 30-34 weeks.
  • It increases up to 50% during labour and
  • it is increased by 70% in the immediate post-partum period.
  • Cardiac output typically remains increased for 24 to 48 hours following delivery and then begins to fall by 10 days to non-pregnant levels.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Cardiac output typically returns to pre-pregnant levels by 10 days postpartum.

 

Ref: Williams textbook of obstetrics 26th edition pg 671 , Duttas textbook of obstetrics 8th edition pg 60

questions.text: A 35-year-old female presented to the emergency with upper abdominal pain radiating to the back. On X-ray, Colon Cut off sign is seen. What is the likely diagnosis? (FMGE DECEMEBR 2021)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Acute Pancreatitis

 

Acute pancreatitis is an inflammation of the pancreas that manifests with severe upper abdominal pain that radiates to the back. The pain is often described as being relieved by sitting or bending forward. One of the radiological signs associated with acute pancreatitis seen on abdominal X-ray is the "colon cut off sign." This sign indicates a gas-filled segment of the colon at the splenic flexure, which abruptly ends due to spasm or inflammation caused by the nearby inflamed pancreas.

 

Common Causes:

 

  • Gallstones
  • Alcohol consumption

 

Symptoms:

 

  • Severe epigastric pain radiating to the back
  • Nausea and vomiting
  • Elevated serum amylase and lipase levels

 

Radiological Signs on X-ray:

 

  • Sentinel loop sign: Dilated loop of small bowel near the inflamed pancreas.
  • Renal halo sign: A fat-attenuation line seen in the perirenal space.
  • Gasless abdomen: Lack of gas in the intestine due to ileus.
  • Ground glass appearance: Due to edema and inflammation.
  • Colon cut off sign: Gas-filled segment of the colon at the splenic flexure abruptly ending.

 

Other Options:

 

  • Option A. Acute Cholecystitis:
    • Acute cholecystitis is inflammation of the gallbladder, typically presenting with right upper quadrant pain, fever, and positive Murphy's sign. Radiological findings might show gallstones and thickening of the gallbladder wall but not the colon cut off sign.
  • Option B. Acute Appendicitis:
    • Acute appendicitis typically presents with right lower quadrant pain, fever, and tenderness at McBurney's point. Imaging might show an enlarged appendix or localized fluid collection but not the colon cut off sign.
  • Option D. Chronic Pancreatitis:
    • Chronic pancreatitis involves persistent inflammation of the pancreas, leading to fibrosis. Symptoms include chronic abdominal pain, malabsorption, and diabetes mellitus. Imaging might show calcifications in the pancreas and ductal changes, but the colon cut off sign is not typically associated with chronic pancreatitis.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The "colon cut off sign" on X-ray is indicative of acute pancreatitis, characterized by severe epigastric pain radiating to the back.

questions.text: What is the Battle sign? (FMGE DEC 2021)
questions.solution:
Ans. A. Mastoid ecchymosis   

 

Battle's sign is characterized by ecchymosis (bruising) over the mastoid process, which is located just behind the ear. This sign is typically associated with fractures of the temporal bone. The presence of such bruising is a delayed symptom that generally appears several hours to days after the injury and serves as a clinical indicator of the fracture's extent and location, potentially involving the base of the skull.

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Periorbital hematoma: Also known as "raccoon eyes," this refers to bruising around the eyes and is another sign that can be associated with base of skull fractures but is not indicative of the specific location over the mastoid process.

 

Option C. Bezold abscess: This is an infection that spreads from the middle ear to involve the mastoid process and surrounding tissues, leading to a collection of pus. Unlike Battle's sign, this is an infectious process, not a direct sign of a fracture.

 

Option D. Perichondritis: This is an infection of the cartilage and surrounding tissue of the ear, typically caused by bacterial infection. It presents with pain, redness, and swelling around the cartilage of the ear but does not relate to temporal bone fractures or manifest as ecchymosis.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Battle’s sign is ecchymosis over the mastoid seen in fractures of temporal bone

 

Reference – Dhingra 7th edition, Page No. 507

questions.text: A young woman visited the ENT OPD reporting a sudden onset of hearing loss in one ear, accompanied by tinnitus and dizziness. This occurred after experiencing an episode of acute otitis media two weeks ago. During her initial visit, the Rinne test and fistula test showed positive results, but she declined treatment at that time. Now, she returned with aggravated hearing loss in the same ear. Upon examination, the fistula test yielded negative results. Considering the situation, what would be the most probable result on the Rinne test in this case? (FMGE DEC 2021)
questions.solution:
Ans. D. False negative

 

The given clinical history suggests severe sensorineural hearing loss secondary to untreated suppurative labyrinthitis, hence Rinne’s test will be false negative.

 

Positive fistula test and Rinne’s positive test in the beginning suggests a functional labyrinth along with normal or early sensorineural hearing loss respectively.

 

False Negative Rinne is seen in severe unilateral sensorineural hearing loss. Patient does not perceive any sound of tuning fork by air conduction but responds to bone conduction testing. This response to bone conduction from the opposite ear because of transcranial transmission of sound.

 

Educational Objective:

 

 

Reference – Dhingra 7th edition, Page No. 24

questions.text: What dose of folic acid is recommended for a woman who wants to become pregnant but has a history of pregnancy complicated with a neural tube defect? (FMGE DEC 2021)
questions.solution:
Ans. D) 4mg/day

 

Explanation:

 

  • Pre-conceptional Folic Acid (400 mcg /day ie. 0.4 mg / day to low risk women; 4 mg/ day to high risk for neural tube defects - NTD).
  • Women at high risk for NTD are
    • H/o previous baby with NTD
    • Pre-gestational Diabetes Mellitus               
    • Folic acid deficiency
    • Obesity hiii
    • Epilepsy/ on Antiepileptic Drugs (AED)

 

Educational Objective:

 

For women with a history of pregnancy complicated by neural tube defects, the recommended pre-conceptional folic acid dose is 4 mg/day.

 

Ref: Williams textbook of obstetrics 26th edition pg 441

questions.text: A 6-year-old child was brought to her pediatrician for routine well-child care. Her physical examination is normal except for a systolic murmur and a widely split-second heart sound that does not vary with respiration. She has no family history of heart disease. Which among the following is the most likely diagnosis? (FMGE DEC 2021)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Atrial septal defect

 

A diagnosis of an atrial septal defect is supported by the patient's age, normal physical findings other than a systolic murmur, and wide and fixed splitting of S2.

 

Atrial septal defect (ASD)

 

 

Types of defects

 

  • Secundum ASD
  • Primum ASD (partial atrioventricular septal defect)
  • Sinus venosus ASD
  • Other

 

Secundum ASD

 

A defect in the centre of the atrial septum involving the fossa ovalis.

 

Clinical features

 

  • Asymptomatic
  • 80% of ASDs
  • Soft systolic murmur at upper left sternal edge
  • Fixed split S2 (difficult to hear)

 

ECG

 

  • Partial right bundle-branch block (90%)
  • Right ventricle hypertrophy

 

Chest X-ray

 

  • Increased pulmonary vascular markings

 

Management

 

  • Closure at 3–5 years (ideally)
  • 90% undergo device closure in catheter laboratory
  • 10% undergo surgical closure (too large or personal preference).

 

Patients with TAPVC typically exhibit cyanosis and congestive heart failure at 4 to 10 weeks of age. Early-onset cardiac failure is caused by the fetal pulmonary vasculature regressing and increasing pulmonary blood flow. The physical findings match those of ASD exactly.

 

Physical signs of VSD, an acyanotic heart condition, include a wide and variable split S2 that is typically hidden by the pansystolic murmur and a pansystolic murmur that is best heard in the left 4th parasternal area.

 

Physical symptoms of PS include an ejection systolic murmur, a thrill in the left second interface, a wide and variable split S2, and a delayed closure of P2. PS is an acyanotic heart disease.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Total anomalous pulmonary venous connection: Patients typically exhibit cyanosis and congestive heart failure at 4 to 10 weeks of age, along with symptoms not matching the described physical findings.

 

Option B. Pulmonic stenosis: This condition presents with an ejection systolic murmur, a thrill in the left second interspace, a wide and variable split S2, and a delayed closure of P2, differing from the fixed split S2 seen in ASD.

 

Option D. Ventricular septal defect: VSD presents with a wide and variable split S2 that is typically hidden by the pansystolic murmur best heard in the left 4th parasternal area, unlike the fixed split S2 in ASD.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Atrial septal defect (ASD) is characterized by a systolic murmur and a wide, fixed split-second heart sound that does not vary with respiration.

 

Ref - O P Ghai, Page No- 405-410.

questions.text: At what level does spinal cord end in infants? (FMGE DEC 2021)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) L3

 

In new born Spinal cord ends at Upper border of L3.

In adults spinal cord ends at lower border of L1.

 

 

Educational Objective:

 

Spinal cord ends at L3 level in infants.

 

Ref: Miller’s Anesthesia, 9th Ed. Pg 1414

questions.text: A couple who recently welcomed their first child into their home consulted a family therapist to navigate this new chapter in their lives. According to standard family life cycle theory, which stage is this family entering? (FMGE DEC 2021)
questions.solution:
Ans. B. Expansion / Extension

 

The family life cycle describes the emotional and developmental stages that most families go through. These stages help professionals understand family dynamics and the evolution of family structures over time.

 

The "Expansion/Extension" stage of the family life cycle begins with the birth of the first child. This phase involves adapting to new roles and responsibilities that come with parenting, expanding the family structure to include child-rearing, and adjusting the couple's relationship to include their roles as parents.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Formation: This stage involves the period from the marriage or significant commitment of the couple up until the birth of the first child. Since the couple already has their first child, they have moved past this stage.

 

Option C. Contraction: This stage starts when the first child moves out of the home, marking a contraction or reduction in the active parenting role.

 

Option D. Dissolution: This is the final stage, occurring after the death of one spouse, leading to the dissolution of the family unit as it was originally known.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Family Cycle has SIX phases; each phase begins with the following events as described below.

 

  • Formation = Marriage of the husband and wife till Birth of the first child
  • Extension = Birth of the first child till Birth of the last child
  • Complete extension = Birth of the last child till First child moving out of the home 
  • Contraction = First child moving out of the home of his/her parents till All the children moving out
  • Complete Contraction = All the children moving out of their parents’ home till Death of one parent.
  • Dissolution = Death of one parent till Death of the other spouse (Extinction)

choices.text: Rich in potassium
Rich on calcium
Rich in sodium
Rich in magnesium

questions.text: DASH DIET includes the following food except?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Rich in sodium

 

Option C. Rich in Sodium: DASH diet specifically recommends reducing sodium intake. High sodium intake is associated with higher blood pressure, and the DASH diet aims to lower sodium consumption to help control or prevent hypertension.

 

Other Options

 

Option A. Rich in Potassium: The DASH diet includes foods rich in potassium. Potassium helps to lessen the effects of sodium on blood pressure and is found in fruits, vegetables, and dairy products, which are integral parts of the DASH diet.

 

Option B. Rich in Calcium: The DASH diet also recommends foods that are rich in calcium. Calcium is important for maintaining healthy blood pressure levels. Dairy products, which are a recommended part of the DASH diet, are a good source of calcium.

 

Option D. Rich in Magnesium: The DASH diet includes foods that are high in magnesium. Magnesium can help lower blood pressure and is found in whole grains, nuts, seeds, and green leafy vegetables, which are encouraged in the DASH diet.

 

Educational objective:

 

The Dietary Approaches to Stop Hypertension (DASH) diet is designed to help prevent and manage hypertension (high blood pressure). The DASH diet emphasizes the consumption of nutrient-rich foods that are high in potassium, calcium, magnesium, and fiber while being low in sodium. Sodium restriction is a key component of the DASH diet, as high sodium intake is associated with increased blood pressure.

 

Ref: https://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/books/NBK482514/

questions.text: Which of the following is used as a screening test for pheochromocytoma?
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Urinary Metanephrines and VMA

 

Pheochromocytoma is a catecholamine-secreting tumor that arises from the adrenal medulla. The best screening test for pheochromocytoma is the measurement of urinary metanephrines and vanillylmandelic acid (VMA), which are metabolites of catecholamines. Elevated levels of these metabolites in the urine are indicative of pheochromocytoma.

 

24-hour urinary fractionated catecholamines, metanephrines, normetanephrines, and VMA assays.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Albumin: Not relevant for diagnosing pheochromocytoma.

 

Option C. 5-HIAA: This test is used for diagnosing carcinoid syndrome, not pheochromocytoma.

 

Option D. Glucose: Blood glucose levels are not related to the diagnosis of pheochromocytoma.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Urinary metanephrines and VMA are the screening tests of choice for pheochromocytoma.

choices.text: It is the breastmilk that is seen in the initial 3-4 days.
Contains high amount of lactose and low amounts of protein.

questions.text: Which of the following statements is incorrect about colostrum? (FMGE DEC 2021)
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Contains high amount of lactose and low amounts of protein.

 

Colostrum is the first milk produced by the breasts during pregnancy and in the early days after giving birth. It is thick and yellowish in color. Colostrum is rich in protein, low in fat, and low in lactose. It contains essential nutrients such as vitamins B12, A, D, E, and K, as well as immunological components like antibodies, secretory IgA, lactoferrin, and leukocytes. These components provide crucial immune protection to the newborn in the early days of life. As breastfeeding continues, colostrum gradually transitions into mature breast milk over the first few weeks, which becomes thinner and more watery but still contains important nutrients and antibodies.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. It is the breastmilk that is seen in the initial 3-4 days: This statement is correct. Colostrum is produced in the first few days after birth.

 

Option B. It is yellow in color: This statement is correct. Colostrum is often yellowish due to its high beta-carotene content.

 

Option C. Contains large number of antibodies: This statement is correct. Colostrum is rich in antibodies, particularly secretory IgA, which helps protect the newborn from infections.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Colostrum, the initial breastmilk produced in the first few days postpartum, is rich in protein and antibodies but low in lactose.

questions.text: A 25-year-old woman with no history of pregnancies is considering a CuT 380A IUD and discusses her health concerns related to its use. Which condition is an absolute contraindication to this contraceptive device? (FMGE DEC 2021)
questions.solution:
Ans. D. Unexplained vaginal bleeding

 

The device shown in the given image is CuT 380A, which has specific contraindications that need careful consideration before it is recommended. Unexplained vaginal bleeding is an absolute contraindication for the placement of an IUD because it could indicate underlying disorders that need diagnosis and treatment before considering insertion of an intrauterine device.

 

Educational Objective:

choices.text: A high concentration of oxygen should be given by a face mask + Salbutamol nebulization
High doses of SABA to be given by a nebulizer only
Sedatives should be added to alleviate anxiety
Nebulized anticholinergics to be added immediately as the mainstay of treatment

questions.text: A 5-year-old male with known history of asthma developed sudden onset breathlessness, and wheezing. He was rushed to the emergency, where the preliminary assessment was done. The pulse is 140/min, respiratory rate 28/min, and the FEV1 is 40% of the predicted value. Which of the following is the best next step in treatment in this case? (FMGE DEC 2021)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) A high concentration of oxygen should be given by a face mask + Salbutamol nebulization

 

The clinical situation described indicates a severe, acute asthma attack. The best course of action for treatment involves administering a high concentration of oxygen via a face mask and nebulizing with salbutamol. This approach addresses both hypoxemia and bronchoconstriction, which are critical aspects of managing a severe asthma exacerbation.

 

Management of Acute Severe Asthma:

 

  • Oxygen: Administer high-flow oxygen via a face mask to maintain oxygen saturation levels above 90%.
  • Short-Acting Beta-Agonists (SABA): Administer large doses of SABA (e.g., salbutamol) via a nebulizer or metered-dose inhaler (MDI) with a spacer. These are the mainstay of treatment for acute asthma.
  • Anticholinergics: If there is an inadequate response to SABA alone, add a nebulized anticholinergic (e.g., ipratropium bromide).
  • Intravenous Beta-Agonists: In critically ill patients with impending respiratory collapse, intravenous Beta-2 agonists may be required.
  • Aminophylline: A continuous infusion may be considered for patients not responding adequately to inhalation treatments.

 

Characteristics of Severe Acute Asthma Attack:

 

  • Inability to complete a full sentence in one breath
  • Pulse rate above 120 beats per minute
  • Respiratory rate over 25 breaths per minute
  • FEV1 between 33% and 50% of predicted
  • Pulsus paradoxus greater than 10 mmHg

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. High doses of SABA to be given by a nebulizer only: While SABA is essential, oxygen supplementation is also critical to address hypoxemia.

 

Option C. Sedatives should be added to alleviate anxiety: Sedatives are generally not recommended as they can depress respiratory drive, which is dangerous in an acute asthma attack.

 

Option D. Nebulized anticholinergics to be added immediately as the mainstay of treatment: Anticholinergics are useful adjuncts but are not the primary treatment. SABA and oxygen are first-line treatments.

 

Educational Objective:

 

In cases of severe acute asthma, administer high-concentration oxygen via a face mask and nebulized SABA (e.g., salbutamol) as the first-line treatment to address hypoxemia and bronchoconstriction.

questions.text: A 56-year-old multiparous woman presented with grade II/III uterine prolapse with cystocele. She complains of passing urine on coughing and sneezing. What is the type of urinary incontinence seen in this patient? (FMGE DEC 2021)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Stress incontinence

 

Explanation:

 

  • Stress incontinence is a form of urine incontinence that patients with prolapse and cystocele experience when they urinate during coughing and sneezing.
  • When there is an increase in intraabdominal pressure, it is known as stress incontinence (e.g. coughing, sneezing, laughing, Valsalva maneuver).
  • In urodynamic investigations, there is no evidence of detrusor muscle contraction.

 

Other options:

 

Option A. Overflow incontinence: Overflow incontinence the inability to completely empty the bladder, characterized by uncontrollable, continuous urination.

 

Option B. Urge incontinence: Urge incontinence is the urgent desire to urinate. It happens because of detrusor instability or overactive detrusor muscles.

 

Option D. Neurogenic bladder: Patients with neurogenic dysfunction that results in detrusor hyperreflexia experience neurogenic bladder. It is seen in multiple sclerosis, stroke, Parkinson's disease, and spinal injury. They exhibit urge incontinence or urgency.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Stress incontinence is a type of urinary incontinence characterized by the involuntary leakage of urine during activities that increase intra-abdominal pressure, such as coughing, sneezing, or laughing, often seen in patients with uterine prolapse and cystocele.

 

Ref: Dutta’s textbook of Gynecology 6th edition pg 398,399 , Williams textbook of Gynecology 3rd edition pg514

questions.text: A couple wished to abort their female fetus after 30 weeks of gestation as they already had five daughters. Their gynecologist refused to resort to criminal methods so they got an abortion done by a quack. What is the method most likely to be? (FMGE DECEMBER 2021)
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Abortion stick

 

Criminal abortion is an artificial termination of pregnancy with the consent of a woman, performed in a manner and within a time frame for which criminal liability is provided

 

Methods of criminal abortion

 

  1. Abortifacient drugs
  2. Drugs directly acting on Uterus:
    • Ecbolics = increase Uterine contractions → ex: strychnine , quinine , ergot
    • Emmenagogues = increase Uterine bleeding → ex: estrogen , borax , Savin
  3. Drugs acting on nearby structures
    • GIT Irritants = increase Uterine contractions, eg- croton, castor
    • Genitourinary Irritants = increase Uterine contractions à ex: cantharides
  4. General Violence
    • Ex:- violent excessive,  jumping from height etc
  5. Local Violence
    • Syringing = injecting irritating fluid into Uterus à ex : soap water, formalin,  KMNO4.
    • Aspiration by syringe or a suction pump
    • Rupturing of membranes  = by sharp objects
    • Abortion stick = stick covered with some Irritant juice or stick itself of irritants plants (Calotropis , semi carpus anacardium )
    • Dilatation of cervix = Compressed sponge can be kept
    • Air insufflation = injecting Air inside Uterus
    • Electric current = electric current applied inside Uterus or vagina , increase Uterine contraction
    • Cupping = placental separation

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Vacuum Aspiration: A medical method for early abortion, not typically associated with criminal abortion in later stages.

 

Option B. Prostaglandins: Used medically to induce labor or abortion, but not typically associated with criminal methods at such a late stage.

 

Option C. Dilatation & Curettage (D&C): A medical procedure for early abortion or diagnostic purposes, not typically used in criminal abortions for later stages.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The use of an abortion stick is a method of criminal abortion, particularly in late stages of pregnancy, and is characterized by inserting a stick covered with irritant substances into the uterus to induce abortion.

questions.text: A 10-month-old child undergoes treatment for diarrhea with hypokalemia but the child does not respond to the treatment appropriately and on examination muscular weakness is noted. What is the most likely cause of treatment failure? (FMGE DEC 2021)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Hypomagnesemia

 

The most likely cause of treatment failure in a child with diarrhea and hypokalemia, who does not respond to potassium supplementation and exhibits muscular weakness, is hypomagnesemia. Severe diarrhea can cause significant gastrointestinal loss of both potassium and magnesium. Hypomagnesemia is a common cause of refractory hypokalemia, as magnesium plays a critical role in maintaining intracellular potassium levels. Without correcting the magnesium deficiency, it is difficult to restore normal potassium levels.

 

Mechanisms of Hypomagnesemia-Induced Hypokalemia:

 

  1. Increased Renal Potassium Loss: Hypomagnesemia impairs the function of the sodium-potassium pump and increases renal potassium excretion.
  2. Cellular Redistribution: Magnesium deficiency can lead to increased intracellular potassium loss, which exacerbates hypokalemia.

 

Management:

 

  • Correction of hypomagnesemia with magnesium supplements is essential to effectively treat hypokalemia in this context.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Hyponatremia: Symptoms are primarily neurological, including headache, nausea, vomiting, seizures, brainstem herniation, and coma due to cerebral edema. It does not typically cause refractory hypokalemia.

 

Option C. Hypermagnesemia: Clinical features are dose-dependent and include symptoms such as hypotension, bradycardia, and cardiac arrest at higher levels. It is not commonly associated with treatment-resistant hypokalemia.

 

Option D. Hypernatremia: This condition involves elevated sodium levels, which can cause neurological symptoms due to cellular dehydration, but it is not related to the failure of hypokalemia treatment.

 

Educational Objective:

 

In cases of hypokalemia that do not respond to potassium supplementation, always check and correct serum magnesium levels to ensure effective treatment.

questions.text: A newborn baby presents with irritability and cyanosis which subsides on crying. On examination, you are unable to pass a nasogastric tube and no mist formation is noted on the laryngeal mirror test. Which of the following is the best next step in management? (FMGE DEC 2021)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Oro pharyngeal airway

 

The clinical presentation of a newborn with irritability, cyanosis that subsides on crying, and the inability to pass a nasogastric tube strongly suggests bilateral choanal atresia. Choanal atresia is a congenital obstruction of the posterior nasal apertures (choanae), and the cyclical nature of cyanosis is due to the neonate's obligate nasal breathing. When crying, the baby breathes through the mouth, which relieves the cyanosis. The next best step in management is to secure an airway to ensure adequate ventilation.

 

  • Diagnosis of Choanal Atresia:
    • Injecting methylene blue dye into the nose and checking its transit to the pharynx.
    • Injecting a radio-opaque dye into the nose and taking a lateral radiograph.
    • Absence of air bubbles in the nasal discharge.
    • Failure to pass a catheter from the nose to the pharynx.
    • In the axial plane, CT scans can confirm the diagnosis.
       
  • Initial Management:
    • Use of an oropharyngeal airway (such as McGovern's nipple) to bypass the nasal obstruction and establish an airway.
    • This avoids the need for a tracheostomy in cases of bilateral atresia.
       
  • Definitive Treatment:
    • Surgical correction of the atresia, typically by a trans-palatal or trans-nasal technique, is usually performed by one and a half years of age.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Endotracheal intubation: Not the immediate next step unless there is severe respiratory distress unrelieved by simpler measures.

 

Option C. Oxygen inhalation: May be used to improve oxygenation but does not address the underlying obstruction.

 

Option D. Epinephrine nebulization: Used for croup or bronchiolitis but not indicated for choanal atresia.

 

Educational Objective:

 

In a newborn presenting with cyanosis that subsides on crying and an inability to pass a nasogastric tube, suspect bilateral choanal atresia and use an oropharyngeal airway as the initial management step.

questions.text: A worried mother brought her 6-year-old unimmunized child to the ER with complaints of fever, cough, and shortness of breath.
