On examination, a pseudo membrane was noted over the tonsils which bleed on trying to remove and a bull-neck appearance of the neck. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis? (FMGE DEC 2021)
questions.solution:
Ans. C. Diphtheria

 

Based on the provided clinical history, the presence of a pseudo membrane and a bull-neck appearance strongly suggests a diagnosis of diphtheria. The diphtheritic membrane is firmly attached and may bleed when removed.

 

Causative organism – Corynebacterium diphtheriae

 

 

CLINICAL FEATURES

  • Children are affected more often
  • Oropharynx is commonly involved and the larynx and nasal cavity may also be affected.
  • In the oropharynx, a greyish white membrane forms over the tonsils and spreads to the soft palate and posterior pharyngeal wall. It is quite tenacious and causes bleeding when removed.
  • Cervical lymph nodes, particularly the jugulodigastric, become enlarged and tender, sometimes presenting a “bull-neck” appearance. Patient is ill and toxemic but fever seldom rises above 38 °C.

 

COMPLICATIONS

 

  • Exotoxin produced by C. diphtheriae is toxic to the heart and nerves. It causes myocarditis, cardiac arrhythmias and acute circulatory failure.
  • Neurological complications usually appear a few weeks after infection and include paralysis of soft palate, diaphragm and ocular muscles.
  • In the larynx, diphtheritic membrane may cause airway obstruction.

 

TREATMENT

 

  • Dose of antitoxin is based on the site involved and the duration and severity of disease. It is 20,000–40,000 units for diphtheria in less than 48 h, or when the membrane is confined to the tonsils only; and 80,000–120,000 units, if disease has lasted longer than 48 h, or the membrane is more extensive.
  • Antibiotics used are benzyl penicillin 600 mg 6 hourly for 7 days. Erythromycin is used in penicillin-sensitive individuals (500 mg 6 hourly orally).

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Infectious Mononucleosis: Typically presents with fever, sore throat, and swollen lymph nodes, but lacks the pseudo membrane and bull-neck appearance.

 

Option B. Tonsillitis: Inflammation of the tonsils, usually without the severe systemic symptoms seen in diphtheria.

 

Option D. Candidiasis: Can cause white patches in the mouth and throat but these are easily wiped away and not associated with systemic toxicity or the bull-neck appearance.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Diphtheria is a serious bacterial infection that requires immediate medical attention and treatment. The presence of a bleeding pseudo membrane and severe neck swelling in an unimmunized child is highly indicative of this condition, emphasizing the importance of vaccination and early intervention.

questions.text: Fat sugar baby is seen in:
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Kwashiorkor

 

Option B. Kwashiorkor: "Fat sugar baby" is a descriptive term for a child with kwashiorkor, a form of severe protein-energy malnutrition.

 

Other Options

 

Option A. Diabetes: Diabetes is a metabolic disorder characterized by elevated blood glucose levels and is not associated with the "fat sugar baby" appearance seen in kwashiorkor.

 

Option C. Marasmus: Marasmus is another form of severe malnutrition, but it is characterized by overall energy deficiency, leading to wasting of muscle and subcutaneous fat. It does not typically present with the edema and "fat sugar baby" appearance seen in kwashiorkor.

 

Option D. Hypothyroidism: Hypothyroidism is a condition caused by an underactive thyroid gland, and it does not typically present with the specific features associated with kwashiorkor.

 

Educational objective:

 

Kwashiorkor is characterized by edema (fluid retention), fatty liver, and the appearance of a swollen abdomen, giving the child a "potbelly" or "fat sugar baby" appearance. This condition often occurs when there is sufficient calorie intake, particularly from carbohydrates (sugar), but a deficiency of high-quality proteins.

 

Ref: Harper’s Illustrated Biochemistry 32nd edition Page no. 533

questions.text: Following complete ileal and partial jejunal resection, the patient is most likely to have: (FMGE DECEMBER 2021)
questions.solution:
Ans. B. Vitamin B12 deficiency

 

  • After a complete ileal and partial jejunal resection, the patient is at a significant risk of developing Vitamin B12 deficiency. Vitamin B12 absorption occurs in the terminal ileum, the site where the vitamin, bound to intrinsic factor (a glycoprotein secreted by gastric parietal cells), attaches to specific receptors. The resection of this part of the intestine disrupts the absorption process, leading to deficiency.
  • Intrinsic factor is crucial because it not only protects vitamin B12 from degradation in the stomach but also facilitates its absorption by binding to receptors in the ileum. Without an adequate ileal surface, the absorption of Vitamin B12 cannot occur efficiently, leading to deficiency which can cause various hematologic and neurological disorders.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Folic acid deficiency: Incorrect as folic acid is primarily absorbed in the jejunum, and while part of the jejunum is resected, sufficient surface area typically remains to absorb folate.

 

Option C. Gastric ulcer: Incorrect because gastric ulcers are not directly related to the resection of the ileum and part of the jejunum.

 

Option D. Constipation: Incorrect as constipation is generally not associated with ileal and jejunal resections; issues like diarrhea are more common due to rapid transit time and decreased absorptive surface.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Vitamin B12 deficiency is a likely complication following complete ileal and partial jejunal resection due to the disruption of its absorption site in the terminal ileum. This highlights the importance of monitoring and possibly supplementing Vitamin B12 in patients who have undergone such surgical procedures.

 

Major Sites of Absorption of Hematopoietic Factors:

 

  • Duodenum and upper jejunum: Iron
  • Jejunum: Folate
  • Terminal Ileum: Vitamin B12

questions.text: An intern observed that a patient was unresponsive, and an ECG which was performed urgently showed an arrhythmia as below. DC shock was delivered but the arrhythmia persisted and the patient is still unresponsive. What is the next best step in the management of this patient? (FMGE DEC 2021)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Continue CPR

 

After detecting ventricular fibrillation (VF) and delivering a DC shock, continue CPR for at least 2 minutes before rechecking the rhythm. Avoid the immediate temptation to reassess the rhythm right after the shock. After 2 minutes of CPR, check the rhythm again. If it remains shockable (e.g., VF or VT), administer another shock. If the rhythm is non-shockable, continue CPR for another 2 minutes. Repeat this process as necessary, depending on the rhythm assessment.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Synchronised cardioversion: This is used for treating hemodynamically unstable tachyarrhythmias with a pulse, not for cardiac arrest.

 

Option C. Deliver another DC shock: This can be considered, but only after continuing CPR for a specific period and following advanced cardiac life support (ACLS) protocols.

 

Option D. 1 mg epinephrine IV: Epinephrine is administered after continuing CPR, usually every 3-5 minutes during cardiac arrest management according to ACLS guidelines, but the immediate next step after the initial shock is to continue CPR.

 

Educational Objective:

 

After delivering an initial DC shock in a cardiac arrest situation, the next step is to continue CPR to maintain circulation until further advanced interventions can be administered.

questions.text: A female patient presented with greenish vaginal discharge and pruritus. Clue cells were present. What is the drug of choice for this condition? (FMGE DECEMBER 2021)
questions.solution:
Ans. B. Metronidazole

 

  • The clinical presentation of greenish vaginal discharge, pruritus, and the presence of clue cells in a female patient strongly suggests a diagnosis of Bacterial Vaginosis (BV). Clue cells, which are vaginal epithelial cells covered with bacteria, are a hallmark finding in BV.

  • The drug of choice for treating Bacterial Vaginosis is Metronidazole. Alternative drug that can be used for this condition is clindamycin.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Doxycycline: This is an antibiotic used for various bacterial infections, but it's not the first-line treatment for BV.

 

Option C. Ceftriaxone: This antibiotic is commonly used for treating gonorrhea and other types of bacterial infections, but not specifically for BV.

 

Option D. Fluconazole: This is an antifungal medication used primarily to treat yeast infections, not bacterial infections like BV.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Metronidazole is the drug of choice for treating Bacterial Vaginosis due to its effectiveness against the anaerobic bacteria commonly associated with the condition. It can be administered either orally or as a topical gel or cream. In cases where metronidazole cannot be used, clindamycin is a suitable alternative. This knowledge is crucial for appropriate clinical management to relieve symptoms and prevent potential complications related to BV.

questions.text: A research study is set up to explore the impact of maternal smoking during pregnancy on neonatal birth weight. Researchers collect data on the smoking habits of expectant mothers during their antenatal visits and later record the birth weights of the newborns. Which epidemiological research design best describes this study? (FMGE DEC 2021)
questions.solution:
Ans. B. Prospective Cohort

 

The study employs a Prospective Cohort design. This method involves selecting participants based on a specific exposure—maternal smoking in this case—and following them over time to monitor the outcomes, which are the birth weights of the babies. This forward-looking approach is characterized by observing the effects of an exposure before the outcome has occurred, making it particularly effective for understanding causal relationships in health research.

 

Additional information

 

Cohort Study

 

  • Is a type of analytical (observational) study used for ‘hypothesis testing’
  • Is also known as - 
    • Prospective study
    • Forward looking study
    • Cause to effect study
    • Exposure to outcome study
    • Risk factor to disease study
    • Incidence study
    • Follow up study

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Retrospective Cohort: This approach uses historical data where both exposure and outcome have already occurred, which is not the case here.

 

Option C. Case control: This design starts with an outcome (like low birth weight) and looks backward to find correlations with exposures, which contrasts with the methodology used in this study.

 

Option D. Cross-sectional: Observes both exposure and outcome at a single point in time, which does not apply to this study as it involves monitoring changes over the course of the pregnancy.

 

Educational Objective:

questions.text: A patient was operated on for benign prostatic hyperplasia. On evaluation, incidentally, cancer of the Prostate was detected and on further workup was found to have metastasis. Which of the following drug is used for treatment? (FMGE DECEMEBR 2021)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Goserelin

 

The treatment for metastatic prostate cancer involves reducing testosterone levels because prostate cancer is often testosterone-dependent. This can be achieved through surgical or medical methods.

 

  • Goserelin is an LHRH agonist (Leuprolide is another example) used to achieve medical castration by reducing the production of testosterone. It is a preferred option when the patient is not willing for surgical orchidectomy.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Adriamycin:

 

  • Adriamycin (Doxorubicin) is a chemotherapy drug used for various cancers but is not the first-line treatment for metastatic prostate cancer.

 

Option C. Cisplatin:

 

  • Cisplatin is a chemotherapy drug used for several types of cancer, including testicular, bladder, and ovarian cancer, but it is not typically used for prostate cancer.

 

Option D. BCG:

 

  • Bacillus Calmette-Guérin (BCG) is used primarily in the treatment of superficial bladder cancer and is not used for prostate cancer.

 

Educational Objective:

 

For the treatment of metastatic prostate cancer, the preferred drug is an LHRH agonist like Goserelin to reduce testosterone levels, providing a medical alternative to surgical orchidectomy.

questions.text: Identify the stage of follicular development shown in the histological image. (FMGE DECEMBER 2021)
questions.solution:
Ans. B. Antral follicle

 

Antral Follicle (also known as Graafian Follicle) are characterized by the presence of a fluid-filled cavity called the antrum, which forms within the granulosa cell layer surrounding the oocyte.

 

The antrum contains follicular fluid and helps to facilitate the maturation of the oocyte.

 

Antral follicles are typically selected for ovulation, and the mature oocyte is released during the menstrual cycle.

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Primary Follicle: Primary follicles are a stage of ovarian follicle development that follows primordial follicles. Each primary follicle consists of a primary oocyte (an immature egg cell) surrounded by a single layer of granulosa cells. These granulosa cells are responsible for nourishing and supporting the oocyte as it matures. Primary follicles are more advanced than primordial follicles but are still relatively early in their development.

 

Option C. Primordial Follicle: Primordial follicles are the most primitive and earliest stage of ovarian follicle development. Each primordial follicle consists of a primary oocyte surrounded by a single layer of flattened, dormant granulosa cells. These follicles are present in the ovaries from birth and represent the reserve of immature eggs that a female has throughout her reproductive life. They remain quiescent until they are selected to undergo development into primary and antral follicles.

 

Option D. Corpus Luteum: The corpus luteum is not a stage of follicle development but rather a structure that forms after ovulation. When an ovulated mature follicle releases its egg, it undergoes a transformation into the corpus luteum. The corpus luteum is a temporary endocrine structure that secretes hormones, primarily progesterone, to prepare the uterine lining for potential pregnancy. If pregnancy does not occur, the corpus luteum regresses, leading to a drop in hormone levels and the start of a new menstrual cycle.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The antral follicle stage is a critical phase in the maturation of the oocyte, marked by the formation of the antrum, which facilitates hormonal and nutritional support for the developing oocyte.

choices.text: Small cell carcinoma of lung
Squamous cell carcinoma of lung

questions.text: A 55-year-old construction factory worker presents with dyspnoea. He has been working in this industry for the past 25 years. Which is the most specific malignancy that we can expect in this patient? (FMGE DEC 2021)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Malignant mesothelioma

 

Malignant mesothelioma is strongly associated with asbestos exposure, which is common among construction and industrial workers. This cancer affects the lining of the lungs (pleura) and is characterized by a long latency period between exposure and onset of symptoms.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Adenocarcinoma of lung: Common lung cancer but not specifically associated with asbestos exposure.

 

Option C. Small cell carcinoma of lung: Strongly associated with smoking but not specifically with asbestos.

 

Option D. Squamous cell carcinoma of lung: Also related to smoking and other factors, but not specifically to asbestos.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Malignant mesothelioma is highly specific to asbestos exposure.

questions.text: A 20-year-old male presented to emergency in comatose state after consuming some unknown fruit. Excessive sweating is evident and on general physical examination, there is bradycardia and his Blood Pressure is 80/60 mm Hg. Which of the following drugs is the antidote for the treatment of this patient? (FMGE DECEMBER 2021)
questions.solution:
Ans. B. Atropine

 

  • The clinical scenario of a patient presenting with increased secretions (sweating), hypotension, bradycardia and coma is suggestive of Organophosphorus poisoning.

  • Organophosphates causes irreversible inhibition of acetylcholinesterase enzyme which leads to raised Acetylcholine levels and so cholinergic side effects (DUMBELSS).

  • The cholinergic side effects include – 

    • Diarrhea

    • Urination

    • Miosis

    • Bradycardia, bronchospasm

    • Emesis

    • Lacrimation

    • Salivation

    • Sweating

 

  • The antidote for the Organophosphates poisoning is IV Atropine.

  • Atropine is repeated every 5 minutes until the signs of Atropinization are seen. These include mydriasis, decrease in secretions, tachycardia. The most common sign is mydriasis whereas the most reliable/specific sign is decreased secretions. Atropine can reverse all the symptoms except for muscle weakness.

  • Pralidoxime, a cholinesterase reactivator can also be used for treatment.

 

Other Options:


Option A: Neostigmine is a water soluble AChE inhibitor and is used for treatment of myasthenia gravis and cobra bite

 

Option C: Physostigmine is a lipid soluble AChE inhibitor used for glaucoma and atropine poisoning.

 

Option D: N-acetylcysteine is the antidote of choice for paracetamol (acetaminophen) poisoning

 

Educational Objective:

 

In cases of suspected organophosphate poisoning, prompt administration of atropine is critical for reversing life-threatening muscarinic symptoms. Monitoring and supportive care in an intensive care setting are also necessary to manage the patient's condition effectively.

questions.text: A child is brought to the pediatrician with short stature. On evaluation, growth hormone levels are found to be high and Insulin-like growth factor (IGF-1) levels are low. Which among the following could be the abnormality here? (FMGE DEC 2021)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) GH receptor anomaly

 

In case of GH deficiency, the levels of GH and the IGF -1 will be decreased, but in this case, the GH level is normal along with Decreased level of IGF -1 which results from the receptor resistance to GH, it is seen in case of Laron dwarfism.

 

Laron syndrome/dwarfism:

 

Cause:

 

A mutation in the growth hormone receptor gene that leads to an inability to respond to growth hormone (GH), resulting in low levels of IGF-1.

 

Symptoms:

 

  • Short stature
  • Delayed growth and puberty
  • High-pitched voice
  • Delayed dentition
  • Facial features characteristic of Laron syndrome (e.g., prominent forehead, saddle nose, and underdeveloped jaw)

 

Diagnosis:

 

  • Physical examination
  • Genetic testing to detect mutations in the growth hormone receptor gene
  • Blood tests to measure levels of growth hormone, IGF-1, and other related hormones

 

Treatment:

 

  • Recombinant human IGF-1 therapy to replace the missing IGF-1 hormone and stimulate growth
  • Treatment of associated health problems (e.g., hypothyroidism)
  • Psychological support to help cope with the psychosocial impact of the condition

 

Prognosis:

 

  • Laron dwarfism is a lifelong condition
  • With proper treatment, individuals with Laron syndrome can achieve a normal quality of life, but they will remain short in stature.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. GH deficiency: Both GH and IGF-1 levels would be low.

 

Option B. GHRH deficiency: This would result in low GH levels as well as low IGF-1 levels.

 

Option D. IGF-1 deficiency: IGF-1 levels would be low, but GH levels might be normal or elevated due to a lack of feedback inhibition.

 

Educational Objective:

 

A high growth hormone level and low IGF-1 level in a child with short stature indicate a growth hormone receptor anomaly, also known as Laron syndrome.

questions.text: In a child presenting with febrile seizures, which is the first-line drug used to control the seizures? (FMGE DEC 2021)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Midazolam

 

Febrile seizures occur in children between the ages of 6 months to 5 years, associated with high fever (>100.4°F), without any prior unprovoked seizures or underlying cerebral illnesses.

 

Initial management of febrile seizures involves administration of benzodiazepines like lorazepam, midazolam, or diazepam.

 

Hydration and antipyretics are essential in the treatment of febrile seizures.Intravenous lorazepam or midazolam is used to stop seizures during acute bouts. If febrile seizures last longer than five minutes, rectal diazepam is given as a rescue medication at home.

 

Prophylaxis:

 

  • Intermittent prophylaxis: Oral clobazam (1 mg/kg/day) for 3 days during the fever episode if there are 3 or more febrile seizures in 6 months or 4 or more seizures in a year.
  • Continuous prophylaxis: Sodium valproate and phenobarbitone may be administered in cases of recurrent atypical febrile seizures and failure of intermittent prophylaxis.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Sodium valproate: This is primarily used in the management of juvenile myoclonic epilepsy and absence seizures, not typically for acute control of febrile seizures.

 

Option B. Phenytoin: Generally used in managing generalized tonic-clonic seizures (GTCS) and is not the first choice for febrile seizures.

 

Option D. Phenobarbitone: The drug of choice for neonatal seizures, but not typically used as first-line treatment for febrile seizures in older children.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Midazolam is the first-line drug used to control febrile seizures in children due to its rapid onset and efficacy.

questions.text: A 12-year-old girl presents with severe headache, photophobia and high fever of 101°F. On examination, papilledema and nuchal rigidity was present. Kernig's and Brudzinski signs were positive. CS examination shows reduced glucose, increased protein, and increased leukocytes with the predominance of neutrophils. Gram staining of the CSF is shown below. What is the Causative organism? (FMGE DECEMBER 2021)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Neisseria meningitidis

 

History and physical examination findings are suggestive of bacterial meningitis. The given image shows intracellular gram-negative diplococci i.e., Neisseria meningitidis

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Haemophilus influenzae type B: This organism can cause bacterial meningitis, particularly in unvaccinated children, but it typically appears as small, pleomorphic gram-negative coccobacilli on Gram stain.

 

Option C. Streptococcus pneumonia: This is another common cause of bacterial meningitis and would appear as gram-positive lancet-shaped diplococci on Gram stain.

 

Option D. Listeria monocytogenes: This organism can cause meningitis, particularly in neonates, the elderly, and immunocompromised individuals, and appears as gram-positive bacilli on Gram stain

 

Educational Objective:

choices.text: Beta galacto cerebrosidase
Alpha gluco cerebrosidase

questions.text: Enzyme deficient in Gaucher’s disease:
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Beta glucocerebrosidase

 

Option B. Beta gluco cerebrosidase: Gaucher's disease is most common lysosomal storage disorder caused by a deficiency of the enzyme beta-glucocerebrosidase.

 

Other Options

 

Option A. Beta galactocerebrosidase: It is associated with Krabbe's disease, another lysosomal storage disorder.

 

Option C. Glucose-6-phosphatase: Glucose-6-phosphatase is associated with glycogen storage disorders, von Gierke’s disease.

 

Option D. Alpha Glucocerebrosidase: Enzyme deficient in Gaucher's disease is beta-glucocerebrosidase, not alpha-glucocerebrosidase.

 

Educational objective:

 

Beta-glucocerebrosidase enzyme is responsible for the breakdown of glucocerebroside, a glycolipid found in cell membranes. The deficiency leads to the accumulation of glucocerebroside in various tissues, particularly in macrophages (characteristic crumpled tissue paper appearance), causing organomegaly and other symptoms associated with the disease.

 

Ref: Harper’s Illustrated Biochemistry 32nd edition Page no. 245

questions.text: Identify the imaging modality and diagnosis. (FMGE DECEMBER 2021)
questions.solution:
Ans. C. MRI of Polycystic kidney disease

 

Explanation

 

  • Given image is MRI: Bone cortex will be hypointense (dark) while in a CT the bone cortex will appear hyperdense (white).
  • The image shows multiple large cysts in bilateral kidneys suggestive of Autosomal dominant Polycystic kidney disease (ADPKD)
  • Inheritance: Autosomal dominant trait
  • Genes: PKD1(chromosome 16) and PKD2 genes (chromosome 4).
  • Presentation: Adults in fourth or fifth decade
  • Associations: 
    • Liver, pancreas, ovarian and spleen cysts
    • Berry aneurysm
    • Colonic diverticulosis

 

Educational Objective:

 

MRI is a valuable imaging modality for diagnosing Polycystic Kidney Disease due to its detailed visualization of soft tissues and cystic structures within the kidneys.

choices.text: Infants born to an HbsAg positive mother

questions.text: Which of the following is an absolute contraindication for breastfeeding? (FMGE DEC 2021)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Classic galactosemia for the infant

 

Infant galactosemia is a metabolic disorder where the infant lacks the enzyme needed to metabolize galactose, a sugar present in milk. For infants with classic galactosemia, breastfeeding is absolutely contraindicated because consuming milk can lead to serious complications including liver damage, intellectual disability, and other severe symptoms.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Alcoholic Mother: While alcoholism in the mother is a serious concern due to potential fetal alcohol syndrome and other risks, it is not an absolute contraindication to breastfeeding. However, mothers who consume alcohol should be advised on the risks and encouraged to limit alcohol intake.

 

Option C. A mother with HIV infection: In the developed world, HIV infection in the mother is generally considered a contraindication to breastfeeding due to the risk of transmission of the virus to the infant through breast milk. However, in settings where safe alternatives to breast milk are not available, the benefits of breastfeeding may outweigh the risks.

 

Option D. Infants born to an HbsAg positive mother: Mothers who are HbsAg positive can still breastfeed their infants. Hepatitis B virus is not transmitted through breast milk, and with appropriate immunoprophylaxis (administration of hepatitis B vaccine and immunoglobulin to the infant), breastfeeding is considered safe.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Classic galactosemia in the infant is an absolute contraindication to breastfeeding due to the inability to metabolize galactose, leading to serious health complications.

choices.text: Ground glass opacification
Halo around nucleus

questions.text: A chest X-ray from a patient of Covid-19 would show: (FMGE DEC 2021)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Ground glass opacification  

 

Ground glass opacities at periphery (GGO) of lower lobes is characteristic X-ray finding of COVID-19.

 

These opacities represent areas of increased attenuation in the lungs with preserved bronchial and vascular markings, indicative of partial filling of air spaces, interstitial thickening, or partial collapse of alveoli. GGO is not exclusive to COVID-19 and can also be seen in other conditions such as interstitial lung disease.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Halo around nucleus: This description is not related to COVID-19 chest X-ray findings. It may refer to cytoplasmic features seen in histological examinations rather than imaging.

 

Option C. Cavitation: Cavitation refers to the formation of cavities within the lung tissue and is typically seen in conditions such as tuberculosis or necrotizing pneumonia. It is not a characteristic finding in COVID-19.

 

Option D. Sigma sign: The sigma sign is not a recognized radiographic feature in the context of COVID-19. It may be confused with other terms but is not relevant here.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Ground glass opacification (GGO) at the periphery of the lower lobes is a characteristic finding on chest X-rays of patients with COVID-19.

questions.text: A 20-year-old male presented with a 1-week history of yellow skin and sclerae but is otherwise asymptomatic. He gives a history of viral infection for 10 days which resolved 2 days back. There is a history of a similar episode of icterus 2 years back for a period of 2 weeks. The current serum bilirubin is 2.4 mg/ dL, unconjugated bilirubin 2.1mg/dl, conjugated bilirubin is 0.3mg/dl, Serum AST and ALT levels are normal. What is the likely diagnosis? (FMGE DEC 2021)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Gilbert syndrome

 

Gilbert syndrome is characterized by intermittent jaundice with elevated unconjugated bilirubin levels and normal liver enzyme levels, often triggered by stress or illness. The patient’s history of similar episodes and current lab findings fit the profile of Gilbert syndrome.

 

Gilbert syndrome is a benign condition characterized by mild elevations in unconjugated bilirubin, often occurring during periods of stress such as dehydration, fasting, surgery, or viral illness. Patients are typically asymptomatic, and the bilirubin elevation is usually transient and accompanied by normal liver enzymes and imaging. Viral markers are negative, and the condition is often discovered incidentally. The bilirubin levels do not exceed 3 milligrams per deciliter. Gilbert syndrome requires no treatment and is a common, harmless condition.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Dubin-Johnson syndrome: Typically shows conjugated hyperbilirubinemia.

 

Option B. Criggler-Najar type 1 syndrome: Severe form with persistent high unconjugated bilirubin levels from birth. the enzyme UDP-glucuronosyltransferase (UGT1A1) activity is essentially zero. This complete lack of enzyme activity leads to severe jaundice from birth. Liver transplantation is often necessary for survival, as the condition is fatal if untreated.

 

Option D. Rotor Syndrome: Similar to Dubin-Johnson but without liver pigmentation.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Gilbert syndrome causes intermittent jaundice with unconjugated hyperbilirubinemia and normal liver enzymes.

questions.text: A child who was fed only on rice water presents with a swollen belly and dull face. His appearance is of a 'fat sugar baby' and is found to have low serum protein and low albumin. What is the probable diagnosis? (FMGE DEC 2021)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Kwashiorkor

 

Kwashiorkor is characterised by a bloated abdomen, a lifeless face, the look of a "fat sugar baby," low blood albumin levels, and low protein levels.

 

The clinical case and the image of malnourished toddler with an enlarged abdomen suggests the diagnosis of Kwashiorkor, It is due to less protein.

 

  • Kwashiorkor is an acute severe malnutrition (SAM) that is characterised by edema and apathy.
  • Infants and young children are typically affected, most frequently between the time of weaning and age 5.
  • Children with kwashiorkor have faces that resemble the moon.
  • Edema is most likely to start in the feet and lower legs before spreading to the entire body. Hepatomegaly, fatty infiltration, and dilated bowel loops can all cause abdominal distension.
  • the skin changes include flaky paint dermatosis, often known as crazy paving, which is characterised by dark, peeling, cracked patches with pale skin beneath.
  • The hair is fine, thin, brittle, and readily pulled out. It might stop curling. Children with dark hair may experience a reddish or light hair change. The "flag sign" is made up of bands of hair that alternate between being light and being normal in colour.
  • Children frequently refuse to eat and are unhappy and apathetic.
  • Both growth retardation and muscular atrophy are clearly seen.

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Marasmus: Characterized by severe calorie deficiency leading to significant weight loss and muscle wasting without edema. Children appear emaciated and wasted but do not have the swollen belly typical of Kwashiorkor.

 

Option C. Indian Childhood Cirrhosis: A form of liver disease affecting Indian children, characterized by jaundice, hepatomegaly, and ascites, not typically presenting with the swollen belly and protein deficiency seen in Kwashiorkor.

 

Option D. Kawasaki Disease: A condition affecting blood vessels, characterized by fever, rash, and inflammation of the coronary arteries, not associated with protein deficiency or the typical presentation of Kwashiorkor.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Kwashiorkor is primarily due to a severe deficiency in protein intake, leading to edema, hepatomegaly, and characteristic skin and hair changes, with low serum protein and albumin levels.

questions.text: Which serotype of HPV is responsible for Ca Cervix? (FMGE DEC 2021)
questions.solution:
Ans. D) 16, 18, 31, 33

 

Explanation:

 

HPV - 16, 18, 31, 33, 35, 39, 45, 52, 56, 58, 59, 68 are associated with Ca Cervix.

 

Human Papilloma Virus (DNA Virus):

 

  • ﻿The most common serotype of HPV responsible for Ca. Cervix: HPV-16
  • ﻿﻿The most malignant serotype of HPV for Ca Cervix: HPV-18
  • ﻿﻿HPV serotype most specific for Ca. Cervix is HPV-18.
  • ﻿﻿The most common serotype of HPV associated with Squamous Cell Carcinoma is HPV-16
  • ﻿﻿The most common serotype of HPV associated with Adenocarcinoma is HPV-18
  • Low risk HPV responsible for genital warts, papilloma : 6, 11

 

Educational Objective:

 

Human Papilloma Virus (HPV) serotypes 16, 18, 31, and 33 are commonly associated with cervical cancer, with HPV-16 being the most common and HPV-18 being the most malignant serotype.

 

Ref: Dutta’s textbook of Gynecology 6th edition pg 323, Williams textbook of gynecology 3rd edition pg 627

questions.text: In which of the following is the Normal level of ALP seen? (FMGE DEC 2021)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Osteoporosis

 

Osteoporosis presents with Codfish vertebrae (biconcave vertebrae)

 

Diagnosis is: Bone mineral density by DEXA SCAN.

 

T score: Normal is 0 to -1; If <-2.5 then it is osteoporosis.

 

Osteoporosis with fracture is referred as - severe osteoporosis.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Paget’s disease: Paget’s disease of bone is characterized by increased bone remodeling and typically presents with elevated ALP levels. It is known for its radiographic finding of "cotton wool spots" and increased hat size.

 

Option C. Multiple myeloma: Multiple myeloma can present with normal or elevated ALP levels. It is characterized by features such as punched out lesions on the skull, hypercalcemia, renal insufficiency, anemia, and bone lesions (CRAB features). However, normal ALP levels are seen in the absence of bone involvement.

 

Option D. VitB1 deficiency: Vitamin B1 (thiamine) deficiency is not associated with changes in ALP levels. It primarily affects the nervous and cardiovascular systems, causing conditions like beriberi and Wernicke-Korsakoff syndrome.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Osteoporosis typically presents with normal alkaline phosphatase (ALP) levels and is diagnosed by measuring bone mineral density using a DEXA scan.

questions.text:
A 40-year-old female patient came to OPD with features of anemia. She had undergone subtotal gastrectomy few months back. General examination showed the following changes in the tongue as shown in the image.(FMGE DECEMBER 2021)

 

 

Which of the following vitamin is responsible for this?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Vitamin B12

 

The fissured tongue, also known as a scrotal tongue or lingua plicata, is a characteristic finding associated with vitamin B12 (cobalamin) deficiency.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Vitamin A deficiency is more commonly associated with night blindness and other ocular manifestations.

 

Option C. Vitamin C deficiency can cause scurvy, but the characteristic oral finding in scurvy is gingival hyperplasia or bleeding gums, not a fissured tongue.

 

Option D. Vitamin B2, also known as riboflavin, deficiency is not commonly associated with a fissured tongue. Riboflavin deficiency can manifest with symptoms such as sore throat, redness, and swelling of the lining of the mouth and throat.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Subtotal gastrectomy can lead to malabsorption of vitamin B12, as the stomach produces intrinsic factor necessary for its absorption in the ileum. Vitamin B12 deficiency can result in megaloblastic anemia and various neurological symptoms. One of the characteristic features of this condition is the fissured tongue aka scrotal tongue or lingua plicata.

 

Ref: Harper’s Illustrated Biochemistry 32nd edition Page no. 544

questions.text: A 50-year-old man with a 5-year history of type 2 diabetes is seeking advice on choosing foods that minimally impact his blood sugar levels. Which of the following foods has the lowest glycemic index, making it the best option for him? (FMGE DEC 2021)
questions.solution:
Ans. C. Sweet corn

 

Sweet corn has the lowest glycemic index among the options listed, making it a suitable choice for individuals with diabetes looking to manage blood sugar levels effectively.

 

Glycemic response (GR) of a food is a measure of that food’s ability to raise blood sugar

 

Glycemic index implies value assigned to each food item on how much after consumption, can increase the blood sugar levels.

 

Watermelon – 73

 

Papaya – 60

 

Sweet corn – 53

 

Potato – 65

 

Educational Objective:

 

Glycemic index scale is 0 to 100 when using glucose as the standard.

 

  • Low Glycemic index: ≤ 55 - Most fruits and vegetables (EXCEPT potato/watermelon/sweet potato), Whole grains, Beans, Pasta, Lentils.  
  • Medium Glycemic index: 56-69 -  Sucrose, Basmati rice, Brown rice
  • High Glycemic index: ≥ 70 - Corn flakes, White bread, syrup foods, jasmine rice.

questions.text: Menke’s kink hair disease is due to: (FMGE DECEMBER 2021)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Copper deficiency

 

Copper Deficiency: Menkes disease is caused by a genetic defect that leads to a deficiency in copper. The disease is characterized by a defect in copper transport, leading to low levels of copper in the liver and brain, and abnormally high levels in the kidney and intestinal lining. This copper imbalance leads to numerous developmental issues, including characteristic kinky hair, growth failure, and neurological problems.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. P53 defect: P53 is a tumor suppressor gene, and mutations in this gene are more commonly linked to various cancers.

 

Option B. Copper excess: Wilson’s disease is characterized by copper excess. The genetic mutation in this disease affects the ATP7B gene, which plays a role in copper transport.

 

Option D. Zinc deficiency: Zinc plays a crucial role in various physiological processes, including immune function, wound healing, and maintenance of skin and hair The symptoms of Zn def include dermatitis, loss of appetite, diarrhea, alopecia, and delayed wound healing.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Menkes disease, also known as Menkes syndrome, is a genetic disorder caused by impaired copper absorption and transport due to defect in ATP7A gene, resulting in copper deficiency.

 

Menke’s kinky hair syndrome- Clinical features

 

  • Grey depigmented hair: Tyrosinase (an oxidase) is affected as oxidases require Cu. Tyrosinase is required for synthesis of Melanin. so, melanin synthesis is decreased causing grey hair.
  • Brittle kinky hair: As lysyl oxidase affected, so defective and weak collagen synthesis
  • Decreased Cu in blood and urine
  • Premature birth
  • Hypotonia
  • Growth retardation
  • Mental retardation

 

Ref: Harper’s Illustrated Biochemistry 32nd edition Page no. 603

questions.text: Lucid Interval is seen in? (FMGE DECEMEBR 2021)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Extradural hematoma

 

Lucid interval refers to a period of consciousness that occurs between two periods of unconsciousness. This phenomenon is most commonly associated with Extradural Hemorrhage (EDH). In EDH, a traumatic injury causes bleeding between the skull and dura mater, usually from an arterial source like the Middle Meningeal Artery. This condition has a rapid onset, and patients often experience a transient loss of consciousness, followed by a lucid interval, and then a subsequent deterioration as the hematoma expands and increases intracranial pressure.

 

  • Origin: Arterial (Middle Meningeal Artery)
  • Features: Rapid onset, lucid interval seen
  • Radiological Findings: Lens-shaped, biconvex hyperdensity on CT scan that does not cross suture lines

 

Other options:

 

  • Option B. Subdural hematoma:
    • Subdural Hematoma (SDH) involves bleeding between the dura mater and arachnoid mater, typically from venous sources such as the emissary veins. SDH usually presents with a more gradual onset of symptoms and does not typically feature a lucid interval.
    • Radiological Findings: Crescent-shaped hyperdensity on CT scan that crosses suture lines.
  • Option C. Subarachnoid hemorrhage:
    • Subarachnoid Hemorrhage (SAH) occurs due to bleeding into the subarachnoid space, often from a ruptured aneurysm. The classic presentation is a sudden, severe headache described as "the worst headache of my life." There is no lucid interval associated with SAH.
    • Radiological Findings: Intraventricular and subarachnoid space hyperdensities on CT scan.
  • Option D. Scalp hematoma:
    • Scalp hematomas are collections of blood within the layers of the scalp due to trauma. These do not involve intracranial bleeding and do not present with a lucid interval. They are generally localized and less severe.
    • Radiological Findings: Localized soft tissue swelling without intracranial involvement.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Lucid interval is a key clinical feature of Extradural Hematoma, characterized by a transient period of consciousness following initial unconsciousness due to traumatic arterial bleeding between the skull and dura mater.

questions.text: Which of the following breast cancer has the best prognosis? (FMGE DEC 2021)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Luminal A

 

BRCA 1/2 mutations

 

Germline BRCA1 and BRCA2 are low frequency mutations in luminal A breast cancer (4%), but loss of BRCA1 protein over all subtypes of breast cancer, particularly TNBC, is considerably more common (30%). Approximately 30% of breast cancers contain loss-of-function mutations in BRCA1 through multiple mechanisms. BRCA1/2 proteins are key regulators of DNA repair via homologous recombination. Defects in this repair pathway can result in genome instability, facilitating the accumulation of large numbers of genomic alterations that promote cancer development and progression. Defects in DNA repair pathways also make the cancer cells more susceptible to further DNA damaging treatments (e.g., platinum, temzolomide, and radiation)

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. p53: p53 is a tumor suppressor gene, and mutations in p53 are associated with various cancers, including more aggressive forms of breast cancer. It is not a subtype but rather a genetic marker indicating poorer prognosis.

 

Option C. HER2+: HER2-positive breast cancer involves the overexpression or amplification of the HER2 gene. While targeted therapies like trastuzumab have improved outcomes, HER2-positive cancers are generally more aggressive and have a worse prognosis compared to Luminal A subtype.

 

Option D. Luminal B: Luminal B breast cancer is characterized by being ER positive and/or PR positive, but can be either HER2 negative with a high Ki67 index (high defined as ≥ 14%) or HER2 positive. Luminal B cancers have a worse prognosis than Luminal A due to higher proliferation rates and potential HER2 positivity.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Luminal A breast cancer subtype, characterized by ER/PR positivity, HER2 negativity, and low Ki67 index, has the best prognosis among breast cancer subtypes.

choices.text: Direct inguinal hernia
Indirect inguinal hernia

questions.text: A patient presents with herniation of intestinal loop which passes along the spermatic cord and reaches till scrotum. Identify the pathology. (FMGE DECEMEBR 2021)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Indirect inguinal hernia

 

An indirect inguinal hernia occurs when a hernia protrudes through the deep inguinal ring, travels through the inguinal canal along with the spermatic cord, and exits through the superficial inguinal ring. This type of hernia is more likely to descend into the scrotum, which aligns with the presentation described in the question.

 

  • Indirect Inguinal Hernia:
    • Pathway: Protrudes through the deep inguinal ring, travels along the inguinal canal with the spermatic cord, and can exit through the superficial inguinal ring.
    • Location: Lateral to the inferior epigastric artery.
    • Also Known As: Lateral hernia.
  • Boundaries of Hesselbach's Triangle (for Direct Inguinal Hernia):
    • Laterally: Inferior epigastric artery.
    • Medially: Lateral border of rectus abdominis muscle.
    • Inferiorly: Inguinal ligament.

 

Other Options:

 

  • Option A. Femoral hernia:
    • Occurs below the inguinal ligament through the femoral canal and typically presents as a bulge in the upper thigh or groin. It does not follow the pathway described and does not extend into the scrotum.
  • Option B. Direct inguinal hernia:
    • Occurs directly through the posterior wall of the inguinal canal within Hesselbach's triangle. It is typically medial to the inferior epigastric artery and does not usually descend into the scrotum.
  • Option D. Paraumbilical hernia:
    • Occurs near the umbilicus and involves herniation of the abdominal contents near the belly button. It does not follow the inguinal canal and does not extend into the scrotum.

 

Educational Objective:

 

An indirect inguinal hernia is characterized by herniation through the deep inguinal ring, traveling along the inguinal canal with the spermatic cord, and potentially extending into the scrotum. This type of hernia is lateral to the inferior epigastric artery and distinct from other types of hernias based on its pathway and location.

questions.text: A chronic alcoholic present with visual hallucinations and disorientation two days after the last alcohol intake. What is the likely diagnosis?(FMGE DECEMBER 2021)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Alcohol withdrawal delirium

 

The patient's presentation of visual hallucinations and disorientation two days after the cessation of alcohol intake is indicative of alcohol withdrawal delirium (often called "delirium tremens" or DTs).

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Alcohol withdrawal seizures: Typically occur within 24-48 hours after the last drink and are characterized by generalized tonic-clonic seizures.

 

Option C. Alcoholic hallucination: While it can cause hallucinations, it usually does not present with the marked confusion or disorientation seen in DTs.

 

Option D. Dementia: Chronic alcoholism can lead to dementia. However, it would not typically present acutely after cessation of alcohol.

 

Educational Objective: 

 

Alcohol withdrawal delirium (DTs) typically presents 48-72 hours after the last drink and is characterized by disturbances of consciousness, disorientation to time, place, and person, hallucinations (especially visual), agitation, coarse tremors and autonomic hyperactivity. Risk factors include surgery, infections or other medical conditions. It is a medical emergency requiring prompt intervention. Treatment includes intravenous lorazepam or diazepam with thiamine supplementation to prevent Wernicke encephalopathy.

 

Reference: Kaplan & Sadock’s Synopsis of Psychiatry, 12th edition, Page No 276-277

questions.text: Identify the test shown in the image below: (FMGE DECEMBER 2021)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Teichman test

 

As the crystals are seen under the microscope, this indicates that it is a microchemical test.

 

MICROCHEMICAL TESTS FOR BLOOD STAINS (Both are confirmatory tests)

 

Hemin (Teichmann’s) test:

 

  • Reagent: NaCl + acetic acid
  • Brownish-black rhombic crystals of hematin chloride as shown below

 

 

Note – other Microchemical tests for Blood:

 

Hemochromogen (Takayama) test:

 

  • Reagent: NaOH + pyridine + glucose
  • Pink feathery crystals of hemochromogen (reduced alkaline hematin), as shown below

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Takayama’s test: Produces pink feathery crystals.

 

Option C. Barberio’s test: Produces yellow needle-shaped crystals for semen detection.

 

Option D. Benzidine test: Not a microchemical test and does not involve crystallization.

 

Educational Objective

 

The brownish-black rhombic crystals observed under the microscope are characteristic of the Teichmann test, which is a confirmatory test for the presence of blood stains.

 

Additional Information

 

MICROCHEMICAL TESTS FOR SEMEN (Both are presumptive tests)

 

1) Florence test

 

  • Reagent: KI + I2 + H2O
  • Component of semen detected: Coline (secreted from seminal vesicles)
  • Shape of crystals: Dark Brown rhombic crystals of choline iodide (resemble hemin but larger than hemin crystals) as shown below

 

 

2) Barberio’s test

 

  • Reagent: Picric Acid
  • Component of semen detected: Spermine (secreted from prostate gland)
  • Shape of crystals: Yellow needle shaped crystals of spermine picrate as shown below.

questions.text: What is the axis of this ECG? (FMGE DEC 2021)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Right

 

The axis of an ECG is determined by analyzing the QRS complex in the frontal plane leads. Right axis deviation (RAD) occurs when the electrical conduction of the heart is deviated to the right side, which is typically indicated by the following findings:

 

  • Lead I shows a negative QRS complex.
  • Lead aVF shows a positive QRS complex.
  • The overall axis is more positive than +90 degrees.

 

Right axis deviation can occur in various clinical conditions such as right ventricular hypertrophy, chronic obstructive pulmonary disease (COPD), pulmonary embolism, or can be a normal variant in some individuals.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Left: Left axis deviation would show a positive QRS complex in lead I and a negative QRS complex in lead aVF, with an axis between -30 and -90 degrees.

 

Option C. Northwest: This term refers to an extreme right axis deviation (no man's land), which is between -90 and -180 degrees, and is very rare.

 

Option D. Normal: A normal axis ranges from -30 to +90 degrees and would show positive QRS complexes in both leads I and II.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Right axis deviation on an ECG is characterized by a negative QRS complex in lead I and a positive QRS complex in lead aVF, indicating an axis of more than +90 degrees​​.

questions.text: What is the mechanism of oxygen delivery of the following device? (FMGE DEC 2021)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Venturi effect

 

Venturi Mask:

 

  • Definition: The image shows a Venturi mask, an oxygen delivery device that utilizes the Venturi effect.
  • Mechanism:

 

The Venturi effect occurs when fluid (in this case, air) is passed through a constricted section of a pipe, increasing its velocity and causing a decrease in lateral pressure. This drop in pressure entrains the surrounding air into the main flow. The Venturi mask uses this principle to mix ambient air with pure oxygen, providing a fixed and predetermined concentration of oxygen to the patient.

 

  • Application:
    • The mask has different colored valves, each corresponding to a specific oxygen concentration.
    • The Venturi effect ensures that each valve delivers a consistent mix of room air and oxygen, regardless of the patient's breathing rate.
    • This precise oxygen delivery is crucial for patients who require a specific FiO2 (fraction of inspired oxygen).

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Photoelectric Effect:

  • Definition: The photoelectric effect involves the emission of electrons from a material when it is exposed to light.
  • Usage: It has no application in the mechanism of oxygen delivery.

 

Option B. Bernoulli Effect:

  • Definition: The Bernoulli effect states that an increase in the speed of a fluid occurs simultaneously with a decrease in pressure or potential energy.
  • Usage: Although related to fluid dynamics, it does not specifically describe the mechanism used in the Venturi mask.

 

Option D. Boyle's Law:

  • Definition: Boyle's law describes the relationship between the pressure and volume of a gas at constant temperature (P1V1 = P2V2).
  • Usage: It is a fundamental gas law but does not directly relate to the mechanism of oxygen delivery in a Venturi mask.

 

 

Educational Objective:

 

The Venturi mask utilizes the Venturi effect to deliver a precise and consistent concentration of oxygen by mixing ambient air with pure oxygen. This principle ensures the patient receives the required FiO2, crucial for managing specific respiratory conditions.

questions.text: A nutritionist aims to visually demonstrate the nutritional composition of a family's daily diet, highlighting the proportions of carbohydrates, proteins, fats, and vitamins from their meals. Which visual representation tool would best help the family understand the relative contributions of different nutrients in their diet? (FMGE DEC 2021)
questions.solution:
Ans. C. Pie chart

 

The nutritious value of various food items, in terms of carbohydrates, proteins, fats, micronutrients etc. can be pictorially depicted using the pie chart.

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Histogram: More suitable for showing frequency distributions of continuous data, not for the proportional breakdown of categories.

 

Option B. Bar chart: Useful for comparing quantities across different groups but does not emphasize the holistic proportionality of components within a single category as effectively as a pie chart.

 

Option D. Pictogram: While visually engaging, pictograms might not accurately convey precise proportions of nutrients as effectively as a pie chart.

 

Educational Objective:

 

PIE CHART

 

  • Qualitative data diagram
  • Each qualitative category is represented as pie of a circle
  • Each category drawn as % of 360 degrees
  • Categories are mutually-exclusive and total of all categories is 100%.

questions.text: A 65-year male presented with a mass in the left lumbar region which was ballotable. He was having abdominal discomfort and on investigations, he was found to have a mass of 7 x 5 x 3cm which was confined within the kidney and was diagnosed as renal cell carcinoma. What would be the treatment for this patient? (FMGE DECEMEBR 2021)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Radical nephrectomy

 

Given that the lesion is 7 x 5 x 3 cm and confined within the kidney, the preferred treatment is radical nephrectomy. This procedure involves the surgical removal of the entire kidney, the attached adrenal gland, surrounding fatty tissue, and sometimes nearby lymph nodes. It is the treatment of choice for larger tumors or those that are not suitable for partial nephrectomy due to their size, location, or extent.

 

  • Radical nephrectomy ensures complete removal of the tumor and is recommended for tumors that are larger than those typically treated with partial nephrectomy. In this patient’s case, the tumor size and confinement within the kidney make radical nephrectomy the most appropriate treatment.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Partial nephrectomy:

 

  • This involves removal of only the tumor and a margin of surrounding healthy tissue, sparing the rest of the kidney. It is typically done for smaller tumors (often those less than 7 cm) that are located in a way that makes this procedure feasible. It preserves renal function and is preferable when possible. However, for a tumor of 7 x 5 x 3 cm, radical nephrectomy is more appropriate.

 

Option C. Radiotherapy:

 

  • RCC is generally considered radioresistant, meaning it does not respond well to radiation therapy. While radiation can be used to treat metastatic sites or for symptom relief in advanced disease, it is not typically the primary treatment for localized RCC.

 

Option D. Chemotherapy:

 

  • RCC is relatively resistant to chemotherapy. While some patients might benefit from targeted therapies and immunotherapy, traditional chemotherapy is not the primary mode of treatment for localized disease. Radical nephrectomy remains the preferred treatment for localized RCC confined within the kidney.

 

Educational Objective:

 

For a renal cell carcinoma confined within the kidney and of a size 7 x 5 x 3 cm, the treatment of choice is radical nephrectomy.

questions.text: A 27-year-old woman presented with malodorous discharge in the vagina which started a week earlier. On examination, the whiff test is positive, and the gram stain shows the presence of clue cells. This infection is commonly treated with which of the following? (FMGE DEC 2021)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Metronidazole

 

Explanation:

 

  • This is Bacterial vaginosis, which is diagnosed by Amsel’s criteria
    • Bacterial Vaginosis is diagnosed by Amsel’s criteria in which 3 out of 4 of these have to be present:
      1. Greyish white homogenous discharge
      2. Whiff Test 
      3. Presence of Clue cells
      4. Vaginal pH: Alkaline (> 4.5)
    • Treatment is Metronidazole (200mg TDS for 7 days) or metronidazole gel or clindamycin cream

 

Other options:

 

Option B. Nystatin pessary: It is an antifungal used in cases with candidial vaginitis as an alternative to azole group (clotrimazole, fluconazole) of antifungals.

 

Option D. Azithromycin and Option C. Tetracycline (Doxycycline) are useful in treating chlamydial infection which causes PID

 

Educational Objective:

 

Bacterial vaginosis, characterized by a positive whiff test and clue cells on a gram stain, is commonly treated with metronidazole.

 

Ref: Dutta’s textbook of Gynecology 6th edition pg 152, Williams textbook of Gynecology 3rd edition pg 61

questions.text: A 9 young boy was brought to hospital with complaints of few episodes of fast blinking and staring at something for around 20 seconds. EEG shows spike and wave pattern. Which of the following drug should be used for treatment? (FMGE DECEMBER 2021)
questions.solution:
Ans. B. Sodium valproate

 

  • Clinical features and the EEG showing spike and wave pattern are suggestive of Absence seizures.

  • DOC for absence seizures is Sodium Valproate. Another antiepileptic drug which can be also used for typical absence seizures is Ethosuximide.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Phenytoin and Option D. Carbamazepine: Both of these drugs are more commonly used for the treatment of partial and tonic-clonic seizures rather than absence seizures. Importantly, both Phenytoin and Carbamazepine can potentially exacerbate absence seizures, making them inappropriate choices for this type of epilepsy.

 

Option C. Diazepam: While Diazepam, a benzodiazepine, is effective in acute seizure management, particularly for stopping ongoing seizure activity (status epilepticus), it is not used as a long-term treatment option for absence seizures. Its use is limited due to the development of tolerance and sedative side effects.

 

Educational Objective:

 

For managing absence seizures, particularly in children, Sodium Valproate offers effective control and is a well-established first-line treatment. It's important for clinicians to differentiate between types of seizures when prescribing antiepileptic drugs to ensure that the chosen medication will not exacerbate the condition.

questions.text: During a discussion among global health experts on assessing disease impact, a key metric is highlighted that combines the years lost due to premature mortality and the years lived with disability to provide a comprehensive measure of health loss in populations. Which metric best represents this holistic view of a disease's burden? (FMGE DEC 2021)
questions.solution:
Ans. A. DALY

 

DALY or Disability Adjusted Life Years = YLL+YLD =Years Lost to Life + Years Lived with Disability.

 

It tells us about the disease burden in the society.

 

Other Options:  

 

Option B. Sullivan Index is similar to HALE but applies at an individual level. It tells us about the number of years a person will spend in good health free from disease or disability.

 

Option C. HALE (Health Adjusted Life Expectancy) Life expectancy: DALY of all diseases. It is an indicator of the overall health status of the country.

 

Option D. QALY or Quality Adjusted Life Years:  Tells us about the number of quality years gained in life because of an intervention.

 

Educational Objective:

 

DALYs provide a comprehensive metric for quantifying the burden of diseases, considering both the quality and the quantity of life affected, which helps in understanding the true impact of diseases on society and guiding health policy and funding decisions.

questions.text: Which of the following drugs is used for treatment of Pregnancy Induced Hypertension?
questions.solution:
Ans. A. Alpha methyl dopa

 

Methyl dopa and labetalol are the preferred drugs for treatment of pregnancy induced hypertension (PIH)

 

  • ﻿﻿Drug of choice for hypertension in pregnancy: Labetalol

  • Drug of choice for hypertensive emergency in pregnancy: Labetalol

  • ﻿﻿Drugs like Labetalol, Clonidine, Alpha Methyl Dopa and Hydralazine are safe in pregnancy.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Lisinopril: It is an ACE-enzyme inhibitor which is used in management of hypertension, but it is contraindicated in pregnancy due to its potential teratogenic effects like Renal Agenesis & Oligohydramnios.

 

Option C. Hydralazine: It is a potassium channel opener which is an arteriodilator. It is used in management of angina and hypertensive emergencies. It is known to cause Coronary Steal Phenomenon. Although it is safe in pregnancy but it is used for hypertensive emergencies only.

 

Option D. Telmisartan: it is an angiotensin-receptor blocker (ARB). Its use in pregnancy is also contraindicated as it can cause Oligohydramnios.

 

﻿﻿Educational Objective:

 

For managing hypertension during pregnancy, Alpha Methyl dopa is considered a safe and effective first-line treatment. Its safety profile during pregnancy is well-documented compared to other antihypertensive agents that carry significant risks of fetal harm. This makes it a preferred choice in clinical practice to ensure both maternal and fetal well-being.

questions.text: The image below shows the cross-section of the trachea. Identify the structure marked? (FMGE DECEMBER 2021)
questions.solution:
Ans. A. Trachealis muscle

 

The structure marked in the image shows the trachealis muscle.

 

  • The trachealis muscle lies posterior to the trachea and anterior to the oesophagus. 
  • It bridges the gap between the free ends of C-shaped rings of cartilage at the posterior border of the trachea, adjacent to the oesophagus.
  • This completes the ring of cartilages of the trachea. 
  • The trachealis muscle also supports a thin cartilage on the inside of the trachea. 
  • It is the only smooth muscle present in the trachea.
  • Nerve supply: vagus and upper thoracic spinal nerve
  • Function: Constricts trachea.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Tracheal Cartilage: The trachea is supported by a series of 16-20 C-shaped rings made of hyaline cartilage. These rings encircle the anterior and lateral sides of the trachea. The cartilage rings provide structural support and prevent the trachea from collapsing during inhalation. The tracheal cartilage ensures that the trachea remains patent (open) for the passage of air. The C-shaped rings are open on the posterior side, allowing for flexibility during swallowing.

 

Option C. Submucosal Glands: Submucosal glands are specialized glands located beneath the mucous membrane lining of the trachea and other respiratory passages. These glands secrete mucus, which plays a crucial role in protecting and lubricating the airways. The mucus produced by submucosal glands traps dust, debris, and pathogens, preventing them from entering the lungs. Cilia on the surface of the respiratory epithelium move the mucus upward in a coordinated manner, a process known as mucociliary clearance, ultimately leading to the expulsion of foreign particles from the respiratory tract.

 

Option D. Perichondrium: The perichondrium is a connective tissue membrane that surrounds and nourishes cartilage. It consists of two layers: an outer fibrous layer and an inner cellular layer. In the trachea, the perichondrium surrounds the hyaline cartilage. It provides blood vessels and nutrients to the cartilage, aiding in the maintenance and repair of the cartilage tissue. It also serves as a protective layer for the cartilage.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The trachealis muscle, also known as the Tracheal muscle/ Tracheal ring. It is a smooth muscle that forms a continuous C-shaped ring in the posterior part of the trachea.

 

These muscle rings are incomplete, with a gap on the posterior side, bridged by fibrous tissue. The trachealis muscle's primary function is to control the diameter of the trachea.

 

The contraction of the trachealis muscle narrows the trachea, increasing airway resistance, and expiration. Relaxation of the muscle widens the trachea, reducing airway resistance and facilitating inspiration.

questions.text: Thermogenin is present in:
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Mitochondria

 

Option A. Thermogenin is a natural uncoupler present in the inner mitochondrial membrane of brown fat cells.

 

Other Options

 

Option B. Cytoplasm: Thermogenin is not present in the cytoplasm. It is specifically associated with the inner mitochondrial membrane.

 

Option C. Lysosomes: Lysosomes are cellular organelles involved in the degradation of cellular waste.

 

Option D. Peroxisomes: Peroxisomes are involved in various metabolic processes, including lipid metabolism and detoxification.

 

Educational objective:

 

Thermogenin is primarily found in brown adipose tissue and plays a crucial role in the generation of heat (non-shivering thermogenesis) by uncoupling oxidative phosphorylation from ATP production. Thermogenin acts as a proton ion channel and allows protons to re-enter the mitochondrial matrix without passing through ATP synthase, dissipating the proton motive force as heat.

 

Ref: Harper’s Illustrated Biochemistry 32nd edition Page no. 258

questions.text: The cell marked as A in the given histological section of thyroid gland secretes which hormone?  (FMGE DECEMBER 2021)
questions.solution:
Ans. B. Calcitonin

 

The structure marked A is the C-cells or the parafollicular cells of the thyroid gland and they secrete calcitonin.

 

Calcitonin is a hormone produced by the parafollicular or C cells in the thyroid gland. Calcitonin primarily regulates calcium and phosphate levels in the blood by reducing the release of calcium from bones. It has a minor role in calcium homeostasis and is involved in reducing blood calcium levels.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Thyroxine (T4): Thyroxine, often abbreviated as T4, is one of the primary hormones produced by the thyroid gland. It is synthesized and released into the bloodstream in response to stimulation by thyroid-stimulating hormone (TSH) from the pituitary gland. T4 is considered an inactive thyroid hormone. However, it serves as a precursor to the more active thyroid hormone, triiodothyronine (T3). T4 regulates the body's overall metabolic rate, affecting various functions, including heart rate, body temperature, and energy metabolism.

 

Option C. Parathormone (Parathyroid Hormone or PTH): Parathormone is not produced by the thyroid gland but by the parathyroid glands, which are small glands located adjacent to the thyroid gland. Parathormone acts to increase blood calcium levels by promoting the release of calcium from bones, increasing calcium absorption from the intestines, and decreasing calcium loss in urine.

 

Option D. Serotonin: Serotonin is not produced by the thyroid gland. It is a neurotransmitter primarily found in the central nervous system and the gastrointestinal tract. Serotonin is involved in regulating mood, appetite, sleep, and other neurological and physiological functions.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Thyroxine-The thyroid gland produces three hormones:

 

  • Triiodothyronine, also known as T3.
  • Tetraiodothyronine, also called thyroxine or T4
  • Parathyroid hormone (PTH)- also called parathormone or parathyrin, is a peptide hormone secreted by the parathyroid glands that regulates the serum calcium concentration through its effects on bone, kidney, and intestine

choices.text: Posterior Urethral valves
Hydronephrosis to compare abdominal and urinary bladder pressures
Benign prostatic hyperplasia

questions.text: Whitaker test is performed for: (FMGE DECEMEBR 2021)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Hydronephrosis to compare abdominal and urinary bladder pressures

 

The Whitaker test is a diagnostic procedure used to evaluate the severity of urinary tract obstruction, particularly at the pelviureteric junction (PUJ). This test is designed to compare pressures within the renal pelvis and the bladder to determine if there is a significant obstruction.

 

The procedure involves puncturing the kidney and infusing contrast percutaneously to measure the intrapelvic pressure. If the pressure rises significantly during the test, it indicates an obstruction at the PUJ, which can lead to hydronephrosis. Hydronephrosis is a condition characterized by the swelling of a kidney due to a build-up of urine, often caused by an obstruction in the urinary tract.

 

Other Options:

 

  • Option A. Posterior Urethral valves:
    • This condition involves obstructive membranes in the posterior male urethra, which can lead to urinary retention and damage to the kidneys and bladder. Diagnosis and treatment typically involve cystoscopy and valve ablation, not the Whitaker test.
  • Option C. Ureterocele:
    • A ureterocele is a cystic dilation of the lower end of the ureter that can cause obstruction. Diagnosis is typically made via ultrasound, voiding cystourethrogram (VCUG), or intravenous pyelogram (IVP). The Whitaker test is not typically used for this condition.
  • Option D. Benign prostatic hyperplasia:
    • This condition involves the enlargement of the prostate gland, which can obstruct urine flow from the bladder. Diagnosis and management often include digital rectal examination, PSA testing, and imaging studies like ultrasound or cystoscopy. The Whitaker test is not used for evaluating benign prostatic hyperplasia.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The Whitaker test is a pressure flow study used to measure the pressure difference between the kidney and the bladder, specifically to evaluate the severity of obstruction in cases of hydronephrosis, particularly at the pelviureteric junction (PUJ).

questions.text: Match the auscultatory areas of the heart from image given below?(FMGE DECEMBER 2021)
questions.solution:
Ans. B.1-Aortic, 2-Pulmonary, 3- Tricuspid, 4-Mitral

 

Explanation:

 

The image shows the auscultation areas of the heart and option B is correctly matched.

 

Auscultation sounds are primarily generated by the closing of heart valves and blood flow through the chambers. Let's discuss these auscultation areas in detail:

 

1. Aortic Area (Second Right Intercostal Space):

 

Location: This area is in the second right intercostal space, just to the right of the sternum (breastbone).

 

Sounds: The primary sound heard in the aortic area is the second heart sound (S2), which corresponds to the closing of the aortic valve. It is a high-pitched "dub" sound.

 

2. Pulmonary Area (Second Left Intercostal Space):

 

Location: This area is in the second left intercostal space, just to the left of the sternum.

 

Sounds: The primary sound heard in the pulmonary area is also the second heart sound (S2), which corresponds to the closing of the pulmonary valve. It is another high-pitched "dub" sound.

 

3. Tricuspid Area (Fourth Left Intercostal Space):

 

Location: The tricuspid area is in the fourth left intercostal space, along the lower left sternal border.

 

Sounds: The tricuspid area primarily allows for the auscultation of the first heart sound (S1), which corresponds to the closing of the tricuspid valve. S1 is a low-pitched "lub" sound. Additionally, some tricuspid regurgitation murmurs may be heard in this area.

 

4. Mitral Area (Fifth Left Intercostal Space, Midclavicular Line):

 

Location: The mitral area is in the fifth left intercostal space, along the midclavicular line (an imaginary line drawn vertically from the midpoint of the clavicle).

 

Sounds: The mitral area primarily allows for the auscultation of the first heart sound (S1), which corresponds to the closing of the mitral valve. S1 is a low-pitched "lub" sound. Additionally, some mitral regurgitation murmurs may be heard in this area.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Auscultation areas of the heart

questions.text: Which of the following drug is contraindicated in XDR tuberculosis in pregnancy? (FMGE DECEMBER 2021)
questions.solution:
Ans. A. Kanamycin

 

Kanamycin, an aminoglycoside antibiotic, is known to be teratogenic and can cause irreversible hearing loss in the fetus when used during pregnancy. Aminoglycosides cross the placental barrier and can affect the baby's developing ear structures, leading to sensorineural hearing loss. Due to these risks, Kanamycin is contraindicated in pregnant women being treated for tuberculosis, including those with extensively drug-resistant (XDR) TB.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Ethambutol: This drug is generally considered safer during pregnancy compared to aminoglycosides. Ethambutol can be used in pregnant women, if necessary, although monitoring for potential side effects like optic neuritis is recommended.

 

Option C. Pyrazinamide: While the safety of Pyrazinamide in pregnancy is not fully established, it is often used as part of the treatment regimen for TB during pregnancy under careful supervision, particularly when the benefits outweigh the potential risks.

 

Option D. Amoxicillin-clavulanic acid: This is a commonly used antibiotic for various bacterial infections and is generally considered safe in pregnancy. However, it is not typically used for treating tuberculosis but may be used for concurrent bacterial infections during TB treatment.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Aminoglycosides and injectable drugs like Streptomycin, Capreomycin, Kanamycin, Amikacin etc. are not used for treatment of TB In pregnancy. These are teratogenic drugs causing hearing loss in baby so C/I in pregnancy.

  • Fluoroquinolones likes Moxifloxacin are also avoided in pregnancy for most infections but can be used in XDR (Extensive drug resistant) TB in pregnancy.

questions.text:
A 22-year-old primigravida at 10 weeks gestation comes to the ER with nausea, vomiting, and abdominal pain. Nausea and vomiting began one day back and now the patient is unable to tolerate fluids. She complains of pain in the right upper quadrant which started a few hours back. On examination, her temperature is 100.2 F, the pulse is 118 bpm and her BP is 110/70 mm of Hg. She has swelling of her lower limbs up to the ankles bilaterally. Abdominal examination shows a gravid uterus corresponding to 10 weeks of gestation and tenderness in the right upper quadrant, with mild guarding and is diagnosed as acute appendicitis. What is the next step of management? (FMGE DEC 2021)

 

Complete blood count

 

  • ﻿﻿Hemoglobin: 11g/dL
  • ﻿﻿Leukocytes: 13,000 cells/uL
  • ﻿﻿Platelets: 150,000 cells/uL

 

Liver function tests

 

  • Aspartate transaminase (AST): 40U/L
  • ﻿﻿Alanine transaminase (ALT): 48U/L

 

Urinalysis

 

  • Protein: negative
  • ﻿﻿Pus cells: 1-2/HPF
  • ﻿﻿Bacteria: none

 

USG Abdomen:

 

Reveals a 7mm diameter, peristaltic, non-compressible, dilated, blind-ending structure arising from the base of the caecum:
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Do appendicectomy

 

Explanation:

 

  • Laparoscopic appendicectomy is the next stage of treatment at the earliest. It is possible to do a laparoscopic appendectomy before 28 weeks of pregnancy.
  • The most frequent surgical, non-gynecological cause of acute abdomen in pregnancy is acute appendicitis.
  • Whenever acute appendicitis is suspected, it is better to operate since perforation and peritonitis can result in significant maternal and fetal morbidity and mortality.
  • While performing laparoscopy, the position of trocars, type of entry, and rate of CO2 insufflation need to be adjusted due to the gravid uterus.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Wait till 2nd trimester: This is not recommended as delaying surgery can lead to complications such as perforation and peritonitis, which can significantly increase maternal and fetal morbidity and mortality.

 

Option C. Conservative management: Conservative management is not advisable in cases of suspected acute appendicitis during pregnancy due to the high risk of complications.

 

Option D. Reassurance: Reassurance is not appropriate in this scenario as acute appendicitis requires surgical intervention.

 

Educational Objective:

 

In pregnant women with suspected acute appendicitis, prompt surgical intervention, preferably a laparoscopic appendectomy, is recommended to avoid complications.

 

Ref: William’s textbook of obstetrics 24th edition pg 1079,

928, Duttas textbook of obstetrics 8th edition pg 355

questions.text:
A 61-year-old male presented to physician with fever, weight loss, fatigue and pallor.

 

CBC shows: Hb- 9mg/dl, TLC- 17000/mm3, Basophil -4%, Platelet count 1,60,000/cumm, myeloid blasts <11%.

 

What is the diagnosis? (FMGE DEC 2021)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) CML

 

Chronic myeloid leukemia:

 

  • Seen in elderly, with clinical features of massive splenomegaly, hepatosplenomegaly.
  • Pathogenesis: t (9;22) BCR ABL fusion transcript.
  • Lab diagnosis: Hb normal, Platelet ↑, Basophilia.
  • Myeloid blast concentration 10-19%.
  • Peripheral smear shows college girl appearance.
  • IOC: FISH

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. HCL (Hairy Cell Leukemia): HCL typically presents with pancytopenia and splenomegaly but not the specific blood findings seen in CML.

 

Option B. ALL (Acute Lymphoblastic Leukemia): ALL is characterized by a high percentage of lymphoblasts in the bone marrow and peripheral blood, along with symptoms like fever, fatigue, and pallor, but it is more common in children.

 

Option D. NHL (Non-Hodgkin Lymphoma): NHL usually presents with lymphadenopathy and systemic symptoms but not with the specific hematologic findings seen in CML.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Chronic Myeloid Leukemia (CML) is characterized by the presence of the Philadelphia chromosome t (9;22), leading to the BCR-ABL fusion gene, which can be diagnosed using FISH.

questions.text: A patient comes with a BP of 160/100 mmHg and left-sided facial paralysis and weakness for 8 hours. Her CT is shown below. What is the next step? (FMGE DEC 2021)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Observation and monitoring
