Option A. Klinefelter’s syndrome: Klinefelter’s syndrome is characterized by a male patient with tall stature, gynecomastia, and micropenis. It is not typically associated with Tetralogy of Fallot.

 

Option B. Edwards syndrome: Edwards syndrome (trisomy 18) is associated with physical abnormalities like rocker bottom feet and is not commonly associated with Tetralogy of Fallot.

 

Option D. Turner’s syndrome: Turner syndrome (45, X) is commonly associated with congenital heart defects such as bicuspid aortic valve and coarctation of the aorta, but not typically with Tetralogy of Fallot.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Tetralogy of Fallot is a congenital heart defect that is most commonly associated with Down syndrome (trisomy 21).

questions.text: What type of smell is produced by the decomposed body from the given image? (FMGE DECEMBER 2021)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Odorless

 

The picture given above is of a mummified body.

 

Mummification: When body is exposed to dry/hot climate, drying & dehydration of body results in mummification.

 

Time required for mummification:3-12 months

 

No specific smell/odorless.

 

Arsenic & Antimony favor mummification.

 

Adipocere/saponification has ammoniacal smell

 

Adipocere is formed in 3 days to 3 months under warm, moist climate conditions.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Ammoniacal: The smell associated with adipocere or saponification, which occurs in warm, moist climates.

 

Option C. Offensive: A general term for the foul odor produced during the decomposition process, not specific to mummification.

 

Option D. Garlicky: Not typically associated with mummified bodies.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Mummified bodies are generally odorless due to the drying and dehydration process that preserves the body and prevents the production of decomposition odors.

questions.text: A 78-year-old patient was urgently brought to the casualty department due to recurring episodes of severe breathlessness. The patient mentioned experiencing a fever and cough over the last three days. To investigate the underlying cause of the symptoms, laboratory tests were conducted, and the test report indicated the presence of target sequences for the RdRp gene, E gene, N gene, and ORF1ab. Which diagnostic test was most likely performed to obtain these results? (FMGE DECEMBER 2021)
questions.solution:
Ans. D) RT-PCR

 

The given clinical scenario, along with target sequences for RdRp, E gene, N gene and ORF1ab is suggestive of COVID-19. The gold standard for its diagnosis is the identification of viral genome targets in the respiratory tract materials by reverse transcriptase polymerase chain reaction (RT-PCR).

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. CLIA (Chemiluminescent Immunoassay): Used for detecting antibodies or antigens in blood samples but not for detecting viral RNA directly.

 

Option B. ELISA (Enzyme-Linked Immunosorbent Assay): Typically used for detecting antibodies or antigens in blood samples, not for direct viral RNA detection.

 

Option C. CBNAAT (Cartridge-Based Nucleic Acid Amplification Test): Used for detecting specific nucleic acids in pathogens like Mycobacterium tuberculosis but not commonly used for COVID-19 diagnosis.

 

Educational Objective:

 

RT-PCR is the gold standard diagnostic test for detecting COVID-19 by identifying specific genetic sequences of the SARS-CoV-2 virus in respiratory samples.

questions.text: What is the term used for excessive sexual desire in men?(FMGE DECEMBER 2021)
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Satyriasis

 

Satyriasis refers to excessive sexual desire in men.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Voyeurism: This is a paraphilic disorder where an individual derives sexual pleasure from observing unsuspecting people, usually strangers, who are naked, undressing, or engaging in sexual activities.

 

Option B. Sadism: This term refers to deriving pleasure from causing pain or humiliation to others.

 

Option C. Nymphomania: This is an older term, now considered outdated and stigmatizing, used to describe excessive sexual desire in women.

 

Educational Objective: 

 

Satyriasis is the term used to describe excessive sexual desire in men. It's the male counterpart to the term nymphomania in women.

 

Reference: Kaplan & Sadock’s Synopsis of Psychiatry, 11th edition, Page No 591.

questions.text: Identify the airway examination test given below? (FMGE DECEMBER 2021)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Mallampati grading

 

 

Mallampati grading

 

The image depicts the Mallampati grading system, which is used to predict the ease of intubation by assessing the visibility of oropharyngeal structures.

 

Mallampati grading:

 

  • Class I: Complete visualization of the soft palate, tonsillar pillars, and entire uvula.
  • Class II: Complete visualization of the soft palate and base of the uvula, but the tip of the uvula and tonsillar pillars are obscured.
  • Class III: Only the soft and hard palates are visible.
  • Class IV: Only the hard palate is visible.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. ASA scoring: The ASA (American Society of Anesthesiologists) Physical Status Classification System assesses a patient's pre-anesthetic medical comorbidities and ranges from ASA I (healthy patient) to ASA VI (brain-dead patient).

 

Option C. Glasgow coma scale: The Glasgow Coma Scale (GCS) is a neurological scale used to assess a person's level of consciousness based on eye, verbal, and motor responses.

 

Option D. Cormack–Lehane grading: The Cormack–Lehane grading system is used during laryngoscopy to describe the view of the glottis. It ranges from Grade I (full view of glottis) to Grade IV (no view of glottis).

 

Educational Objective:

 

The Mallampati grading system is a pre-anesthetic assessment tool used to predict difficult tracheal intubation by classifying the visibility of oropharyngeal structures. It is essential for anesthesiologists to evaluate airway management needs.

 

Ref: Miller’s Anesthesia, 9th Ed. Pg 1379

questions.text: A 3-day old male neonate who has not yet passed meconium developed abdominal distension. There is no history of fever. On rectal examination, forceful expulsion of stool was observed. A barium enema is performed and the findings are shown in the image below. Which of the following is the gold standard for the diagnosis of the above condition? (FMGE DEC 2021)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Rectal biopsy

 

A male infant presenting with failure to pass meconium, abdominal distension, forceful fecal evacuation on rectal examination, and a transition zone in the mid-descending colon on a barium enema is suspected of having Hirschsprung's disease.

 

The ideal method for determining Hirschsprung’s condition's diagnosis is a rectal biopsy. The congenital absence of ganglion cells in the submucosal and myenteric plexus of the intestine results in Hirschsprung's disease, a condition of the digestive system.

 

Megacolon or Congenital Aganglionic Megacolon are other names for it.

 

Peristalsis is absent in the affected area due to the neural crest cells' failure to migrate.

 

The colon enlarges and is known as a megacolon. Gas and waste buildup close to the defect (Functional colon blockage)

 

 

CLINICAL FEATURES:

 

  • In neonates and infants:
  • Failure to pass meconium (delayed passage of meconium)
  • Abdominal distension
  • Bile- stained vomiting
  • Shock
  • Episodes of diarrhea & constipation
  • In older children: Constipation with abdominal distension
  • When stool passed foul smelling, and liquid in consistency
  • Malnourished and anemic

 

DIAGNOSTIC EVALUATION:

 

Hirschsprung’s disease is suspected in a baby who has not passed meconium within 48 hours of birth.

 

  • Rectal examination
  • Palpation
  • Anorectal manometry
  • Barium enema & Rectal biopsy

 

Medical management:

 

  • Administration of Isotonic enema
  • Administration of stool softeners
  • Low residue diet

 

Surgical management: The surgery involves two steps:

 

1) TEMPORARY COLOSTOMY

 

2) DEFINITIVE SURGERY: After about a year of these surgeries, the colostomy is closed.

 

A): Swenson Procedure B): Duhamel Procedure C): Soave’s Procedure.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Ultrasonography: Not the gold standard for diagnosing Hirschsprung's disease; useful for detecting other abdominal issues.

 

Option B. MRI Abdomen: Can provide detailed imaging but is not the diagnostic standard for Hirschsprung's disease.

 

Option D. Anorectal manometry: Useful as a screening tool but not definitive for diagnosis.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Hirschsprung's disease is best diagnosed with a rectal biopsy, which shows the absence of ganglion cells in the submucosal and myenteric plexus.

 

Ref - Nelson 21st Edition, Chapter- 358, – Page No- 7769.

questions.text: Which of the following drugs can cause gynecomastia? (FMGE DECEMBER 2021)
questions.solution:
Ans. C. Spironolactone

 

Spironolactone is a potassium-sparing diuretic often used to treat conditions like heart failure, hypertension, and edema. It has anti-androgenic effects because it inhibits the action of androgens at their receptors and can also block androgen production. These properties contribute to its potential side effect of gynecomastia, which is the benign enlargement of breast tissue in males. This occurs due to the imbalance in the estrogen to androgen ratio that the drug might induce.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Tamoxifen: Though it is a selective estrogen receptor modulator (SERM) used primarily in the treatment and prevention of breast cancer, Tamoxifen actually acts to block estrogen receptors in breast tissue. Interestingly, it can occasionally have a paradoxical effect of gynecomastia in men, particularly when used as a therapy for conditions like breast cancer due to its partial estrogen agonist effects in other tissues.

 

Option B. Oxytocin: This hormone is involved in childbirth and lactation and does not typically affect breast tissue growth in a way that would cause gynecomastia.

 

Option D. Clomiphene citrate: An anti-estrogen used to treat male infertility and stimulate ovulation in women. It is generally associated with increasing testosterone levels in men and is unlikely to cause gynecomastia; in fact, it may be used off-label to treat this condition in men.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Drugs leading to gynecomastia: (Mnemonic “DISCO”)

    • D – Digoxin

    • I – Isoniazid

    • S – Steroids, Spironolactone

    • C- Cimetidine, Ketoconazole

    • O– Oestrogen

questions.text: Tall and tented T waves, wide QRS, and absent P wave are features of: (FMGE DEC 2021)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Hyperkalemia

 

Tall, tented T waves, wide QRS complexes, and absent P waves are classic ECG findings in hyperkalemia, which indicate a high level of potassium in the blood. Hyperkalemia affects the electrical activity of the heart, leading to these characteristic changes on the ECG.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Bundle branch block: Characterized by a widened QRS but does not typically present with tall T waves or absent P waves.

 

Option B. Acute MI: May show ST elevation or other changes, but not specifically tall T waves and wide QRS without P waves.

 

Option D. Ventricular ectopic: Characterized by premature ventricular contractions, not the described ECG findings.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Hyperkalemia shows tall T waves, wide QRS complexes, and absent P waves on ECG.

questions.text: A 7-year-old child presents to the clinic with a high fever, difficulty swallowing, and a visibly swollen neck. The child's parents mention that the symptoms started with a sore throat a few days ago. On physical examination, the child has a thick grayish-white membrane covering the tonsils and posterior pharynx, extending into the nasopharynx. The neck is noticeably swollen, giving it a "bull neck" appearance. Based on these findings, which causative organism is most likely responsible for this presentation? (FMGE DECEMBER 2021)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Corynebacterium diphtheria

 

Presented case with a child exhibiting symptoms of high fever, difficulty swallowing, and a swollen neck with the presence of a grayish-white membrane is highly suggestive of bull neck diphtheria caused by Corynebacterium diphtheriae.

 

  • Colony Appearance: Small, greyish-white, granular colonies with a matte or rough texture.
  • Gram Stain: Gram-positive, rod-shaped bacteria with irregular arrangements.
  • Culture Requirements: Special media like Loeffler's medium or Tinsdale agar are needed for growth.

 

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Corynebacterium ulcerans: Can cause diphtheria-like illness but is less common and typically associated with zoonotic transmission.

 

Option C. Corynebacterium minutissimum: Causes erythrasma, a superficial skin infection, and does not produce a pseudomembrane or systemic symptoms.

 

Option D. Corynebacterium tenuis: Associated with trichomycosis axillaris, a superficial infection of hair shafts, and does not cause diphtheria-like illness.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Corynebacterium diphtheriae is the causative organism of diphtheria, characterized by the formation of a grayish-white pseudomembrane in the throat, high fever, and a swollen neck (bull neck). Early recognition and treatment are critical to managing this potentially life-threatening infection.

choices.text: Increase in insulin level and decrease in glucagon level
Increase in glucagon level and decrease in insulin level
Both insulin and glucagon levels decrease

questions.text: Which of the following condition is true about fed state? (FMGE DECEMBER 2021)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Increase in insulin level and decrease in glucagon level

 

Increase in Insulin Level and Decrease in Glucagon Level: This is the correct answer. In the fed state, blood glucose levels rise due to the absorption of carbohydrates. In response, the pancreas secretes more insulin, a hormone that facilitates the uptake of glucose by cells for energy and also stimulates the storage of excess glucose as glycogen in the liver and muscles. At the same time, the secretion of glucagon, a hormone that promotes the release of stored glucose from the liver, decreases. This coordinated hormonal response ensures that blood glucose levels are kept within a healthy range.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Increase in Glucagon Level and Decrease in Insulin Level: This would be more characteristic of the fasting state, not the fed state. During fasting, glucagon levels increase to promote the release of stored glucose to maintain blood glucose levels, while insulin levels decrease.

 

Option C. Both Insulin and Glucagon Levels Decrease: This option is not typical for the fed state. As mentioned, insulin levels increase in response to higher blood glucose levels, and glucagon levels typically decrease.

 

Option D. Only Insulin Levels Increase: While insulin levels indeed increase in the fed state, this option ignores the change in glucagon levels. The decrease in glucagon is also a key aspect of the body's response to being in a fed state.

 

Educational Objective:

 

In the fed state, after a meal, the body experiences an increase in insulin levels which is an anabolic hormone. Insulin facilitates the uptake of glucose by cells for energy production and promotes the storage of excess glucose as glycogen in the liver and muscles. Simultaneously, glucagon levels decrease in the fed state. Glucagon, which is released in response to low blood glucose levels (fasting state), promotes the release of glucose from the liver.

 

Ref: Harper’s Illustrated Biochemistry 32nd edition Page no. 188

questions.text: A community health team is planning an educational outreach in an urban slum to teach residents how to prepare Oral Rehydration Solution (ORS) effectively. Considering the practical nature of the task and the residents' limited literacy, which educational method would be most effective for teaching them to accurately and independently prepare ORS? (FMGE DEC 2021)
questions.solution:
Ans. B. Demonstration 

 

This is the ideal method for teaching practical tasks that people need to replicate. A 2-way communication process that involves believing after seeing and learning by doing.

 

Other Options:  

 

Option A. Roleplay: This is an interactive method often used to simulate real-life scenarios to promote understanding and skill development. While roleplay can be effective for teaching communication or decision-making skills, it's less suitable for teaching a practical, hands-on task like ORS preparation.

 

Option C. Group discussion: This method can be beneficial for topics that require understanding and reflection, such as discussing the importance of ORS or sharing experiences related to dehydration. However, it's less effective for teaching practical skills.

 

Option D. Flashcard: Flashcards are useful for memorization or quick recall. They can be used as supplementary tools but are not the primary method for teaching a hands-on skill like ORS preparation.

 

Educational Objective:

 

For practical skills, especially in health education among populations with limited literacy, demonstrations provide a clear, direct way to learn and master essential tasks, ensuring that participants can effectively carry out these practices independently, enhancing their ability to respond to health needs effectively.

questions.text: Which hormone is produced by parafollicular cells: (FMGE DEC 2021)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Calcitonin

 

The parafollicular cells (also known as C cells) of the thyroid gland produce the hormone calcitonin. Calcitonin plays a role in calcium and phosphate metabolism by lowering blood calcium levels. It does this by inhibiting osteoclast activity, which reduces bone resorption and increases calcium excretion in the kidneys.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Parathormone: Parathormone, also known as parathyroid hormone (PTH), is produced by the parathyroid glands, not the thyroid gland. It increases blood calcium levels by stimulating bone resorption, increasing calcium reabsorption in the kidneys, and activating vitamin D.

 

Option C. T3/T4: Thyroxine (T4) and triiodothyronine (T3) are hormones produced by the follicular cells of the thyroid gland, not by parafollicular cells. These hormones are essential for regulating metabolism, growth, and development.

 

Option D. TSH: Thyroid-stimulating hormone (TSH) is produced by the anterior pituitary gland. It stimulates the thyroid gland to produce, stores these thyroid hormones and releases as required.

 

Educational Objective:


Parafollicular cells (C cells) in the thyroid gland produce calcitonin, which helps regulate calcium and phosphate levels in the blood.

questions.text: The body can be divided into anterior and posterior parts, by which of the following anatomical planes? (FMGE DECEMBER 2021)
questions.solution:
Ans. A. Coronal plane

 

The coronal plane is a vertical that divides the body into anterior and posterior parts. The coronal plane, also referred to as the frontal plane, is a vertical plane that divides the body into anterior (front) and posterior (back) sections. This plane runs perpendicular to the sagittal plane, which divides the body into left and right halves.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Transverse Plane: The transverse plane, also known as the horizontal plane or axial plane, is a horizontal plane that divides the body into upper (superior) and lower (inferior) sections. It runs parallel to the ground and is often used to visualize cross-sectional anatomy. The transverse plane helps us understand structures located above or below a specific level.

 

Option C. Axial Plane: The term "axial plane" is sometimes used interchangeably with the transverse plane. Both refer to a horizontal plane that divides the body into upper and lower sections. However, "axial" can also be a general term referring to the central axis of the body, including structures along the head-to-toe axis.

 

Option D. Median Plane: The median plane, also known as the midsagittal plane, is a vertical plane that divides the body into equal left and right halves. It runs through the midline of the body. The term "median" is often used to describe structures or positions that are at or near the midline.

 

Educational Objective:

choices.text: Conductive hearing loss, Ipsilateral temporoparietal neuralgia, Palatal paralysis
Sensorineural hearing loss, Contralateral temporoparietal neuralgia, Palatal paralysis
Sensorineural hearing loss, Ipsilateral temporoparietal neuralgia, Palatal paralysis
Conductive hearing loss, Contralateral temporoparietal neuralgia, Palatal paralysis

questions.text: Which of the following is part of trotter's triad, seen in nasopharyngeal carcinoma? (FMGE DECEMBER 2021)
questions.solution:
Ans. A. Conductive hearing loss, Ipsilateral temporoparietal neuralgia, Palatal paralysis

 

TROTTER'S TRIAD:

 

  • ﻿﻿Conductive hearing loss due to Eustachian tube obstruction. Ipsilateral temporoparietal neuralgia (CN V mandibular branch)
  • ﻿﻿Palatal paralysis

 

 

Reference – Dhingra 7th edition, Page No. 285

choices.text: Wait and watch for spontaneous resolution
Give GnRH for 1 month, if testis does not descend down on its own, then do surgery before 2years
Give GnRH for 1 month, if testis does not descend down on its own, then do surgery before 5 years of age
Do immediate Surgery

questions.text: Mother while giving a bath to her 9-day old baby noticed that the scrotum of the baby is empty. What treatment should be prescribed to this baby? (FMGE DECEMEBR 2021)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Wait and watch for spontaneous resolution

 

The clinical scenario given is a case of undescended testis. It gets spontaneously resolved within 3 months. Till then, the best step should be to wait and watch.

 

  • Most undescended testes will descend spontaneously in the first few months of life. This is particularly true for testes that are located high in the scrotum or just outside the external inguinal ring. Therefore, the first approach, especially in infants, is usually to wait and monitor. If the testis hasn't descended by around 3-6 months, further evaluation or treatment might be needed.

 

Other options:

 

Option B. Give GnRH for 1 month, if testis does not descend down on its own, then do surgery before 2 years:

 

  • Hormonal therapy, like GnRH, has been used to encourage testicular descent. The results are variable, and the response rate is not very high. If hormonal therapy is unsuccessful, surgical correction (orchidopexy) is typically recommended. Surgery is ideally performed between 6 to 12 months to maximize fertility potential and prevent complications.

 

Option C. Give GnRH for 1 month, if testis does not descend down on its own, then do surgery before 5 years of age:

 

  • As stated above, waiting until 5 years for surgery may not be ideal. Delayed treatment can result in reduced fertility and an increased risk of testicular cancer.

 

Option D. Do immediate Surgery:

 

  • Immediate surgical intervention in a 9-day-old baby is not typically recommended. The preferred approach is to monitor for spontaneous resolution first.

 

Educational Objective:

 

For a newborn with undescended testis, the initial management is to wait and monitor for spontaneous descent within the first few months of life. If the testis has not descended by 3-6 months, further evaluation and potential intervention are considered.

choices.text: The procedure is done under local anesthesia.
Sterility is achieved 3 weeks after the procedure.
A no-scalpel technique is being widely used now.
The vas deferens is the structure that is divided in the procedure.

questions.text: Which of the following statements is incorrect regarding vasectomy? (FMGE DEC 2021)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Sterility is achieved 3 weeks after the procedure.

 

  • Sterility is achieved 3 weeks after the procedure is incorrect because sterility is not achieved immediately after the procedure. Sperm can remain in the reproductive tract for up to three months.
  • The recovery process can take up to 3 months, during which the couple should either abstain from sexual intercourse or use alternative forms of contraception until a semen analysis confirms azoospermia.

 

Vasectomy:

 

  • The procedure is typically done under local anesthesia 
  • The no-scalpel technique is now widely used. This technique involves making a single puncture with special forceps, and no skin stitches are required
  • The vas deferens is the structure that is divided during the procedure to prevent sperm from being present in the ejaculate 
  • The semen is usually cleared of all sperm in about 20 ejaculations. Before a man can be considered sterile, a semen analysis must be performed to confirm the absence of sperm.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. The procedure is done under local anesthesia: This is correct. Vasectomy is typically performed under local anesthesia.

 

Option C. A no-scalpel technique is being widely used now: This is correct. The no-scalpel technique is less invasive and has become the preferred method for vasectomy.

 

Option D. The vas deferens is the structure that is divided in the procedure: This is correct. The vas deferens is cut or sealed to prevent sperm from entering the ejaculate.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Sterility is not immediately achieved after a vasectomy and may take up to three months, requiring confirmation through semen analysis to ensure azoospermia.

 

Ref: Dutta’s textbook of Gynecology 6th edition pg 495, Williams textbook of Gynecology 3rd edition pg. 118

questions.text: A woman with a history of infertility is on treatment with HMG. She presented the following finding in the US. What is the most likely diagnosis? (FMGE DEC 2021)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Ovarian hyperstimulation syndrome

 

Explanation:

 

  • The image is a transvaginal ultrasound showing the ovaries which appear significantly enlarged.
  • In view of her history of controlled ovarian hyperstimulation in IVF, the answer is OHSS
  • Theca lutein cysts are enlarged cysts seen in molar pregnancy
  • PCOS is a risk factor for OHSS, in view of the history, OHSS is a more appropriate answer
    • Ovarian hyperstimulation syndrome is characterized by multiple ovarian follicular cysts accompanied by increased capillary permeability and leakage of intravascular fluid to the third space. 
    • It is commonly seen after exogenous administration of FSH, LH or HCG injections. 
    • Bilateral ovaries are enlarged and show presence of multiple follicular cysts
    • The OHSS risk is high in women with PCOS with high AMH, high AFC Or with history of previous high response.
    • Risk can be reduced using antagonist protocol with GnRH agonist trigger.
    • The mainstay of management is conservative. The ongoing stimulation cycle is suspended, and further administration of exogenous gonadotropins is stopped in that cycle. 
    • Severe OHSS can also cause ascites, pleural effusion, liver dysfunction, raised hematocrit (>55%), oliguria, thromboembolic phenomenon etc. and must be managed conservatively.

 

Other options:

 

Option B. Theca lutein cysts: They may be seen in gestational trophoblastic diseases such as molar pregnancies. They subside once the HCG normalizes.

 

Option C. PCOS: It is characterized by the presence of 2 out of 3 criteria (Rotterdam criteria))

 

Educational Objective:

 

Ovarian hyperstimulation syndrome (OHSS) is characterized by multiple ovarian follicular cysts, increased capillary permeability, and leakage of intravascular fluid into the third space, commonly seen after exogenous administration of FSH, LH, or HCG injections, particularly in women undergoing controlled ovarian hyperstimulation for IVF.

 

Ref: Duttas textbook of Gynaecology 6th edition pg  529 Williams textbook of gynaecology 3rd edition pg 453

questions.text: A 30-year-old female came with chief complaints of vaginal discharge with lower abdominal pain and cervical motion tenderness. Which color kit will you prescribe her? (FMGE DEC 2021)
questions.solution:
Ans. C. Yellow kit (6)

 

  • The given clinical scenario of fever & lower abdominal pain & cervical motion tenderness is suggestive of PID.
  • Yellow / KIT 6 is used in treating Pelvic Inflammatory Disease patients.

 

 

PID Lower abdominal pain

 

  • Tab metronidazole 400mg BD for 14 days
  • (anaerobes)
  • Tab Cefixime 400mg 1 stat (gonococci)
  • Tab Doxycycline 100mg BD for 14 days (Chlamydia trachomatis)

 

The best treatment option for this patient on a OPD basis according to RCOG guidelines is Ceftriaxone 250mg IM injection + Oral Doxycycline 100mg BD +/-Metronidazole 400mg BD X 14 days.

 

Educational Objective:

questions.text: What is the likely diagnosis based on the image shown: (FMGE DECEMBER 2021)
questions.solution:
Ans. B. Pulmonary hamartoma

 

  • The NCCT image is showing a well-defined nodule with popcorn calcification which is suggestive of a pulmonary hamartoma.
  • Pulmonary hamartoma also known as chondroma: most common benign lung tumor.
  • H/P: Normal lung tissue that has grown in an abnormal pattern with cartilage, fat, and muscle.

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Hodgkin's lymphoma: Typically presents with lymphadenopathy, which can be intrathoracic but would not show popcorn calcifications.

 

Option C. Metastasis: Lung metastases can present as multiple nodules but generally do not have the popcorn calcification pattern.

 

Option D. Squamous cell carcinoma: A malignant lung tumor that might present as a mass with spiculated margins or cavitation, but not typically with popcorn calcifications.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Pulmonary hamartoma is a benign lung tumor characterized by the presence of popcorn calcifications on imaging studies.

questions.text: A 7-year-old boy has non-blanching rashes on the legs and buttocks as seen in the picture. He also complains of joint pains, abdominal pain, vomiting, and blood in the stool. Lab investigations revealed normal platelet count and urine analysis shows hematuria + ++ and proteinuria +. What is the diagnosis? (FMGE DEC 2021)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Henoch Schonlein purpura (HSP)

 

The diagnosis based on the clinical picture Hench Schonlein purpura.

 

Henoch Schonlein purpura (HSP) characteristics:

 

About half of HSP patients experience renal manifestations, which can range from asymptomatic microscopic hematuria to severe, progressive glomerulonephritis: Henoch-Schönlein purpura (HSP) is a common small vessel vasculitis in children that is characterised by a purpuric rash and frequently accompanied by arthritis and abdominal pain. Laboratory investigations typically reveal a slight leukocytosis, a normal platelet count, and sporadically eosinophilia as the pathophysiology of HSP nephritis appears to be mediated by the deposition of polymeric immunoglobulin A (IgA) in glomeruli. The components of serum complement are typical.

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Systemic lupus erythematosus (SLE): Typically presents with a butterfly rash over the nasolabial folds, photosensitivity, and systemic involvement of various organs. Lab tests often show positive ANA and dsDNA antibodies.

 

Option C. Immune thrombocytopenic purpura (ITP): Characterized by petechiae and ecchymoses primarily due to thrombocytopenia (low platelet count). The absence of systemic symptoms like abdominal pain and renal involvement helps differentiate it from HSP.

 

Option D. Polyarteritis Nodosa (PAN): A medium vessel vasculitis that presents with systemic symptoms such as fever, weight loss, hypertension, abdominal pain, and multisystem involvement. It is rare in childhood and typically does not present with the characteristic palpable purpura of HSP.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Henoch-Schonlein purpura (HSP) presents with a purpuric rash, joint pain, abdominal pain, and renal involvement, often following an upper respiratory infection.

questions.text: If all extraocular muscles are paralysed, where would you suspect the lesion? (FMGE DEC 2021)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Brainstem

 

The brainstem houses the nuclei of the cranial nerves responsible for eye movements. Paralysis of all extraocular muscles suggests a lesion affecting these nuclei or their associated pathways within the brainstem.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Frontal eye field: Lesions here cause ipsilateral gaze deviations and saccadic eye movement disorders, not complete paralysis of extraocular muscles.

 

Option B. Cerebral surface: Cerebral lesions usually do not cause paralysis of all extraocular muscles but may affect ipsilateral voluntary eye movements.

 

Option D. Spinal cord: The spinal cord does not control the extraocular muscles; it is involved in motor and sensory pathways for the limbs and trunk.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Paralysis of all extraocular muscles typically indicates a brainstem lesion affecting cranial nerve nuclei.

choices.text: Reassure the patient and follow up

questions.text: A lady was incidentally diagnosed with a 0.5 cm solid mass in her Gall Bladder on USG which is immobile and it is diagnosed as a gall bladder polyp. She is asymptomatic. What is the next step in the management? (FMGE DECEMEBR 2021)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Reassure the patient and follow up

 

The incidental finding of a 0.5 cm asymptomatic gallbladder polyp on ultrasound does not warrant immediate surgical intervention. Polyps smaller than 1 cm are generally benign and do not require surgery unless there are other risk factors such as rapid growth, patient age over 55, or presence of gallstones. Regular follow-up with periodic ultrasound is recommended to monitor the size and characteristics of the polyp.

 

Other Options:

 

  • Option B. Laparoscopic Cholecystectomy:
    • This is the surgical removal of the gallbladder using a minimally invasive method. It is indicated for polyps larger than 1 cm or if there are other risk factors suggesting a higher likelihood of malignancy. Since the polyp is only 0.5 cm and the patient is asymptomatic, this option is not necessary at this stage.
  • Option C. Open Cholecystectomy:
    • This is a more invasive procedure compared to laparoscopic cholecystectomy. It is typically reserved for cases where laparoscopic surgery is not feasible or if there is suspicion of malignancy. Given the small size of the polyp and the absence of symptoms, this option is not appropriate.
  • Option D. CECT Abdomen:
    • Contrast-enhanced computed tomography (CECT) of the abdomen can provide detailed images of abdominal structures. However, for a small, asymptomatic gallbladder polyp, this investigation is not required. It would expose the patient to unnecessary radiation without adding significant value in this scenario.

 

Educational Objective:

 

For an asymptomatic gallbladder polyp smaller than 1 cm, the appropriate management is to reassure the patient and arrange regular follow-up to monitor for any changes in the polyp size or characteristics.

questions.text: An 8-year-old boy presented with dark-colored urine as shown below, oliguria, hypertension, and facial puffiness for 3 days. The urine test is positive for albumin. He had a history of throat infection 2 weeks back. On microscopic examination, enlarged, pale glomeruli and epithelial humps are seen. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis? (FMGE DEC 2021)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Post-streptococcal glomerulonephritis

 

The clinical presentation of dark-colored urine, oliguria, hypertension, facial puffiness, and a history of throat infection 2 weeks prior, along with the microscopic findings of enlarged, pale glomeruli and epithelial humps, are indicative of Post-streptococcal glomerulonephritis (PSGN).

 

Post-streptococcal glomerulonephritis (PSGN):

 

  • Etiology: Typically follows a throat infection by nephritogenic strains of group A beta-hemolytic streptococci (GABHS). It can also follow skin infections such as impetigo.
  • Pathophysiology: The disease is an immune complex-mediated condition where circulating immune complexes are deposited in the glomeruli, leading to inflammation.
  • Symptoms: Gross hematuria (tea or cola-colored urine), oliguria, edema (especially facial puffiness), and hypertension.
  • Microscopic Findings: Light microscopy shows enlarged, hypercellular glomeruli with leukocyte infiltration. Immunofluorescence reveals granular deposits of IgG and complement C3 along the glomerular basement membrane (GBM) and in the mesangium. Electron microscopy shows electron-dense deposits (humps) on the epithelial side of the GBM.
  • Laboratory Findings: Decreased serum C3 levels (which normalize in 6-8 weeks), elevated anti-streptolysin O (ASO) titers, and proteinuria.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Post-staphylococcal glomerulonephritis: Typically occurs after a staphylococcal infection. The presentation is similar to PSGN but often occurs in older patients and has different immunofluorescence patterns (IgA dominant).

 

Option C. Nephrotic syndrome: Characterized by heavy proteinuria (>3.5 g/24 hours), hypoalbuminemia, generalized edema, and hyperlipidemia. The urine is often frothy rather than dark-colored.

 

Option D. IgA nephropathy: Typically presents with recurrent episodes of hematuria occurring concurrently with or shortly after upper respiratory infections. IgA deposits are seen in the mesangium on immunofluorescence.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Post-streptococcal glomerulonephritis typically presents with hematuria, oliguria, hypertension, and facial edema following a streptococcal throat infection, with microscopic findings of enlarged glomeruli and epithelial humps.

questions.text: A 34-year-old clinical researcher is setting up a trial to evaluate a new antihypertensive drug. He wants to ensure the trial design eliminates biases that could arise from non-random assignment of participants, which might affect the study's validity. Which method would be most effective in making sure that participants in both the treatment and control groups are comparable at the start of the trial? (FMGE DEC 2021)
questions.solution:
Ans. C.  Randomization

 

Randomisation in Randomized Controlled trial (RCT) is a statistical procedure by which participants are allocated into either of two groups - Experimental Group (in which intervention is given) and Reference Group (in which intervention is not given)

 

Randomization is done to remove selection bias. It ensures comparability of both the groups by removal of both known and unknown confounding factors.

 

Other Options: 

 

Option A. Matching: Involves pairing individuals who have similar characteristics before allocating them to treatment groups. It's primarily used in observational studies to control confounding, but it does not eliminate the risk of selection bias inherent in non-random assignment.

 

Option B. Blinding: This technique ensures that the participants, caregivers, or those evaluating the outcomes do not know which treatment the participant received, thereby preventing measurement and observer bias. 

 

Option D. Stratification: Involves dividing participants into subgroups based on one or more characteristics, and then randomizing within these strata. It ensures balance between treatment groups in terms of the stratified variable, but by itself, it does not eliminate selection bias. 

 

Educational Objective:

 

Randomization is the cornerstone of a well-conducted randomized controlled trial, essential for ensuring that treatment and control groups are equivalent at baseline and that the results are generalizable and free from selection bias.

 

Randomization is Superior to BOTH Matching and Blinding

choices.text: Venous congestion and reduction of the prolapsed part and daily packing with glycerin

questions.text: Miss. Uma presents to you with complaints of mass descending per vaginum for the past 6 months. On examination, you notice a grade 3 uterovaginal prolapse and a decubitus ulcer over the prolapse. Which of the following is a cause for this decubitus ulcer and treatment? (FMGE DEC 2021)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Venous congestion and reduction of the prolapsed part and daily packing with glycerin

 

Explanation:

 

Decubitus ulcers in prolapsed organs are primarily caused by localized alterations in the circulatory system, specifically venous congestion, rather than trauma or friction. The continuous externalization of the prolapsed organ leads to impaired venous return and subsequent ulcer formation.

 

The recommended treatment includes:

 

  • Daily packing with glycerin and acriflavine.
    • Glycerin is a hygroscopic substance that helps to draw fluid out of the tissues, thereby reducing swelling.
    • Acriflavine is an antibacterial substance that helps to prevent infection.
  • Reduction of the prolapsed portion into the vagina to alleviate the venous congestion.

 

If the ulcer does not heal with these measures, a biopsy from the margins of the ulcer should be considered to rule out malignancy.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Malignancy and excision: Decubitus ulcers in the context of uterovaginal prolapse are generally due to venous congestion, not malignancy. Malignancy would present differently and would require histopathological confirmation before excision.

 

Option C. Infection and antibiotics: While infection can complicate ulcers, the primary cause in this scenario is venous congestion, and antibiotics alone would not address the underlying issue.

 

Option D. Trauma and dressing: Trauma is not the primary cause of decubitus ulcers in prolapsed organs. Proper reduction and addressing the venous congestion are essential for treatment.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Decubitus ulcers in uterovaginal prolapse are caused by venous congestion, and treatment involves reducing the prolapsed part and daily packing with glycerin and acriflavine.

 

Ref: Duttas textbook of gynecology 6th edition page 206

questions.text: A 60-year-old patient, a known case of hypertension, was being treated with antihypertensive drugs. He is having chronic cough for 2 weeks. He was started on antimicrobials, but the cough did not resolve. Which of the following antihypertensive drugs may induce chronic cough in this patient? (FMGE DECEMBER 2021)
questions.solution:
Ans. D. Lisinopril

 

  • Lisinopril is an Angiotensin Converting Enzyme inhibitor, that has the common side effect of dry cough.

  • ACE inhibitors as the name suggests, inhibits the Angiotensin converting enzyme (ACE) which is produced by Lungs. This enzyme activates Angiotensin I and is also involved in metabolism of Bradykinin. As a result of inhibition of ACE enzymes, Bradykinin concentration increases which irritates and triggers the cough receptors in the respiratory tract and induces dry cough.

  • The other side effects of Lisinopril include angioedema, altered taste sensation, hyperkalemia, orthostatic hypotension etc. It is contraindicated in pregnancy and in B/L renal artery stenosis.
     

Other Options:

 

Option A. Amlodipine: A calcium channel blocker that primarily affects vascular smooth muscle and cardiac muscle. It is not typically associated with inducing a cough and is generally well-tolerated in terms of respiratory side effects.

 

Option B. Minoxidil: Used primarily as a vasodilator for severe hypertension and not known for respiratory side effects such as cough.

 

Option C. Propranolol: A beta-blocker that can cause respiratory side effects, particularly in individuals with underlying reactive airway diseases like asthma, due to its action on beta receptors. However, it does not typically cause a dry cough.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Patients who develop a chronic dry cough while on ACE inhibitors like Lisinopril should consider consulting their healthcare provider to possibly switch to another class of antihypertensives, such as angiotensin receptor blockers (ARBs), which typically do not cause cough.

questions.text: Adverse effect of orlistat is?
questions.solution:
Ans. B. Steatorrhea

 

Orlistat is an inhibitor of the enzyme lipase; thus, it inhibits the breakdown and absorption of fats. This unabsorbed fat is passed out in stool, leading to steatorrhea.

 

Orlistat is used in the treatment of obesity.

 

Orlistat is a medication used to aid in weight loss and to prevent weight regain in overweight individuals. It works by inhibiting the absorption of fats from the human diet by inhibiting intestinal lipase enzyme.

 

The adverse effects of Orlistat primarily relate to its mechanism of action on fat absorption. Because it blocks the absorption of fats, these fats are excreted in the stool, leading to oily, loose stools and an increased frequency of bowel movements. This is called steatorrhea (fatty stools), which is a common side effect of Orlistat.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Suicidal tendency: There's no direct association between Orlistat and increased suicidal tendencies.

 

Option C. Weight gain: Orlistat is used for weight loss, and weight gain is not a typical side effect.

 

Option D. Hyperglycemia: Orlistat is not known to cause hyperglycemia; in fact, it may have a beneficial effect on blood sugar control in overweight individuals with diabetes.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Orlistat is a useful medication for those looking to lose weight, especially in cases where diet and exercise alone have not been sufficient. Patients prescribed Orlistat should be counseled about the possibility of experiencing gastrointestinal side effects such as steatorrhea and advised on dietary adjustments to manage or minimize such effects, emphasizing a reduced fat intake.

questions.text: A male patient presented to hospital with tachycardia, hypertension, palpitations and pupil dilatation. He Is found to be a substance abuser. Which of the following drug withdrawal can cause the following symptoms? (FMGE DECEMBER 2021)
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Opioid

 

  • In withdrawal symptoms opposite symptoms of toxicity are seen.
  • Hence tachycardia, hypertension etc in withdrawal symptoms will be seen in CNS depressants like alcohol and opioids
  • Withdrawal state in opioid dependence is characterized by yawning, watering eyes, sweating, irritability, tremor, diarrhoea, chills, cramps and muscle aches, increased blood pressure and heart rate, and can lasts up to 7-10 days.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. LSD: Withdrawal typically involves less severe symptoms and may include mood swings, flashbacks, or anxiety rather than the severe autonomic symptoms described.

 

Option B. Cannabis: Withdrawal can include irritability, sleep difficulties, decreased appetite, and anxiety, but does not typically present with severe autonomic symptoms like tachycardia and hypertension.

 

Option C. Cocaine: Withdrawal from cocaine often includes fatigue, depression, increased appetite, and vivid unpleasant dreams. While some autonomic symptoms can be present, they are not as pronounced as with opioid withdrawal.

 

Educational objective

 

Withdrawal from opioids, a CNS depressant, results in symptoms that are opposite to their effects, including tachycardia, hypertension, and pupil dilation, along with other autonomic and physical symptoms.

questions.text: A patient was diagnosed with ear wax and was subjected to syringing to remove the wax. She developed a syncopal episode while doing the procedure when the tip of the syringe touched the ear canal. Which of the nerves is responsible for this episode of syncope? (FMGE DEC 2021)
questions.solution:
Ans. B. Arnold’s nerve

 

Stimulation of Arnolds nerve (auricular branch of vagus nerve) in the posterior canal wall during wax removal can lead to a vasovagal attack causing syncope.

 

Nerve supply of pinna and EAC: Greater auricular, lesser occipital, auriculotemporal, Arnold’s (auricular branch of Vagus nerve), facial branch.

 

 

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Auriculotemporal nerve: Mainly responsible for sensory innervation around the tragus and adjacent areas, not typically involved in reflexive syncope.

 

Option C. Glossopharyngeal nerve: Primarily involved in the sensations and taste from the posterior one-third of the tongue, and innervation of some muscles of the pharynx, not directly related to ear canal stimulation.

 

Option D. Jacobson's nerve: Involved with the middle ear, carrying fibers that contribute to the tympanic plexus.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The Arnold's nerve is crucial in the context of ear procedures, where its stimulation can lead to significant autonomic responses, including syncope. Awareness of this nerve's sensitivity is important for clinicians performing ear syringing or other manipulative treatments involving the ear canal.

choices.text: Kiesselbach’s plexus is present in the Little's area.
It is situated at the posteroinferior part of the nasal septum.
Least common site for epistaxis.
Anastomoses of 7 major arteries occur here.

questions.text: Which of the following statements is true with respect to the Little's area?
questions.solution:
Ans. A. Kiesselbach’s plexus is present in the Little's area.

 

LITTLE’S AREA:

 

  • It is situated in the anterior inferior part of nasal septum, just above the vestibule.
  • Four arteries (anterior ethmoidal, septal branch of superior labial, septal branch of sphenopalatine and greater palatine) anastomose here to form a vascular plexus called “Kiesselbach’s plexus”.
  • Usual site for epistaxis in children (finger nail trauma) and young adults.
  • Sphenopalatine forms majority of blood supply, hence called as ‘artery of epistaxis’.

 

 

 

Other Options:

 

  • Option B. It is situated at the posteroinferior part of the nasal septum: This is incorrect. Little's area is located in the anterior inferior part of the nasal septum.
  • Option C. Least common site for epistaxis: This is false. Little's area is actually one of the most common sites for epistaxis due to the rich vascular supply.
  • Option D. Anastomoses of 7 major arteries occur here: This statement is exaggerated; only four major arteries anastomose in this area.

 

Educational Objective

 

Little's area is a critical site for understanding nasal bleeds in clinical practice, due to the confluence of several arteries forming the Kiesselbach’s plexus. Recognizing this area's location and significance helps in effectively managing and treating cases of anterior epistaxis.

questions.text: A patient came to OPD with complaints of diarrhea, dermatitis and dementia. It was also found that he was a maize eater. Which of the following could be most probably deficient?(FMGE DECEMEBR 2021)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Niacin

 

Patient symptoms indicate pellagra due to Niacin deficiency. Niacin, also known as vitamin B3, is essential for various cellular processes, including energy metabolism and the maintenance of skin, nervous system, and digestive system health.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Thiamin: Thiamin (vitamin B1) deficiency leads to beriberi and Wernicke-Korsakoff syndrome, characterized by neurological symptoms and cardiovascular issues, but not the specific triad seen in pellagra.

 

Option B. Riboflavin: Riboflavin (vitamin B2) deficiency can cause sore throat, redness, and swelling of the mouth and throat.

 

Option D. Biotin: Biotin deficiency can result in symptoms such as hair loss, skin rash, and neurological abnormalities.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Pellagra, resulting from niacin deficiency, manifests as the triad (3Ds) of symptoms: diarrhea, dermatitis, and dementia. Niacin deficiency can occur in individuals with diets heavily reliant on maize (corn), which may contain niacin in a form less bioavailable to humans.

 

Ref: Harper’s Illustrated Biochemistry 32nd edition Page no. 542

questions.text: Identify the dermatome corresponding to the area marked by the arrow in the image. (FMGE DECEMBER 2021)
questions.solution:
Ans. A. L4

 

Explanation

 

The medial side of the leg and medial malleolus is supplied by the L4 dermatome

 

The L4 dermatome primarily covers the medial aspect of the leg, extending from the knee down to the medial malleolus (inner ankle bone). It also includes a small portion of the foot's dorsum and the big toe. Patients with L4 dermatome sensory abnormalities might experience altered sensation or numbness in these areas.

 

Other options

 

Option B) L5:  The L5 dermatome covers the lateral aspect of the leg, the dorsum of the foot, and extends to the space between the first and second toes (great toe and second toe). It does not include the medial malleolus. Sensory abnormalities in the L5 dermatome may manifest as altered sensation or numbness in these regions.

 

Option C) S1: The S1 dermatome covers the lateral and posterior aspects of the leg, the lateral border of the foot, and extends to the fifth toe (pinky toe). It does not include the medial malleolus or the medial side of the leg. Sensory abnormalities in the S1 dermatome may affect these regions but not the specific areas mentioned in the question.

 

Option D) S2:  The S2 dermatome covers the posterior aspect of the thigh and buttock, not the medial malleolus or the medial side of the leg. Sensory abnormalities in the S2 dermatome may manifest as altered sensation in these regions but are not associated with the medial ankle and leg.

 

Educational Objective

 

Dermatomes

questions.text: Which group of drug combinations contain all intarvenous hypnotic agents? (FMGE DEC 2021)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Propofol, Thiopentone sodium, Etomidate

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Halothane, Sevoflurane, Tramadol:

  • Halothane and Sevoflurane: These are inhalational anesthetic agents, not intravenous.
  • Tramadol: An opioid analgesic used to treat moderate to severe pain, not a hypnotic agent.

 

Option C. Vecuronium, Sufentanil, Desflurane:

  • Vecuronium: A muscle relaxant used during anesthesia.
  • Sufentanil: An opioid analgesic used for pain relief, not a hypnotic.
  • Desflurane: An inhalational anesthetic agent.

 

Option D. Sugammadex, Rocuronium, Atracurium:

  • Sugammadex: A medication used to reverse the effects of certain muscle relaxants.
  • Rocuronium and Atracurium: Muscle relaxants used during anesthesia.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Intravenous hypnotic agents, such as Propofol, Thiopentone sodium, and Etomidate, are used for the rapid induction of anesthesia. They differ from inhalational anesthetics and muscle relaxants, which serve different purposes in anesthesia management.

 

Ref: Miller’s Anesthesia, 9th Ed. Chapter 23, Intravenous Anesthetics

questions.text: Identify the tarsal bone pointed in the image below:(FMGE DECEMBER 2021)
questions.solution:
Ans. C. Navicular

 

Explanation

 

The image shows the navicular bone.

Navicular bone is another tarsal bone situated on the medial (inner) side of the foot. It is located between the head of talus and the cuneiform bones. The navicular bone is important for maintaining the longitudinal arch of the foot.

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Calcaneus: It  is the largest bone in the human foot and forms the heel. It is located at the posterior (back) part of the foot, just below the talus. It articulates with the talus bone superiorly and with the cuboid bone anteriorly. Injuries to the calcaneus, such as fractures, can be quite disabling and may result from falls or high-impact trauma.

 

Option B. Cuboid: It is one of the seven tarsal bones in the foot. It is located on the lateral (outer) side of the foot, between the calcaneus and the fourth and fifth metatarsal bones. The cuboid bone helps to maintain the arch of the foot and provides stability to the lateral aspect of the midfoot.

 

Option D. Talus bone: often referred to as the anklebone, is a small bone that forms the main connection between the foot and the leg. It sits atop the calcaneus and articulates with the tibia and fibula to form the ankle joint. The talus is essential for ankle movement, allowing dorsiflexion (raising the foot) and plantarflexion (pointing the foot downward). It also plays a role in inversion and eversion of the foot.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The Navicular bone is a key element in the structural integrity and functional mechanics of the foot, particularly in forming the medial arch. Its position and role are essential in understanding foot biomechanics and addressing issues related to arch abnormalities or injuries

questions.text: During the 14th century Bubonic plague outbreak in Europe, maritime authorities imposed a quarantine period for ships coming from affected areas before allowing them to dock. What was the duration of this quarantine to prevent the spread of the plague? (FMGE DEC 2021)
questions.solution:
Ans. C. 40 days

 

  • Quarantine is done for healthy contacts till maximum incubation period of the disease It was first applied on plague where sailors were quarantined for a duration of 40 days.
  • Quarantine was originally introduced as a protection against Plague
  • The Quarantine Act, 1870
  • Quarantine currently has been ‘replaced with active surveillance’

 

Additional Information

 

Quarantine Vs Isolation  

 

Isolation’ is the separation for the period of communicability, of infected persons from others in such places/conditions as to prevent/limit transmission to those susceptible. It applies to persons who are known to be ill with a contagious disease. This is a secondary level of prevention. 

 

Quarantine is the restriction of activities of apparently healthy persons who have been exposed to a case of communicable disease during its period of communicability. This is a Primary (specific protection) level of prevention. 

 

Educational Objective:

 

Quarantine is required for - 

 

  • Yellow fever (6 days)
  • Cholera (from the onset of symptoms until seven days after resolution of diarrhoea) 
  • Plague (40 days)

questions.text: A central line was being put in the Subclavian vein and the patient collapsed during insertion of the central line. On examination, breath sounds suddenly were found to be absent on the side of insertion of Central line, on Percussion there was hyper resonance on the same side of insertion of the central line. Most likely cause in this patient: (FMGE DECEMEBR 2021)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Pneumothorax

 

While inserting a central venous catheter in the subclavian vein, there can be an accidental puncture of the dome of the pleura, leading to pneumothorax. This results in the entry of air into the pleural space, causing lung collapse and a characteristic clinical presentation.

 

Features of Pneumothorax:

 

  • Auscultation: Absent breath sounds on the affected side
  • Percussion: Hyper-resonance on the affected side
  • Clinical Presentation: Respiratory distress and desaturation
  • Treatment: Intercostal drain insertion is typically required to remove the air from the pleural space.

 

It is standard practice to send patients for a chest X-ray after insertion of a subclavian vein central line to confirm the placement and rule out complications like pneumothorax.

 

Other options:

 

  • Option B. Hemothorax:
    • Hemothorax involves the collection of blood in the thoracic cavity. Clinical examination typically reveals a dull note on percussion, not hyper-resonance. Breath sounds would also be absent, but the percussion finding differentiates it from pneumothorax.
  • Option C. Tension Pneumothorax:
    • Tension pneumothorax presents with severe respiratory distress and unstable vital signs, often necessitating immediate emergency intervention. The given scenario does not mention severe distress or unstable vitals, making simple pneumothorax more likely.
  • Option D. Neurogenic Shock:
    • Neurogenic shock is characterized by reduced blood pressure and heart rate due to loss of sympathetic tone. It does not cause absent breath sounds or hyper-resonance on percussion.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Accidental puncture of the pleura during subclavian vein central line insertion can lead to pneumothorax, characterized by absent breath sounds and hyper-resonance on percussion on the affected side.

questions.text: Identify the anatomical structure marked as 'B' in the given image? (FMGE DECEMBER 2021)
questions.solution:
Ans. A. Epiglottis

 

Explanation

 

The structure marked as 'B', is the Epiglottis.

 

The epiglottis is a leaf-shaped cartilaginous structure located at the base of the tongue, just behind the hyoid bone.

Its main function is to prevent food and liquids from entering the trachea (windpipe) during swallowing. When you swallow, the epiglottis folds down to cover the opening of the trachea, directing the ingested material into the esophagus and toward the stomach. Failure of this process can lead to choking.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Hyoid Bone: The hyoid bone is a horseshoe-shaped bone located in the neck, just above the larynx (voice box) and below the mandible (jawbone). It is unique in that it does not articulate with any other bone in the body but is suspended by ligaments and muscles.

 

Option C. Thyroid Cartilage: The thyroid cartilage is a large, shield-shaped cartilaginous structure located in the front of the neck. It forms the anterior portion of the larynx and is commonly referred to as the "Adam's apple." The thyroid cartilage houses the vocal cords, and its movement, along with the vocal cords, plays a critical role in voice production. During puberty, the thyroid cartilage often enlarges in males, resulting in the prominent Adam's apple seen in adult men.

 

Option D. Cricoid Cartilage: The cricoid cartilage is a ring-shaped cartilage located just below the thyroid cartilage in the neck. It forms the lower part of the larynx and provides support for the trachea above it. The cricoid cartilage is essential for maintaining the patency (openness) of the airway.

 

Educational Objective:

questions.text: A Rh-ve mother had a pregnancy with a Rh+ve fetus. This Rh incompatibility is which of the following type of hypersensitivity reaction? (FMGE DEC 2021)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Type II

 

Type II hypersensitivity reaction refers to an antibody-mediated immune reaction in which antibodies (IgG or IgM) are directed against cellular or extracellular matrix antigens, resulting in cellular destruction, functional loss, or damage to tissues. Damage can occur through multiple mechanisms.

 

 

Educational Objective

 

Rh incompatibility, where a Rh-negative mother produces antibodies against Rh-positive fetal red blood cells, is a Type II hypersensitivity reaction mediated by IgG or IgM antibodies.

questions.text: A 31-year-old lady with diabetes mellitus delivers a term neonate. Which of the following problems may be associated with the baby born to this lady? (FMGE DEC 2021)
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Hypoglycemia

 

In infants born to mothers with diabetes mellitus, the most common complication observed is hypoglycemia. This occurs due to the infant's pancreas producing high levels of insulin in response to maternal hyperglycemia. After birth, the supply of glucose from the mother is cut off, but the infant's high insulin levels persist, leading to hypoglycemia.

 

Infants born to diabetic mothers may present with several complications, including:

 

  • Macrosomia (large for gestational age): Increased glucose in the maternal blood crosses the placenta, causing the fetus to produce more insulin, which leads to increased growth and fat deposition.
  • Hypoglycemia: Due to increased insulin production.
  • Respiratory distress syndrome: Maternal diabetes can delay fetal lung maturity.
  • Neural tube defects: Increased risk due to poorly controlled maternal diabetes.
  • Hypocalcemia: Low calcium levels in the neonate, often due to maternal magnesium deficiency.
  • Cardiomegaly and heart failure: Due to high insulin levels affecting cardiac tissue.
  • Congenital heart defects: Ventricular or atrial septal defects, and transposition of the great vessels are more common in infants of diabetic mothers.
  • Lumbosacral agenesis: A rare congenital disorder affecting the lower spine.
  • Renal anomalies: Hydronephrosis, renal agenesis, and dysplasia.
  • Gastrointestinal atresia: Duodenal or anorectal atresia.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Hyperglycemia: This is more likely to be seen in the mother rather than the infant. The infant typically experiences hypoglycemia due to high insulin levels.

 

Option B. Tetralogy of Fallot: This congenital heart defect is more commonly associated with genetic syndromes such as Down syndrome rather than maternal diabetes. Infants of diabetic mothers are more likely to have septal defects or transposition of the great vessels.

 

Option C. Hypercalcemia: Infants of diabetic mothers are more prone to hypocalcemia rather than hypercalcemia.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Infants born to diabetic mothers are at increased risk of hypoglycemia due to high insulin levels.

questions.text: Based on the disease shown in the image, which of the following specimens would the filarial worms be absent? (FMGE DECEMBER 2021)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Saliva

 

The image depicts a condition known as lymphatic filariasis, which is characterized by severe swelling of the limbs, commonly referred to as elephantiasis. Lymphatic filariasis is caused by parasitic worms, mainly Wuchereria bancrofti, Brugia malayi, and Brugia timori.

 

Filarial worms are not found in saliva, making it an unsuitable specimen for diagnosis.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Blood: Filarial worms are typically detected in the peripheral blood. Microfilariae are usually found in the blood, especially at night (nocturnal periodicity), which is the best time to collect blood samples for diagnosis.

 

Option C. Urine: Though it is uncommon, microfilariae can sometimes be detected in urine in cases of chyluria, where lymphatic fluid leaks into the urinary tract.

 

Option D. Hydrocoele fluid: Filarial worms can be present in hydrocoele fluid, which is the fluid collected from a hydrocele, a common manifestation of lymphatic filariasis in men.

 

Educational Objective:

 

In lymphatic filariasis, filarial worms (microfilariae) are typically absent in saliva. Blood samples collected at night are the most common and effective specimens for diagnosing the presence of these parasites.

questions.text: A 20-year-old patient felt heaviness in his left scrotum, and reported to OPD. There was no pain or tenderness and transillumination test was negative. Most likely diagnosis in this patient would be? (FMGE DECEMEBR 2021)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Varicocele

 

The patient’s symptoms of heaviness in the scrotum without pain or tenderness, along with a negative transillumination test, are indicative of a varicocele.

 

  • Varicocele:
    • Description: A varicocele is an enlargement of the veins within the scrotum, specifically the pampiniform plexus.
    • Symptoms: It often presents with a feeling of heaviness or a dragging sensation in the scrotum.
    • Physical Exam: On physical examination, it can feel like a "bag of worms" due to the dilated, tortuous veins. The transillumination test is negative because the veins do not allow light to pass through.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Hydrocele:

 

  • Description: A hydrocele is a fluid-filled sac surrounding a testicle that causes swelling in the scrotum.
  • Transillumination: Hydrocele usually transilluminates (light passes through) because it contains fluid, which is not consistent with the patient’s negative transillumination test.

 

Option C. Testicular Torsion:

 

  • Description: Testicular torsion is a medical emergency where the spermatic cord twists, cutting off blood supply to the testicle.
  • Symptoms: It presents with sudden, severe pain and swelling of the scrotum, not just heaviness.

 

Option D. Epididymo-orchitis:

 

  • Description: Epididymo-orchitis is inflammation of the epididymis and/or testicle, usually due to infection.
  • Symptoms: It typically presents with pain, swelling, and tenderness, which are not reported in this patient.
  •  

Educational Objective:

 

A varicocele is characterized by dilated and tortuous veins within the scrotum, presenting with heaviness and a negative transillumination test. It is often more common on the left side.

questions.text: A female patient after resection of lipoma on the neck, developed an elevated scar which showed itching and burning sensation. The scar was contained within the wound margin. What is the diagnosis? (FMGE DECEMEBR 2021)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Hypertrophic scar

 

On the basis of the description provided in the question the correct answer would be B. Hypertrophic scar

 

Hypertrophic scar:

 

  • Hypertrophic scars are raised scars that remain within the boundaries of the original wound.
  • They arise when there's an overproduction of collagen, similar to keloids, but do not grow out of bounds.
  • They may be red, itchy, and painful, but they tend to improve over time, though they might not disappear completely.

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Keloid:

 

  • Keloids are a type of raised scar that extend beyond the boundaries of the original wound.
  • They can appear anywhere on the body, but they're most common over the sternum, on the earlobes, and on the shoulders.
  • They can be itchy or painful and may also pucker. They can be much larger than the original injury.

 

 

Option C. Suture granuloma:

 

  • This is a benign nodular inflammatory lesion, often with some fibrosis, which arises at the site of an incompletely absorbed suture.
  • It can be mistaken for a tumor recurrence, especially if it arises a few months after the surgical procedure.
  • Suture granulomas can cause local pain and might discharge some fluid.

 

 

Option D. Incision cut:

 

  • This typically refers to the surgical cut made during an operation. It doesn't usually refer to a type of scar.
  • Any wound, including incision cuts, can develop into a scar depending on various factors, including the depth and size of the wound, the person's age, heredity, sex, and ethnicity.

 

Educational Objective:

questions.text: A patient who is a chronic alcoholic, has signs of B1 deficiency. Which of the following is the marker for Vitamin B1 deficiency? (FMGE DECEMBER 2021)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) RBC transketolase activity

 

This is the correct answer. Red blood cell (RBC) transketolase activity is a key marker for thiamine deficiency. Transketolase is an enzyme that requires thiamine as a cofactor. In cases of thiamine deficiency, the activity of transketolase in RBCs is reduced. Often, the diagnosis is confirmed by demonstrating an increase in enzyme activity upon the addition of thiamine pyrophosphate (the active form of thiamine) to a blood sample, indicating a deficiency in the vitamin.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. RBC Glyceraldehyde Reductase Activity: This enzyme is not commonly used as a marker for vitamin B1 deficiency. Glyceraldehyde reductase is involved in carbohydrate metabolism, but its activity does not directly correlate with thiamine levels.

 

Option C. Homocysteine Activity: Elevated levels of homocysteine are more commonly associated with deficiencies of folate (vitamin B9), vitamin B12, and vitamin B6, but not specifically with thiamine deficiency.

 

Option D. Pyridoxal 5'-Phosphate: This is the active form of vitamin B6 (pyridoxine), not vitamin B1. Deficiency of vitamin B6 affects different metabolic pathways and is identified using different markers.

 

Educational Objective:

 

RBC transketolase activity is a marker used to assess thiamine (vitamin B1) deficiency. Thiamine is essential for the activity of enzymes, including transketolase, involved in carbohydrate metabolism. Reduced transketolase activity in red blood cells (RBCs) can indicate a deficiency of thiamine.

 

Ref: Harper’s Illustrated Biochemistry 32nd edition Page no. 542

choices.text: Rat tail sign
Bird beak sign

questions.text: A 55-year-old male presents to the emergency department complaining of severe chest pain and difficulty swallowing. He describes the chest pain as a squeezing sensation that radiates to his back. He has been experiencing intermittent episodes of chest pain and difficulty swallowing for the past few months, but this episode is the most severe and has lasted for the past 30 minutes. Barium swallow was done and is shown here. What is the sign? (FMGE DECEMBER 2021)
questions.solution:
Ans. A. Corkscrew esophagus

 

  • The corkscrew appearance of the esophagus is seen in diffuse esophageal spasm.
  • Diffuse esophageal spasm (DES) is a motility disorder of the esophagus.
  • Manometry is the IOC for motility disorders.
  • C/F: Retrosternal chest pain that may mimic MI.
  • Treatment: Calcium channel blocker (CCB)

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Rat tail sign : Achalasia cardia/Carcinoma Esophagus

 

 

Option C.  Bird beak sign : Achalasia cardia

 

 

Option D. Feline esophagus:  Refers to the appearance of multiple transient rings in the esophagus often associated with reflux esophagitis.

 

 

Educational Objective:

 

The corkscrew appearance of the esophagus on a barium swallow study is indicative of diffuse esophageal spasm, a condition that should be considered in patients presenting with non-cardiac chest pain and dysphagia.

questions.text: An elderly obese man was brought to casualty with complaints of severe chest pain for the last two hours. He has also had profuse sweating, pain in the left arm, nausea, and one episode of vomiting. On examination, his HR is 58 and BP is 90/60 mm of Hg. ECG was done and it shows the following finding. Cardiac biomarkers showed elevated troponin levels. What is the most likely diagnosis? (FMGE DEC 2021)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Inferior wall MI

 

The symptoms of severe chest pain, pain radiating to the left arm, profuse sweating, nausea, and vomiting, combined with hypotension (BP 90/60 mmHg) and bradycardia (HR - 58), strongly suggest an inferior wall myocardial infarction. Elevated troponin levels confirm myocardial injury.

 

ECG findings – ST elevation in lead II, III & aVf – inferior wall MI

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Anterior wall MI: Typically presents with tachycardia rather than bradycardia and different ECG findings.

 

ECG - ST elevation in V1 to V4 – anterior wall MI

 

Option C. Posterior wall MI: Less common and often associated with ST depression in V1-V3 rather than the symptoms described.

 

ECG - ST elevation in V7, V8 & V9 and characteristic pattern of tall R wave, ST depression in V1-V2 and an upright T wave – Posterior wall MI

 

Option D. Pericarditis: Presents with pleuritic type of chest pain that is relieved by leaning forward and may have a pericardial friction rub on auscultation, not necessarily accompanied by the severe hemodynamic instability described here.

 

ECG finding – Global ST elevation

 

Educational Objective:

 

Inferior wall MI is characterized by chest pain, bradycardia, hypotension, and elevated troponin levels.

 

MC affected right coronary artery.

questions.text: Pressure required to cause a pressure sore is: (FMGE DECEMEBR 2021)
questions.solution:
Ans. D) 30 mm of Hg

 

Pressure ulcer is because of prolonged external pressure when external pressure exceeds the capillary occlusive pressure which is 30 mmHg. This causes the blood flow to the skin to cease, leading to tissue anoxia, necrosis and ulceration at that site.

 

Pressure ulcer or Bed Sore or Decubitus ulcer occurs at the dependent portions of the body. The most common site is Ischial tuberosity > Greater trochanter >Sacrum.

 

Stages of Pressure Sore:

 

Stage 1: Intact skin with non-blanchable erythema

 

Stage 2: Partial thickness loss of dermis

 

Stage 3: Full thickness loss of dermis, visible subcutaneous tissue

 

Stage 4: Full thickness loss of dermis with exposed bone, tendon or muscle.

 

Its prevention includes measures like adequate nutrition, wound care and dressings, pressure redistribution. Its management includes intermittent negative pressure wound therapy in which a pressure of -125 mm Hg is applied intermittently.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Pressure ulcers develop when external pressure exceeds capillary occlusive pressure (30 mmHg), leading to tissue ischemia and necrosis. Prevention and management strategies are crucial to mitigate the risk and promote healing.

questions.text: A middle-aged man presents with a genital ulcer, as shown below. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis? (FMGE DECEMBER 2021)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Granuloma inguinale

 

The image shows a red, beefy genital ulcer. Granuloma inguinale, also known as donovanosis, is a sexually transmitted infection caused by the bacterium Klebsiella granulomatis. This condition is characterized by painless, progressive ulcerative lesions without regional lymphadenopathy. The microscopic findings often reveal Donovan bodies, which are intracellular inclusions seen within macrophages.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Lymphogranuloma venereum:

 

  • Caused by Chlamydia trachomatis (serovars L1, L2, L3).
  • It presents initially with a small, painless genital ulcer followed by painful inguinal lymphadenopathy (buboes).

 

Option C. Chancroid:

 

  • Caused by Haemophilus ducreyi.
  • Characterized by painful genital ulcers and tender suppurative inguinal lymphadenopathy.

 

Option D. Gonorrhoea:

 

  • Caused by Neisseria gonorrhoeae.
  • Typically presents with urethritis, cervicitis, and in some cases, disseminated infection. It does not usually present as an ulcerative genital lesion.

 

Educational Objective:

questions.text: Which artery is being palpated in the image shown below? (FMGE DECEMBER 2021)
questions.solution:
Ans. B. Posterior tibial artery

 

Explanation

 

  • The posterior tibial artery is palpated between the medial malleolus and the calcaneal tendon, as shown in the image.

The posterior tibial artery pulse can be felt against the heel bone calcaneum about 2 cm below and behind (postero-inferior) the medial malleolus. The artery is felt in front (anterior) of the medial border of the tendocalcaneus, between the tendons of flexor hallucis longus and flexor digitorum longus.

Note: Posterior tibial artery lies deep to the flexor retinaculum, hence, the patient is asked to 'invert' (turn the sole inside) his foot to relax the flexor retinaculum, before palpating the artery.

 

 

Other options:

 

Option A) Anterior tibial artery- The anterior tibial artery terminates at the level of the ankle joint, where it gives off its terminal branch, the dorsalis pedis artery. The anterior tibial artery pulse can be palpated near the origin of the dorsalis pedis artery on the dorsum of the foot lateral to the extensor hallucis longus tendon.

 

Option C) Dorsalis pedis artery - The dorsalis pedis artery is a major artery that supplies blood to the dorsum of the foot. It can be palpated by gently pressing your fingers along the midline of the foot, usually just lateral to the extensor hallucis longus tendon, between the first and second metatarsal bones.

 

Option D) Popliteal artery-The popliteal artery is a major blood vessel located in the popliteal fossa, which is the hollow area at the back of the knee joint.
