This artery is a continuation of the femoral artery, which runs down the thigh, and it plays a crucial role in supplying blood to the lower leg and foot

 

Educational Objective

 

The posterior tibial artery lies just posterior to the medial malleolus. It can be felt most readily by curling the fingers of the examining hand anteriorly around the ankle, indenting the soft tissues in the space between the medial malleolus and the Achilles tendon, above the calcaneum.

questions.text: Dystrophin protein is absent completely in which of the following diseases? (FMGE DEC 2021)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Duchenne Muscular Dystrophy

 

  • Duchenne muscular dystrophy is due to the mutation in Dystrophin gene.
  • It is a X linked recessive inherited disease.
  • Calf hypertrophy may be “pseudohypertrophy”,
  • Positive Gower sign indicates lower limb girdle weakness and raised CPK levels in a male with weakness in lower limbs is indicative of Duchenne muscular hypertrophy.
  • The serum CK level is consistently greatly elevated in DMD, even in pre-symptomatic stages, including at birth. The usual serum concentration is 15,000-35,000 IU/L (normal <160 IU/L)

 

Muscle biopsy:

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Becker's Muscular Dystrophy:

 

  • Duchenne muscular dystrophy (DMD) and Becker muscular dystrophy (BMD) are both caused by mutations in the dystrophin gene.
  • In DMD, the mutation results in little or no production of dystrophin protein, whereas in BMD, the mutation leads to the production of abnormal dystrophin protein.

 

Option C. Myasthenia Gravis:

 

  • Myasthenia gravis (MG) is a neuromuscular disorder caused by an autoimmune response that targets acetylcholine receptors (AChRs) at neuromuscular junctions.
  • The autoimmune response reduces the number of available AChRs, leading to muscle weakness and easy fatigue.

 

Option D. Lambert Eaton Myasthenic Syndrome:

 

  • Lambert-Eaton syndrome (LES) is a neuromuscular junction disorder characterized by reduced release of acetylcholine (ACh) from the presynaptic nerve terminals.
  • LES is caused by autoantibodies that target the voltage-gated calcium channels in the nerve terminals, which are responsible for releasing ACh.
  • Even with normal levels of ACh presynaptic concentration, ACh vesicle numbers, and postsynaptic ACh receptors, LES impairs ACh release, resulting in muscle weakness and fatigue.Top of Form

 

Educational Objective:

 

Duchenne Muscular Dystrophy is characterized by the complete absence of dystrophin protein due to a mutation in the dystrophin gene.

 

Ref - Nelson 20th Edition, Page No- 2976 to 2977.

questions.text: Identify the class of immunoglobulin shown in the image below? (FMGE DECEMBER 2021)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) IgA

 

The above image shows a dimeric structure, characteristic of secretory IgA. IgA immunoglobulin is the major antibody responsible for mucosal immunity. Its serum levels are usually low. It is predominantly present in the extravascular secretions. It is present in secretions such as milk, saliva, and tears, and in secretions of the respiratory, intestinal, and genital tracts.

 

When present in the serum, it exists as a monomer similar to IgG. However, when it is secreted, it exists as a dimer.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. IgG: IgG is a monomer and is the most abundant immunoglobulin in blood and extracellular fluid. It plays a critical role in opsonization, neutralization, complement activation, and placental transfer.

 

Option C. IgM: IgM is a pentamer in its secreted form and is the first antibody produced during an initial immune response. It is mainly found in the blood and lymph and is effective in agglutination and complement activation.

 

Option D. IgE: IgE is a monomer and is primarily involved in allergic reactions and defence against parasites. It binds to mast cells and basophils, triggering histamine release upon antigen binding.

 

Educational Objective:

questions.text: Which of the following cell organelles is associated with killing bacteria and viruses? (FMGE DECEMBER 2021)
questions.solution:
Ans. B. Lysosomes

 

Lysosomes are cellular organelles that contain hydrolytic enzymes, such as acid hydrolase, which can break down a variety of biological molecules. They play a crucial role in intracellular digestion by degrading material taken into the cell, including bacteria and viruses. This ability to break down potentially harmful organisms makes them an integral part of the cell’s defense mechanism. They are often referred to as "suicidal bags" because their enzymes can also lead to autolysis, where they destroy the cell itself if they rupture or malfunction.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Peroxisomes: Incorrect because peroxisomes are primarily involved in the metabolism of fatty acids and reactive oxygen species, not directly in killing bacteria or viruses.

 

Option C. Golgi apparatus: Incorrect as the Golgi apparatus is mainly responsible for modifying, sorting, and packaging proteins and lipids for secretion or use within the cell.

 

Option D. Ribosomes: Incorrect because ribosomes are involved in protein synthesis through the translation of mRNA and are not directly involved in the degradation of invasive pathogens.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Lysosomes are critical in the cellular defense against pathogens through their content of hydrolytic enzymes capable of degrading foreign invaders such as bacteria and viruses. They also play a role in the turnover of cellular components and can induce cell death through autolysis.

questions.text: An alcoholic patient who is diagnosed with chronic hepatitis has been admitted to the emergency room for hematemesis for the last 2 days due to variceal bleeding. The patient is in shock. You are the doctor in the emergency medicine and you have started the first-line treatment, but the patient does not survive. What is the underlying cause of death in this patient? (FMGE DECEMEBR 2021)
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Hypovolemic shock

 

Profound blood loss in setting of variceal bleed is likely to lead to hypovolemic shock.

 

 

Parameters to assess shock:

 

  • Shock index = HR/SBP
  • Modified Shock index = HR/MAP, it is better for mortality rate predictions.

 

The patient’s underlying cause of death is hypovolemic shock due to profound blood loss from variceal bleeding. Variceal bleeding, a common complication in patients with chronic liver disease and portal hypertension, can lead to significant blood loss. The body's compensatory mechanisms may initially maintain blood pressure and perfusion, but with continued blood loss, these mechanisms fail, leading to decreased cardiac output, hypotension, and ultimately, hypovolemic shock. Despite first-line treatments such as fluid resuscitation and blood transfusions, if the bleeding is not controlled promptly, the patient can succumb to hypovolemic shock.

 

Other options:

 

  • Option A. Hepatic failure:
    • Hepatic failure, while a severe condition in patients with chronic liver disease, is not the immediate cause of death in the scenario described. The acute cause of death here is related to blood loss and shock, not liver failure directly.
  • Option B. Aspiration pneumonitis:
    • Aspiration pneumonitis is a potential complication in patients with hematemesis, where vomitus can be aspirated into the lungs, leading to inflammation and infection. However, in this scenario, the patient's death is more directly attributed to hypovolemic shock from blood loss rather than aspiration pneumonitis.
  • Option C. Chronic hepatitis:
    • Chronic hepatitis is an underlying condition contributing to the patient's variceal bleeding, but it is not the immediate cause of death. The acute event leading to death is the uncontrolled hemorrhage and resultant shock.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Profound blood loss from variceal bleeding can lead to hypovolemic shock, which is the immediate cause of death in such patients if not promptly managed.

questions.text: A 50-year-old man presents to you with features of anemia, fever, and recurrent nose bleeds. On examination there is hepatosplenomegaly, Lab investigations revealed: Hb = 6g/dL, TLC count = 40,000/ cu.mm with 10% blasts and platelet count = 12,000/cu.mm. On further investigation, t(8;21) was detected in the blasts. What is the diagnosis? (FMGE DEC 2021)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Acute myeloblastic leukemia (AML)

 

The presence of anemia, hepatosplenomegaly, blasts in the blood (<20%), and the t(8;21) translocation is indicative of AML.

 

Typically, the diagnosis of AML requires a blast count greater than 20; However, if a signature cytogenetic abnormality, such as t(8,21), is present, a diagnosis of AML can be made even if the blast count is less than 20%.

 

Other key cytogenetic changes indicative of AML include:

 

  • t(15;17): This translocation results in the PML-RARA fusion protein.
  • Inversion 16 (or t(16;16)): Known as inversion 16 or CBF (core binding factor) leukemia.

 

These 3 signature cytogenetic abnormalities are so characteristic of AML that their presence alone can confirm the diagnosis, bypassing the need for a high blast count.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Acute lymphoblastic leukemia (ALL): Typically presents in children and does not commonly show t(8;21).

 

Option C. Preleukemia: Not a definitive diagnosis with these findings.

 

Option D. Aleukemic leukemia: Refers to leukemia without blasts in the peripheral blood, which is not the case here.

 

Educational Objective:

 

AML is suggested by anemia, hepatosplenomegaly, blasts in blood, and the t(8;21) translocation.

questions.text: A 2-year-old child with signs of malnutrition, including wasting, stunted growth, generalized edema, and symptoms of vitamin A deficiency such as Bitot's spots and xerophthalmia, has a recorded weight of 7.5 kg. What is the most appropriate oral dose of vitamin A for therapeutic supplementation in this child? (FMGE DEC 2021)
questions.solution:
Ans. B. 100000 IU

 

For a 2-year-old child weighing below the standard weight range for age and exhibiting signs of severe vitamin A deficiency, the recommended dose is 100,000 IU of vitamin A. This dose is generally administered to correct the deficiency and prevent the progression of xerophthalmia and other associated conditions. The standard guideline for vitamin A supplementation in children aged more than 12 months but malnourished or underweight (like in this case, where the child is just 7.5 kg) advises a slightly lower dose to prevent the risks associated with high-dose vitamin A in malnourished children.

 

Oral dose of vitamin A as per the age:

 

Age < 12 months – dose given is 1 lac IU each day on day 0,1, after 14 days

 

Age > 12 months – dose given is 2 lac IU each day on day 0,1, after 14 day

 

Additional Information

 

Vitamin A Under National Immunization schedule (NIS)

 

 

Vitamin A Deficiency: Xerophthalmia

 

 

Prevalence criteria for determining the Xerophthalmia problem in a community: (Preschool children 6 months- 6 years).

 

 

 

Educational Objective:

 

Under JSSK scheme, a child more than 12 months old less than 8 kg weight, malnourished with Vitamin A deficiency, oral dose of Vitamin A required is 1 Lac IU

questions.text: A 24-year-old woman reports sudden high fever, intense muscle pain, eye pain, and a rash. Lab tests indicate low white blood cell and platelet counts. She had a similar fever years ago. Her doctor considers a re-infection with a different viral strain that might worsen due to an immunological reaction. Which virus is known for severe symptoms upon re-infection? (FMGE DEC 2021)
questions.solution:
Ans. C. Dengue

 

Dengue virus is of 4 subtypes. DEN1, DEN2, DEN3, DEN4. Infection from one subtype does not provide cross immunity against the other sub types. On the contrary it has been seen that following infection with one serotype, if there is secondary dengue infection with a different serotype, then the heterotypic non neutralizing antibodies from the previous infection leads to increased activation of mononuclear phagocytic cells and cytokine release at a high rate, leading to Dengue Hemorrhagic fever, Dengue Shock Syndrome etc. The risk is particularly more when DEN1 infection is followed by a secondary infection with DEN2 serotype.

 

Other Options: 

 

Option A. Measles: An acute viral infection that presents with cough, coryza, conjunctivitis, and a characteristic rash. Reinfections are rare, and severity is not heightened upon re-infection.

 

Option B. Hepatitis: Various types of hepatitis viruses (A, B, C, D, E) can cause liver inflammation. Secondary infections or re-infections do not typically result in more severe disease.

 

Option D. Rubella: Also known as German measles, it causes a mild rash and fever. Reinfections, if they occur, are not associated with an increase in disease severity.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Dengue is notorious for more severe symptoms during a second infection with a different serotype due to antibody-dependent enhancement (ADE). ADE facilitates the virus's entry into cells, leading to higher viral loads and severe clinical outcomes like Dengue Hemorrhagic Fever or Dengue Shock Syndrome.

questions.text: At her first antenatal checkup, a 26-year-old woman asks about the recommended number of visits during pregnancy. What is the minimum number of antenatal visits advised for optimal health outcomes for her and her baby? (FMGE DEC 2021)
questions.solution:
Ans. C. 4

 

A minimum of 4 visits covering the entire period of pregnancy should be the target.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Minimum ANC visits:

 

  • 1st visit - within 12 weeks, preferably as soon as the pregnancy is suspected, for registration of pregnancy and first antenatal check-up.
  • 2nd visit - between 14 and 26 weeks.
  • 3rd visit - between 28 and 34 weeks.
  • 4th visit - between 36 weeks and term.

choices.text: B12 (Vitamin B12)

questions.text: The micronutrient that is deficient after ileal resection:
questions.solution:
Ans. B) B12 (Vitamin B12)

 

Option B. Vitamin B12: Ileal resection can lead to malabsorption of vitamin B12, as the ileum is the primary site for the absorption of this vitamin in the small intestine.

 

Other Options

 

Option A. Folate: While the absorption of folate can be affected by certain intestinal conditions, ileal resection primarily impacts the absorption of vitamin B12, not folate.

 

Option C. Iron: Ileal resection can lead to malabsorption of various nutrients, but vitamin B12 deficiency is more specifically associated with ileal resection.

 

Option D. Copper: Copper is absorbed in the stomach and proximal small intestine, and deficiencies are not commonly associated with ileal resection.

 

Educational objective:

 

The intrinsic factor, produced in the stomach, binds to vitamin B12 in the ileum, allowing for its absorption. Ileal resection can result in a deficiency of vitamin B12, leading to pernicious anemia and neurological symptoms.

 

Ref: Harper’s Illustrated Biochemistry 32nd edition Page no. 544

questions.text: What is the level at which spinal cord ends in infants?
questions.solution:
Ans. B. L3

In new born Spinal cord terminates at Upper border of L3.

In adults the spinal cord terminates at lower border of L1.

choices.text: Middle cranial fossa fracture
Frontal Bone abscess

questions.text: Battle sign is seen in?
questions.solution:
Ans. A. Middle cranial fossa fracture

Battle sign is seen specifically in fracture of middle cranial fossa.

Battle sign, CSF otorrhea, hemotympanum, bleeding from ear are features of fracture of middle cranial fossa.

CSF rhinorrhea, black eyes are feature of anterior cranial fossa fracture.

Battle sign and black eye are ectopic bruises.

choices.text: Immediately pour ice-cold water on his body
Put the foot of the soldier in ice immediately
Injection of Benzodiazepine
Wrap a cool water-soaked blanket over the person at around 25-degree Celsius temperature and switch on the fan.

questions.text: A Soldier was participating in a marathon in hot temperatures of 40 degrees Celsius. After running for 10 kilometres he suddenly collapsed. What first aid should have been provided to him by the local people?
questions.solution:
Ans. D. Wrap a cool water-soaked blanket over the person at around 25-degree Celsius temperature and switch on the fan.

The soldier would have suffered from heat exhaustion / heat stroke due to running in extreme temperature.

Heat exhaustion is characterized by dehydration, disorientation and sweating. If it is not treated, it leads to heat stroke.

Management - Primary treatment is to cover the body with wet cloth and decrease body temperature by evaporative losses.

Cold water / Ice should not be used as it will cause vasoconstriction leading to heat retention in body.

choices.text: External auditory canal

questions.text: In Branchial fistula the internal opening is located in which part of the pharynx?
questions.solution:
Ans. B. Pyriform Sinus

External opening of the branchial fistula is located in the lateral aspect of the neck below thyroid and cricoid cartilage just anterior to sternocleidomastoid muscle. The internal opening of Branchial fistula is seen in the Pyriform Sinus.

questions.text: A young patient suffered from Blunt trauma to the abdomen and is taken to the casualty. He is unconscious and hypotensive. You are the casualty doctor and you carry out basic resuscitation with Intravenous fluids and the FAST comes out to be positive. He is not improving despite Intravenous fluids. The next step is?
questions.solution:
Ans. B. Exploratory Laparotomy

 

Management in Unstable patient with blunt trauma abdomen:

 

FAST positive – Possibility of bleeding in the body leading to hypotension.

 

Next step - Explorative laparotomy is to be done.

 

Note: Diagnostic laparoscopy is not needed in unstable patients as FAST is already positive suggesting internal bleeding.

 

 

Ref: Miller’s Anesthesia, 9th Ed. Pg 2149

questions.text: Most common cause of blindness among children in India?
questions.solution:
Ans. D. Vitamin A deficiency

The most common causes of blindness in adults and also overall is Cataract, whereas the most common cause of blindness in children is Vitamin A deficiency.

The above image shows Bitot’s spot- a sign of Vitamin A deficiency.

choices.text: The contraceptive result after 3 months

questions.text: All are true for vasectomy except:
questions.solution:
Ans. A. Immediate Sterilization

Vasectomy: It is permanent method of contraception in males wherein the vas deferens is cut. Nowadays the non-scalpel method is preferred. It doesn’t cause immediate sterility; barrier method is recommended for 3 months as spermatozoa takes 3 months to clear the tract.

questions.text: A patient suffered from a fracture neck of Femur for which he underwent Total hip replacement and was immobilized for a period of 3 months. Suddenly he developed breathlessness, cyanosis and was brought to the emergency. What can be the likely cause of this condition?
questions.solution:
Ans. B. Venous thromboembolism

Prolonged period of immobilization following Total hip replacement leads to Deep vein thrombosis. DVT leads to risk of pulmonary venous thromboembolism which can lead to breathlessness.

Fat embolism occurs in case of multiple long bone fractures like lower limb fractures. It is seen within 24-48 hours. It is characterized by dyspnea, petechiae in chest, axilla , retina, tachycardia.

questions.text: Identify the radiological investigation showing polycystic kidney below.
questions.solution:
Ans. C. MRI

The given image is MRI Kidney since bone is black here.

In AD PKD, both kidneys are bulky with large cysts replacing the parenchyma of the kidneys.
